SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I rose to speak on the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill I was sitting here contemplating the terrible damage that has been done by Sydney airport to the people in my electorate and to the people of my previous electorate of Grayndler. I was first elected to public life in 1971 as a councillor on Marrickville Council on a policy of reducing aircraft noise. It is appalling that 26 years later I am still in parliament talking about the atrocious effect that Sydney airport has on the people of my electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, that airport was never really planned. When it became the principal airport for Sydney, no‐one looked ahead to the day when air transport might be the usual way of moving people between Australian cities and overseas. Nobody looked ahead and nobody listened to the growing complaints of residents.

This lack of interest can largely be attributed to one factor: the residents of the suburbs around the airport were, for the most part, working class. They did not carry the weight of being in marginal seats. They did not have access to the media. They were not the rich and powerful. The airport kept growing and evolving and the planes kept getting bigger and noisier and, unfortunately, far more frequent.

The growth of a very centrally and conveniently located airport was in the interests of all who could afford to use the facility and in the interests of the owners of airlines and the bureaucrats responsible for building and maintaining the airport. This very powerful lobby group won hands down every time.

The airport only emerged as a major issue once the planes became of such a size and frequency that they started flying low over suburbs which were of upper or middle class. These people had access to the media and lived in marginal seats. Suddenly the noise and pollution became an issue and suddenly governments started focusing on the problems caused by Sydney airport.

I do not expect miracles and the people of my electorate do not expect miracles. There is no expectation on my part or, I think, on the part of most of my constituents that Sydney airport will one day be packed up and taken away and that the site will be turned into parkland or a marina development. Indeed, many of my constituents work at the airport. It is a very significant local employer and should remain that way.

But what the people of my electorate do expect is a fair and just outcome for the noise and pollution that they have put up with over the years. I speak particularly of my current electorate and the residents of the suburbs of Earlwood and Kingsgrove, who are suffering under the new flight path regime instituted by the Howard government.

I cannot gloss over the decision of my own party to construct the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. I was vocal in my opposition to this decision as were a number of other Labor members whose electorates surrounded the airport. That decision, however, was carried out with the full support of the then opposition, the now government. The current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, were the ones who were saying we should expand Sydney airport and we should do it quickly.

They fully endorsed that course of action until it became obvious that the optimum flight paths for using parallel runways at Sydney airport would take the traffic over their electorates. What a turnaround! From espousing the virtues of a third runway and even being supportive of raising the airport curfew, the Liberal Party and its members of parliament went full circle.

By the time the election came around we had the Prime Minister saying to the electors of Lowe, `If you vote for Mr Zammit'—the current member for Lowe—`you will have no more aircraft noise. If you want aircraft noise, you should keep on voting for Labor's candidate. If you want your property values to go up, you should vote for Mr Zammit.'

BREAK.PARA: Unfortunately, the people of Lowe took the Prime Minister on his word and they voted for Mr Zammit. They believed the Prime Minister when he said that there would be no planes flying over the electorate of Lowe under a Liberal government. They were sucked in. The Prime Minister has not stopped the planes flying over Lowe. But I do note that he has stopped them flying over his own electorate—self-interest will always out.

The Prime Minister has just moved the noise around so that more people suffer from the effects of the airport. Those suffering at the moment include the residents of Earlwood and Kingsgrove in my electorate who now have a great many flights skimming over their rooftops any time from 5.30 a.m. until midnight seven days a week.

Even more alarming to all those people living around Sydney airport was the decision to go back to basics over the location of a second Sydney airport. For over 20 years we have been looking at a site for a second Sydney airport. The Fraser government in the long distant past instituted the major airport needs of Sydney inquiry to look at where we should have an airport. Finally, after the Labor government made the disgraceful decision about the third runway they decided on Badgerys Creek as the preferred site for the second airport for Sydney as part of that package.

Without any forewarning after the last election, particularly to the voters of Hughes, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development suddenly dragged out a Holsworthy option and put it forward as a possible airport site. This sop to a group of Liberal Party supporters and the Lawrence Hargrave project delayed yet again any real progress towards a second Sydney airport. It was another red herring thrown into the ring to distract anyone who was interested from the real game—the game of getting a second airport into the Sydney region and thereby ameliorating the effects of aircraft noise and pollution on the people of the inner west and south-west of Sydney.

Finally, a few weeks ago the government came out and confirmed what everybody already knew—Holsworthy was a stupid proposition and Badgerys Creek was the only viable site left in the Sydney region for a second Sydney airport. This was the position we had come to in the Labor Party many years earlier. Badgerys Creek will provide a solution for the increasing problems with Kingsford Smith airport that is just and fair to all Sydneysiders. It will also, like Kingsford Smith, generate a great deal of employment where it is needed out in the western suburbs.

But in the same way that justice delayed is justice denied, the delaying of the construction of Badgerys Creek will deny the people of my electorate and those surrounding Sydney airport any hope of an improved quality of life or even a halt to the deterioration of their current quality of life.

While we await a longer term solution, Kingsford Smith should be managed to ensure that the least possible noise and pollution to the fewest number of people is achieved. One key aspect of such a management plan is to limit the number of take-offs and landings to ensure that there is not continued growth at Sydney airport.

The plan put forward in the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 simply revisits the proposals in the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill 1996, which was put forward in this House last year by my colleague the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and me. The member for Grayndler and I proposed a cap on aircraft movements of 80 movements an hour into and out of Kingsford Smith airport. This would hold traffic at Sydney airport at around its current levels.

Many of course would tell you that such a cap is not necessary—those people who advocated the third runway and those people who advocated lifting the curfew. They believe that the airport should be utilised to its limit—and that limit is being talked as being up to as many as 120 movements an hour, two movements a minute, one movement every 30 seconds. They also suggest the lifting of the curfew. The more bizarre of them even suggest a fourth runway.

These same people are quick to advocate no second airport for Sydney. They seem convinced that, if they keep ignoring the prob lems associated with Kingsford Smith airport, these problems will go away. They are happy to see the difficulty experienced by those in the inner west exacerbated by increasing the use of this site, which I might say is one of the smallest site areas of any large international airport in the world.

Without some artificial limit being placed on the number of aircraft movements, there will be no pressure to address the real aviation needs of the Sydney region. Already we have seen the projections passed that were made some five years ago about when Sydney airport would saturate. With the exponential growth that you are seeing in this country—both international tourism into and out of Australia, and the attitude of Australians of moving around the country via aircraft rather than via cars, buses and trains as people used to do—there is going to be more and more demand on Sydney airport. The deregulation of the airline industry put in place by the previous Labor government has seen aircraft fares reduce and come within the range of ordinary working people. This has seen the use of aircraft skyrocket.

Yet another set of short‐term fixes would be put in place if the people who have the attitude that Sydney should get bigger and bigger are the ones who win. There is a real danger with the approach to the 2000 Olympics—when the facilities at Sydney airport will be pushed to the absolute limit—that people will say, `We have coped with Olympics. Let's leave it there and let's do nothing.' If the government had shown some leadership on this issue rather than dangling the Holsworthy red herring, which is something that amazed everyone, we would have seen a start on the facilities at Badgerys Creek and probably seen them in place to deal with some of the overload in the year 2000. But we saw nothing. We saw the government cause 18 months of delay once again.

On behalf of my constituents, the people of Watson, I support this legislation wholeheartedly. I think the government should have been a little bit more generous and dealt with the legislation of the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and me last year, or indeed done what the minister said he would, which was introduce legislation last year to do just this. But better late than never. This legislation will go some way to assisting the residents of the electorate of Watson, and particularly those of the suburbs of Earlwood and Kingsgrove, to at least maintain some standard of comfort rather than have it further eroded.

But the government should not stop here. The government should announce that it will be starting work on a second airport at Badgerys Creek immediately. If the government was fair dinkum it would provide an injection of funds from the Federation Fund to kick‐start this project and thus assure the people of Sydney an aviation infrastructure capable of taking them into the 21st century and reassure the people of my electorate their problems will not continue to escalate. If the government has money available to build a railway from Adelaide to Darwin then surely there should be money for a genuine infrastructure program which will be used and of benefit to Australia rather than a bit of cargo cult for the voters in the Northern Territory.

Enough is enough! The government must get on with building Sydney's second airport. This legislation goes some way to at least making that a more urgent matter because, by capping the movements at Sydney, we will ensure that people have to focus on the future rather than continuing to have ad hoc decisions at Sydney which will cause that airport to get bigger, noisier and nastier. It would be stupid, as I said earlier, for any member who represents the airport to say that it should be closed. It is a very significant generator of work for the people of my electorate and I have never argued that Sydney airport should be closed. We should tame this beast, and we should tame it now, but we should ensure also that the work that it provides stays there for the people who live around it.

I also think that those people out in the western suburbs who were originally proponents of Badgerys Creek, and have now all of a sudden become opponents of it, should start to think about the people that they represent who need jobs, as well as the nimby approach, because as the Mayor of Liverpool has said, Badgerys Creek airport will become the single most significant generator of jobs in the western suburbs of Sydney that we have seen in the last 50 years. It will provide work and it will provide work for ordinary working‐class people, which is what is needed out in the western suburbs.

But we must tame Kingsford‐Smith. This legislation goes some way to doing it. I commend the government for that, but I condemn the government for taking so long to get to this piece of legislation. I condemn the government for not starting on Badgerys Creek yet. By condemning the current government I also do not give any comfort to my colleagues who held this project up either. The previous Labor government was wrong in building the third runway. The previous Labor government was wrong in not getting a start on Badgerys Creek, although it did make the final decision to build the airport, and it did acquire the land. The current government has sold a large site adjacent to the airport which will make it very difficult to keep up with some of the plans that should occur at Badgerys Creek.

To conclude my remarks, this legislation will at least say to the people of my electorate that the beast has been tamed a little, and there will be some certainty put back into their lives. I could make some remarks about the government's phoney program of sharing the noise, but I do not think that is all that constructive.

I will just complete my remarks by picking up on a matter regarding the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), who the government has sold out with great distinction. The member for Lowe, in his remarks, mentioned a stunt he got up to by writing to all the local councils and members about his press release. All I will say to the member for Lowe is: stop the stunts, get out there and try to exercise some influence on your government. You got elected on the phoney promise of no planes over Lowe. When there are no planes over Lowe, then he can hold his head up high. He has been sold out by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), he has sold out his own people and all he can get up to is stunts. I think that probably shows about the level of the member for Lowe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 delivers on another commitment that has been made by the coalition. Certainly we accept the support that we have been receiving from members of the opposition, although I noted there has been a little bit of a division in the opposition camp with regard to the development of Badgerys Creek. I acknowledge the contribution of the member for Watson (Mr McLeay) in support of that option and would say in defence of the government's actions on the EIS process that at least we did that.

SPEECH.PARA: We went through that rigorous EIS process with Holsworthy to make sure that the decision to exclude it was a justifiable decision and to make sure that the decision on Sydney's second airport was justified on solid grounds. We can move forward now to the completion of that process with Badgerys Creek. In listening to the debate last night, I noted that there is still some division between some members of the opposition with regard to the proposal to build Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek, but I note the very positive comments of the member for Watson.

The bill that we are debating is a delivery of a coalition commitment. It provides certainty for operators. Everybody knows what is going on. It establishes a maximum limit on aircraft movements at KSA to 80 movements per hour while introducing a slot management system. I suppose in discussing these matters everybody has their own individual concerns and most of them are born out of representing their constituencies. The opposition speakers we have been listening to obviously have strong feelings one way or the other. We know that the development and management of the KSA airport has been a very vexed issue for the Labor Party and the seats around it. We heard the member for Watson say that he never agreed with the establishment of the parallel runway.

As a representative of regional Australia I, too, was keen to see in this slot management system an acknowledgment of the important role that regional airlines play in New South Wales. I understand that they have been given a regional airline slot pool, which has been introduced in this bill as well.

The opposition are complaining about the time it has taken the government to make more progress or to get the development of a second Sydney airport started. The Labor Party in government had 13 years to tackle this problem. They could not sort it out internally. It is public knowledge that there are concerns from some of the members in the government about the EIS process with Holsworthy, but the decision was taken as soon as the results of the EIS were out.

The government promised to open the east-west runway if elected to government. We have done that. The government promised a more equitable distribution of the aircraft noise problem. We have done that. The government promised a review of the flight paths for Mascot airport, and we have done that. In opposition the coalition was committed to capping aircraft movements to 80 per hour and in government the coalition is implementing this promise. Eighty movements an hour equates to approximately 500,000 movements per year. This is in excess of Sydney's 353,000 movement limit which is specified in the long-term operating plan.

Under Labor, 50 per cent of the movements were over the suburbs north of the airport. These residents never got a break at all. The coalition has already cut these movements by 33 per cent. The target is to cut it further to around 17 per cent. Under the coalition, 17 per cent of aircraft movements will be to the north, 15 per cent to the west, 13 per cent to the east and 55 per cent will be to the south and over water.

What is being done here is exactly what we set out to do—that is, to create a more equitable situation not only for the movement of aircraft in and out of KSA but also for the distribution of noise. We are a government that has inherited a problem that we are dealing with. To be criticised for not dealing with it more expeditiously, I think, is a bit disingenuous of the opposition. There has been positive action to deal with the surrounding suburbs around KSA in an equitable way. We have put those measures in place.

BREAK.PARA: The slot system is the means by which the cap can be monitored. The implementation of the slot system will be beneficial to all users of the airport. It is designed to alleviate congestion in a non-discriminatory way. While the bill sets out the general framework for the slot system the detail, to be determined by the slot manager, will be contained in a disallowable instrument. The slot system will be fully operative by March 1998. The slot system is consistent with worldwide practice.

The slot management system is used at approximately 130 airports around the world. The system being implemented in Australia is based on the IATA model with some modifications that reflect the particular conditions that exist at KSA—for instance, as I alluded to earlier, protection for regional services, better access to slots for new entrants, and the introduction of compliance mechanisms. They are all important elements of what we are attempting to achieve here, and I think it should be recognised. It is important to recognise the right of those regional operators to also have access to KSA. All those commuters have an expectation and a right of quick access to the business community in Sydney and should not be penalised because of their smaller aircraft. It is an important element of this bill.

The slot system forces airlines to move away from cluster scheduling where flights are scheduled to arrive and depart and are beyond the capacity of the airport to support. Cluster scheduling can be claimed therefore, particularly at peak times, to be the root cause of the delays experienced at KSA, which is the flip side of the problems. It has been criticised over the years for the low number of hourly movements in comparison to international standards.

The 80 movements per hour is not presently being met at KSA. There will be opportunities for new entrants to obtain slots during all operational hours. This includes peak times. There is a general expectation that there will be a degree of competition for any slots available during peak periods. Potential new entrants will have equal access with their established competitors on a fifty-fifty split. KSA is one of the fairest airports around the world in this area and is consistent with a deregulated aviation industry. At most, other airport incumbents get first go at the slots available.

The bill establishes a slot manager, which is envisaged to be a company formed by Sydney airport and Australian airlines or operators using the airport, which will administer the allocation and compliance. As I have already noted, special arrangements are going to be put in place by the government for regional airlines. We are committed to providing services to regional New South Wales.

The needs of regional New South Wales will be preserved by the use of ring fencing whereby KSA regional airline services have their own slot pool. Existing regional services will be guaranteed a regional slot. These slots cannot be sold or swapped to interstate or international services. So that is locking in the opportunity for continuity of regional services in and out of KSA so they do not get elbowed out, so to speak, by the larger operators.

It would be difficult to put a cap on aircraft movements without some sort of effective compliance mechanism to ensure that it was not abused or misused in other ways. This is the crucial element of the slot management system. The aim is to promote efficient scheduling performance. There will be steep fines for non-compliance. Delays at KSA will be now more open to scrutiny as the slot system introduces a clear set of criteria for flight movements. The maximum penalties are fairly hefty—for a no‐slot movement and an off‐slot movement, the penalty is $220,000 and $110,000 respectively.

A no‐slot movement is the most serious breach, and it jeopardises the cap and disrupts other airport users who have applied for a slot. So, if you have an airline operator who just does not turn up, does not utilise the slot they have been allocated, it means that someone else has missed out, the whole schedule has been put out of whack. That is how critical the timing will be in the operation of the slot management system. To make sure these companies and airline operators are focused on what is trying to be achieved here, the compliance measures will be implemented.

The coalition is a government of action, unlike Labor, which did nothing but create anxiety and stress for the people of Sydney for those 13 years. I note that the member for Chifley (Mr Price) is in the chamber. I do not know whether he has actually spoken on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet, unfortunately.

—Not yet, but I am sure he is going to and I am sure the member for Chifley will probably be at variance with some of his colleagues with regard to the development of the airport at western Sydney. But you can rest assured that this government will deliver on alleviating the problems as far as the second airport in the Sydney basin is concerned. We will not be vacillating on this the way the Labor Party has done. In the last 18 months we have become used to listening to the opposition talk about what they were going to do if they had got another term in government. This is just another one of those areas.

BREAK.PARA: It took a long time for them to try to address the problem with the parallel runway at KSA. They went through the process of identifying Badgerys Creek. We heard the member for Watson criticise the decisions that have been made by his former government for not getting on with the job.

This government is at least going through a rigorous process of eliminating Holsworthy first, and now we will move forward with the job of developing a second airport in Sydney. We will not muck about and wait for 13 years to pander to different interests in some of our electorates, as we have seen happen around KSA. We will get on with the job so there is certainty in what is going to happen in aviation in Australia.

The implementation of the slot management system and the guarantee of 80 movements per hour will create a lot more certainty for the travelling public, inbound international tourism and the businesses that operate in and around KSA, particularly the airline operators, and will provide other competitors with the opportunity to get into that slot management system. But, just as importantly, it will also provide the opportunity for regional travellers within New South Wales to have what they perceive as their reasonable right to access to the Kingsford Smith airport in Sydney when they need to get in there and, subsequently, do their business in the city. In closing, it is good to see a majority of opposition members supporting this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little surprised at the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I was expecting a more spirited bid for a ministerial bench in that speech of his.
—He has obviously got land transport.

—Obviously, he has land transport. I have to say I have a little bit of money on him. I am not going to quit yet, but I did expect a more spirited defence. I do want to pick up one thing—that is, all opposition members support the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill. I am a little surprised that he is suggesting they do not. In fact, I think the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) are to be commended for being the instigators of this bill. I do not think that there can be any member of this House who does not have some sympathy for the plight of constituents who reside, for example, in the electorates of Grayndler, Watson or Barton.
—Or Lowe.
—Or Lowe, for that matter, in terms of the way their lives are changed by airport noise.
—Or North Sydney.
—Even North Sydney. It is extraordinary to see the lengths that this government goes to to protect the citizens of Bennelong and other electorates on the North Shore.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you may be aware, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) thought he was launching some vicious attack on me in purporting to make some great revelations to the House about statements I have made in this place in support of Badgerys Creek. For the record, I think the most nerve‐racking time for me as a new member in this place was talking to my party units who had had a history, dating back to Galston airport, of being opposed to an airport in western Sydney and my advocating that we should in fact look at having an airport in western Sydney. In 1985, in looking at the way things have developed, an airport for Badgerys Creek was, in retrospect or hindsight, a 1980s issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You went to the last election with it.

—Of course. Just let me finish. I think you will find that I have quite a bit to say. In western Sydney it is true that an overwhelming proportion of the population supported an airport at Badgerys Creek. I have some sympathy with the comments of the member for Watson, who said that it is a pity they did not get on and build it.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that the proposal started off as a general airport. The runway was extended to allow a certain class of aeroplane to use it but not all aeroplanes. Indeed, I well remember the comments by, I think, one of the state premiers at the time, who said that Badgerys Creek would only be required, looking at airport demand, in the year 2010.

I have certainly changed my position. I make no apology for that. Indeed, it is not something new to my constituents or new in the western suburbs of Sydney. But what is the reason for me wanting to change my position on Badgerys Creek?

Firstly, I think it is fair to say that the proposal for the third runway and the flawed EIS at the time not only disturbed a lot of people in the inner city but started to raise doubts in the people of the western suburbs about the efficacy of an airport at Badgerys Creek. I remember a number of meetings that Labor members from the western suburbs of Sydney had during 1995. There was complete agreement that, when we went into the next election—that is, the 1996 election—the three studies that we had promised would be completed, the flight paths would be available, there would be a high degree of community consultation and every citizen would know exactly how that airport would actually affect them. History shows of course that this was not done, and I must say that it left people like me well and truly isolated.

I have already referred to a meeting at Memorial Hall during the election period, which I was genuinely informed the member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, was invited to attend. For the record, Jackie has said that she was never invited and I accept that. But we did have the former Senator Woods come along. Do people remember Senator Woods, of travel rorts and a few other things?

What did former Senator Woods say at that meeting? He said that the coalition stood for an open, transparent and publicly accountable EIS process. More than that, as the inner city community groups had been funded by Labor, the relevant groups in western Sydney would also be funded by the coalition. Have we had an open, transparent and accountable EIS process? Of course we have not.

Other speakers have referred to the Holsworthy episode, fiasco, whatever you want to call it. I thought it was really interesting that, as part of upholding this open, transparent and accountable EIS process, we suppressed the information which would allow us to examine what led the government to abandon Holsworthy and refine down its sole solution to Badgerys Creek. Does the honourable member for North Sydney believe this is accountable, open and transparent? He really does swallow the government's propaganda lines to a degree that I did not think was possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has been part and parcel of it.

—Yes, the shadow minister is obviously correct there. He has been part and parcel of it. But let me just talk about noise. I think there was nothing more criticised in the third runway EIS than the use of Australian ANEF standards. They were totally discredited. But what standards are we using in the Badgerys Creek EIS? The very same standards. Even by the time of the last election, people in my part of western Sydney knew that 24 hours was never going to be a goer.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we have issues of air quality. It is true—and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield) will confirm this—that in western Sydney we have an extraordi narily high incidence of asthma. That affects not only people of my age but, of course, young children. What do we have in terms of fine particle pollution in the EIS? There is absolutely no mention of the US standard of 2.5 microns. That is not mentioned in the EIS at all. Why should I raise that? That is the fine particle pollution that lodges and remains in the lungs of people who come in contact with it. I hope that the new fine particle pollution standard currently being negotiated by the federal government with the states does include a 2.5 micron standard because I think, of all things, this alone probably will rule it out.

The EIS does not address ozone pollution. Is the honourable member for North Sydney not concerned about ozone? There is the issue of the remaining stands of the Cumberland Plain woodland and, of course, the 31 endangered species that are in the flight path of the proposed airport. Also in the EIS are the figures that show, under the various options, the dramatic decrease in the value of houses to people. For an airport that is alleged to traumatise cows only, it is surprising that the barn value is going to drop by as much, under one option, as $61 million.

The member for North Sydney probably does not even flinch at $61 million, given the value of houses in his electorate. But I remind him that in western Sydney these houses represent the life savings of battling families. This is the way we have traditionally saved. People's prized assets—their family homes—are going to dramatically decrease in value.

I have said all along—and I have sometimes been criticised for it—that, since the change of government, the real people who are capable of influencing the government on this issue of Badgerys Creek are not the member for Greenway, although he has always been in that fight, or me or even the member for Prospect, Mrs Crosio. The real keys to Badgerys Creek are the government members like the member for Lindsay. What is her position on Badgerys Creek? We cannot quite work it out.

Certainly, Danna Vale left us in no doubt about where she stood in relation to Holsworthy. Apparently, options A and C are not acceptable to the member for Lindsay, but she apparently has no problems with option B, although she has already conceded she may very well lose her seat over it—and I think that is right. There is Kerry Bartlett, the member for Macquarie. What is his position? My understanding is that he will go with the flow, whatever the government decides, or whatever the member for North Sydney instructs him to say. We are offering a reward for the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) on what his position is.

But I make no apology for saying that I will respond to what I see are the needs and aspirations of my constituents. That is a bare minimum position for any member. Yes, it is true, I have changed my position on Badgerys Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha! The big change!

—Of course, it is a big change. I have never denied that. But you go around as though I have kept this as some super secret from my constituents. It is also true that WESROC, representing regional organisations of councils, has come out against Badgerys Creek. Of all the councils in western Sydney that belong to WESROC—and they all belong—the only council that supports Badgerys Creek is Liverpool.
—What about Penrith?
—They are opposed to Badgerys Creek, as well as Blacktown, Parramatta, Merrylands, Campbelltown—
—Camden.
—Camden—I thank the honourable member for Greenway for reminding me of that. Time is running out on me, I regret to say.
—I suggest you ignore the member for North Sydney.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have always attempted to follow your injunctions and, in trying to accede to your injunction, I do so but I admit to a great deal of difficulty. The Liberal Party are saying that they have this EIS process. I want to remind them that they promised an open process, a transparent process and an accountable process, and they are wimping out on these issues. If they believe that they can get Badgerys Creek up in this way, I believe that they will fail.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that those who are in a position to greatly influence the outcome of the government's decision on Badgerys Creek in the western suburbs of Sydney are the members for Lindsay, Parramatta and Macquarie. I am sure that, as the campaign gets under way led by an alliance of councils in western Sydney, increasingly they will be asked to stand up for their constituents.

If I could just finish, because I have only a minute left, by repeating: it is not fair for the member for Lyne to suggest that there is some split on the issue of the bill before us. In fact, all opposition members not only support the bill but also understand what led the member for Grayndler and the member for Watson to take the initiative on this matter that has led to this legislation.

We in western Sydney regret what a lot of constituents have had to put up with in electorates surrounding Kingsford Smith airport. I say with great respect that no member really is entitled to say to us in western Sydney, `Well, you know, you've got to put up with noise pollution. You've got to put up with pollution.' We are not going to cop it. Prevailing attitudes to airports have changed. Whilst I believe it is an urgent necessity to seek relief from Kingsford Smith airport, I am not convinced that Badgerys Creek is a solution in the 1990s and beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly pleased to support the principles embodied in this Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 , given that it arose from a private member's bill moved by me in this House and seconded by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). All I can say is that it is about time. It is about time that this government started to make some genuine decisions and progress about Kingsford Smith airport and what it will do about the hundreds of thousands of residents that are affected by its ever increasing noise.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government characterised by prevarication, delay and an avoidance of making the tough decisions. The delay in this bill is symptomatic of the lack of leadership from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that we have seen on a range of issues. Ever since the coalition came to government, it has been delaying action on the Sydney airport problem. Despite Holsworthy being a clearly unsuitable site—coming second last in the last EIS process—the government set up a process so as to delay the decision about the second Sydney airport for yet another year.

Despite clear election promises to introduce a cap of 80 movements an hour, the government did not raise the issue until this month, 18 months into office. It took a private member's bill from the opposition to put this issue on the agenda. For a whole year, the government has tried to avoid having a debate on my private member's bill before this House. Its delaying tactics take a toll not only on the credibility of this government but in more real ways on the people who have to live under Sydney airport's flight path. These people have been kept waiting over this period by this government's indecision.

I first made the demand for a cap in my private member's bill, the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill 1996, which was introduced and had its first reading on 4 November 1996. The second reading was on 18 November. After the government failed to respond to this challenge and decided to delay the decision, I made repeated calls for the cap, including in the grievance debate on 10 February 1997 and in a speech concerning the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 on 18 March 1997. On 19 June 1997, the member for Watson and I tried to suspend standing orders to bring on the debate regarding the Sydney Airport (Regulation of Movements) Bill. I raised the issue again in the debate on the Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 on 26 June 1997.

Why were we so concerned about pursuing this? Because Kingsford Smith airport accounts for 49 per cent of all passenger traffic in Australia, and this level of passenger traffic is on the increase. In 1965‐66, 2.6 million passengers passed through this airport; in 1995‐96, 20.3 million passengers passed through the same airport. This figure is expected to double by the year 2009, with an estimated 40.4 million passengers expected to pass through Sydney.

Currently, residents who live around Kingsford Smith airport experience up to 753 aircraft movements per day. By 1999‐2000, they will have to experience an average of 866 aircraft movements per day. Added to this, as we all know, Sydney airport—and my electorate—is surrounded by the most densely populated urban area of Australia. A recent Airservices Australia report stated that the number of people living in the 20 ANEF contour range has increased from 68,380 to 116,860. That is over 100,000 people per day putting up with a substantial level of aircraft noise. By and large they are not the people on the far North Shore of Sydney, I might remind my Labor colleagues; by and large they are working people in inner city electorates who have voted Labor their whole lives. That is why we need a solution to this issue.

No doubt aircraft noise will continue to increase until a second Sydney airport in the Sydney basin—which is the only place it can be—is built. Kingsford Smith airport, of course, is continuing to expand. This government's decision to delay the building of the second international airport has also been taken in a period when they have supported the expansion of international facilities at Kingsford Smith airport. Ironically, the decision to expand KSA has been the only decision the government has made with regard to the airport issue that has not involved delaying tactics.

On 19 June 1997, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works announced that the international terminal at KSA should be upgraded at a cost of $350 million. On 29 August 1997, Senator Robert Hill, Minister for the Environment, concluded that an EIS for the expansion of the international terminal at Kingsford Smith airport was not required. So I say to my colleagues on both sides of the House: let us not have any of this nonsense about people being concerned about people around the inner city and not being concerned with Sydney West; we are getting an expansion of facilities and an expansion of flights without an EIS. Interestingly, however, the Public Works Committee noted in their final recommendation that:
Any further development of Sydney airport should have appropriate environmental clearances before being referred to the committee.

In that, the Public Works Committee is clearly stating its dissatisfaction with the government's crash‐through approach on this issue. The committee was clearly concerned about subjecting the residents around Sydney airport to increased noise and pollution, even if John Sharp and Senator Hill were not.

The committee also noted that, because no decision had yet been made on the location of a second Sydney airport, the expansion of KSA had to occur. Why has a decision not been made about the second Sydney airport, despite the commitment of the government, prior to the election, to build a second Sydney airport, despite the fact that there was an obvious growing need for a second Sydney airport and despite the fact that the previous Labor government had already allocated $306 million for airport development at Badgerys Creek, $21 million for a control tower and firefighting services, $23 million for environmental safeguards, $480 million for roads, $17 million for a rail corridor and had already spent $152 million on land acquisitions around Badgerys Creek?

Despite all this, what we had was a delay in the EIS process because of the Holsworthy fiasco. That delay has meant an expansion at Sydney airport. We all know that Holsworthy was never seriously a contender. It had already been considered and knocked over. However, the government proceeded with the sham and told us all it considered Holsworthy a potential site. The government was becoming famous for its delaying tactics when, in the budget of 20 August 1996, it allocated $21 million for the EIS for the Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy second airport options.

When the draft EIS was released, of course we all knew that Holsworthy had been excluded, but at a cost of delay to the second Sydney airport, at a cost of an ever increasing expansion at Sydney airport and at a cost of millions of dollars to the taxpayer. We are now back at the point at which we were in March 1996. All this has achieved is the alienation of thousands of people in south‐western Sydney around Holsworthy airport. How can we trust this government's commitments to solving the problem at Kingsford Smith airport when the only real, concrete action we see is the expansion of facilities at Kingsford Smith airport?

The other issues which have come before the Sydney Airport Community Forum—chaired by the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey)—unfortunately have also been ignored by this government. We have seen the movement of the threshold on the third runway where a clear decision by the Sydney Airport Community Forum was knocked over by the previous Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp).

We have seen the long‐term operating plan proceed. I do not argue that everything in the long‐term operating plan is bad, because clearly it is not. Clearly, aircraft noise has been an ever increasing problem over decades at Sydney airport, and clearly no government, Labor or conservative, can say it has a proud record on these issues, because I do not believe any of them have.

Let me say that the main problem I see with the long‐term operating plan is the number of take-offs to the north, which it clearly favours, rather than take-offs to the south. They are clearly favoured for one reason and one reason only: if a plane takes off to the north, it can veer to the west all over the western parts of my electorate, the Ashfield municipality, and all over the electorate of Lowe whereas if it lands from the north it has to fly over the electorate of Bennelong. It seems to me that the priority of this government has been to protect the residents of the North Shore of Sydney at the expense of the residents to the immediate north of the airport.

There have been a number of other issues brought up by the Sydney Airport Community Forum which are yet to be addressed. There is the issue of those people closest to the airport. I say to the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who spoke last night about the terrible noise that people in Turramurra suffer, that those same planes are a hell of a lot lower when they are over Sydenham than when they are over Turramurra. And hearing is not related to income. People who cannot afford to live at Turramurra—they would probably like to but have to live in weatherboard houses in Sydenham—do not have different hearing from the people in Turramurra. They are the same planes; they are just 10 times noisier when they are over the residents of Sydenham and St Peters.

The member for North Sydney and others to their credit have visited Sydenham and shown a genuine sympathy for the residents around the Sydenham‐St Peters area. I congratulate the member for North Sydney and thank him for his efforts on behalf of those residents which I believe have been very genuine. But the fact is that the residents of Sydenham are still waiting for two major questions to be answered. They are waiting to hear about the issue of those people who are living in weatherboard houses which cannot be insulated. They live in weatherboard houses because they are living in the suburb with probably the lowest income in Sydney. The average income is certainly a lot lower than the electorates of Prospect or Greenway. They have the cheapest houses in Sydenham.

I can assure honourable members that in the inner west housing boom that is going on prices are not increasing in Sydenham and St Peters. What is happening is that the houses cannot be insulated and they are just being left as a result of the government's failure to make a decision. The government should make a decision regarding those residences. We have a buy‐out program that has been approved unanimously by the Sydney Airport Community Forum and those residents deserve certainty.

We have heard a lot over the last couple of days about the government's commitment to small business. But I say to Peter Reith or anyone else in the government, `Go down to Sydenham, just as Lindsay Tanner, the shadow minister, has done twice since the election and have a look at the boarded up shops there.' If you acquire a whole suburb of 151 houses, you knock them over literally—demolish the houses—and you are left with a park, it is not surprising that the newsagent, the chemist and the local stores all close; and those people deserve compensation. Yes, the Labor Party acquired those houses and, yes, that was a great program, because you cannot leave people living in an over‐40 ANEF noise zone.

The former minister showed his ignorance of the issue. Perhaps he should have come down to Sydenham. I invite the member for Lowe, Paul Zammit, to come down. I am sure that I can organise one week living in Sydenham in one of these houses free of charge for any MP or adviser on the other side of the House. I will even give them TA—which the government is concerned about—out of my own pocket to live there for a week and argue that those houses should not have been demolished and that people should not have been given compensation and allowed to live in first world conditions.

Last night I was amazed that the member for Bradfield praised the former transport minister for the personal time and effort he had put in in visiting the people of Pymble. The member for Bradfield said:

Despite his extremely busy schedule—and, despite. . . the very secure margin of Bradfield in . . . returning a Liberal member—he was even prepared to see individual members of my electorate who were concerned and on the verge of psychological despair over airport noise.

Dear, dear! The people from Turramurra suffering from psychological despair. In 18 months the former minister did not come to Sydenham, my electorate or to the area which is most affected. The shadow transport minister, two visits; government, zero. I ask whoever the incoming transport minister is to come to my electorate, sit down and talk to the people there and experience what the noise is.

I say to people on my own side of the House, to Labor members, or any other MP who supported the third runway, `Come and stand in Yelverton Street, Sydenham and tell me it was a good decision.' And none of them have. All the economic rationalists from whatever side of politics cannot defend the decision to build the third runway.

I want to conclude by talking about Sydney West airport and the need for it to be built. I want to quote the report of the New South Wales Labor government's Standing Committee on Public Works, chaired by Paul Crittenden. It is a great report, entitled Report on State Infrastructure Requirements for Sydney West Airport. In the executive summary it says:

SWA offers Western Sydney the opportunity to secure a commercially viable international airport with an associated commercial/industrial complex that will complement and reinforce other economic development catalysts planned for the region. These projects represent a strategic infrastructure network that will significantly enhance the region's competitive base, create jobs and provide opportunities for residential development in the SWA Sub-Region.

This report outlines the measures needed to ensure that the environmental impact on residents of Sydney West are minimised. No‐one who lives in or represents the area, no‐one who has experienced the trauma of Sydney airport, is about repeating the exercise or transferring the problem to Sydney West airport. It is important that there is a proper EIS and that the problems are not repeated. I support the residents of Sydney's western suburbs in seeking to ensure that the chaos around Sydney airport is not repeated.

We do need to get a bit fair dinkum about this debate and to point out that the members around Sydney airport are not saying, `No aircraft noise.' That is the lunatics in the No Aircraft Noise Party. We are not saying, `Shut Sydney airport.' I have never said that. It would be opportunistic and I would be probably get a bigger swing if I did say that. But I am not saying that, because it is unrealistic—just as it is unrealistic to argue that Sydney does not need a second airport.

In my view, it is worse than unrealistic to argue for airports at places like Goulburn and Williamstown, because that means an expanded Kingsford Smith airport. There is only one option, and it is now Badgerys Creek airport, as we have argued since the election. To give one figure from the draft EIS, the maximum number of people who will be living in the 20 ANEC range around Badgerys Creek is 3,000. There are over 120,000 people around Sydney airport. Compare apples with apples and not apples with oranges. What we need to do in terms of Sydney West airport is ensure that the mistakes are not repeated.

I conclude by saying that the member for Bradfield suggested, in quoting me out of context from an article, that I had said: `Only a Labor or a Liberal government could fix the problem.' I did say that during the election campaign, because I do not believe that the No Aircraft Noise Party or independents can solve anything. I am a big political party person, and I believe that only governments, not individuals, provide real solutions. He quoted me out of context, but he did not mention who wrote the article. It was Chris Falvey—John Sharp's adviser. So he has quoted it as an independent source. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It was a fascinating evening last night and has been an even more fascinating morning. Those people listening in the gallery today would wonder whether indeed the ALP supported this Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill 1997 . I can tell them that in actual fact they do, which may well surprise them, given the nature of the debate. Indeed, the shadow minister for transport, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), said that it was a good bill. I congratulate him on that, but I will not be congratulating him on much else that was said during the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The one thing that needs to be remembered in this debate is that we went to the last election with a policy of a cap of 80 movements per hour and, as with every election promise that we have made in relation to Sydney airport, we have kept to it. We have developed an agreed means with industry about how to give effect to that cap of 80 movements per hour. With the greatest respect to the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), who was playing catch‐up politics with his private member's bill, I suspect that it might actually have been a bit of a preselection ploy—that is what we reckon on this side of the House—that he needed to be seen to be doing something.

BREAK.PARA: But all his bill did was meet half of our election commitment. What he did not do was have the mechanism for the implementation. So he had a bit of paper, which was our election policy, and he said, `Right. I've got that through. I'll put it on the table and I'll walk away.' Where was the mechanism? Nowhere at all. He avoided the hard issue: the mechanism for the implementation. It was catch‐up politics. He took our election campaign policy but did not have the means or the wherewithal to put in place the mechanism for the implementation. At the end of the day, that meant that it was a first come first serve basis, which was going to be absolutely inappropriate and disastrous for the Sydney airport.

The point to remember about our long‐term operating plan for Sydney is that it meets our commitment to maximise flights over water and non‐residential land and to more equitably share the noise generated by the airport. It is a fair policy that has been implemented by this government. Indeed, the assertion that there would be no flights over Bennelong was just a bit more cheapjack politics from those on the other side. The member for Grayndler knows that it is not true. It was absolutely untrue, a bit of a gee‐up to keep the pot boiling but with no basis at all. Indeed, this plan is about sharing aircraft noise and about getting away from the funnelling across specific residential areas that was done by the previous government.

The targets for the plan should be known by those opposite. They made no reference to it. They wanted to avoid the issue. They did not want to make the acknowledgments. The targets for the plan are 55 per cent of movements to the south—basically Botany Bay—17 per cent to the north, 15 per cent to the west and 13 per cent to the east. It is sharing the noise. But what did the Labor Party have? They had over 50 per cent of movements over suburbs north of the airport. As the member for Grayndler knows acutely, the residents north of the airport never got a break under the Labor Party. We have already cut it to 33 per cent and, as he well knows, our target is to cut it to 17 per cent.

The utter hypocrisy of the Labor Party, both before this debate and during it, is absolutely mind blowing. They went to the last election, as the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) and the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) know, with not one commitment to a cap.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't here then.

—Oh! In AFL terms, that is the big free kick, the big handball: `I wasn't here.' You poor little dear! What did you do about it before you got here? You let the residents of Sydenham boil and stew in aircraft noise. What have you done since you got here? You have done even less for the residents of Sydenham since you got here. What Labor promised at the last election was more of the same—nonstop jets on parallel runways such that the suburb of Sydenham was needlessly demolished at a cost of $30 million.

BREAK.PARA: Let us forget the cost. Let us talk about the people of Sydenham. Let us talk about the mums and the dads and the kids of Sydenham who, because of the ALP, went through sheer hell. What are we going to do? We have cut that from over 50 per cent, and our target is to cut it down to around 17 per cent. That is good for the people of Sydenham, who have been through sheer hell.

I want to talk briefly about Badgerys Creek. This government is fully committed to building a second major airport for Sydney to a full international standard as a matter of priority, subject to an appropriate EIS process. The EIS process will be very different from Laurie's EIS process. We all remember that, don't we? What a deceptive little number that EIS process was from the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). We are doing it. It will be transparent. It will result in the right decision. We are absolutely firmly committed to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's `Lauriegate'.

—`Lauriegate' indeed. I want to turn to a couple of matters raised by the member for Melbourne. I will give him his due and say that he was very quick in the first minute of his speech on this matter to say that the Labor Party supported the bill.
—It's our bill.

—Oh! We have the poor little possum back again with some more comments about it. You weren't there, and then you were there, and then you weren't there. You are all over the place, Anthony. You know that you are all over the place. You are not a bad bloke on a personal level, but you are all over the place with this. You do not know whether you are coming or going.

BREAK.PARA: It is just extraordinary. We had the member for Melbourne pleading the case for the people of Sydenham: `I have been there, and I have heard it, and I have seen it.' Do you know who caused it? The Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party destroyed Sydenham, and here we have the shadow minister crying crocodile tears for the people of Sydenham. He went on to criticise the long-term operating plan, which is providing relief for the very people that he was talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —They started pulling their houses down.

—Indeed. They were the ones that put $30 million in to pull people's houses down. They did absolutely nothing about it. I have a question for the member for Melbourne. What is fair about destroying the suburb of Sydenham? What is fair about that?
—Madam Deputy Speaker, on a point of order—
—Frivolous, I can tell. Look at the smile on his face.
—I hope it is not a frivolous point of order.
—Of course it will not be, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—I will judge that.
—As the parliamentary secretary knows full well, what is fair about leaving people in noise affected areas? That is what this government would suggest.
—Order! Resume your seat.

—What is fair about making one group of residents the virtual sole receivers of airport noise? There is nothing fair about that at all. I think the comment from the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), in this House on 29 May probably sums up what this is all about. He said:

BREAK.PARA: The real winners in this are people directly to the north of the airport—people in the Labor stronghold suburbs of Sydenham, Marrickville, Stanmore, Petersham, St Peters, Leichhardt and Drummoyne, who were unfairly treated by Labor in government and who are being treated fairly by the coalition in government.

That summed it up lock, stock and barrel. I would like to give enormous credit to the member for North Sydney, the member for Lowe, the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). I would like to thank them on behalf of their constituents and the people of Sydney for doing the right thing with a terrible problem. They have done it and they have delivered.
I would now like to turn to the member for Barton (Mr McClelland). I really felt desperately sorry for the member for Barton. He said that he basically agreed. In fact, his words were:
There is not a lot that the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) has said with which I disagree.
When that is the Labor Party and this is the government, that is code for: `I agree with every single thing that you said.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It's our bill.

—I am going to talk about Backflip Bob soon, so you ought to hang around and listen to that. Basically, the member for Barton said that everything the member for North Sydney said was right. So that means it is a fair plan. Labor is hypocritical. It is hypocritical on Badgerys Creek. Indeed, as raised by the member for North Sydney, Backflip Bob does not know whether he is coming or going. We thank the member for Barton for supporting your comments in relation to that—very generous. He said:

BREAK.PARA: The position of the Australian Labor Party is to support the construction of a second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek.
I will continue the quote—it is not my quote—from the member for Barton:
As the actress said to the bishop, `Just do it.'
That brings me to the next point. We all know that Bishop Bob Carr has gone off the boil. The impotent Bishop Bob is either unwilling or unable to `just do it'.

We then had the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). It is a shame that Hansard cannot record my facial expression. But, for the benefit of Hansard, there is a look of horror on my face in relation to the member for Prospect. This is the very person who stood up here last night and attacked the Badgerys Creek proposal. But she was quite happy to be part of a Labor government which promised to fast track an international 24-hour airport on the same site—the one and the same. It is amazing what happens when you go from here on the government benches to there on the opposition benches. We had the same thing from the member for Chifley (Mr Price)—Hopalong Cassidy. He hopped from the government across to the opposition and totally changed every single thing he had said about Badgerys Creek in the space of about 35 seconds. After 13 years he changed in 35 seconds. Over he went. He completely changed what he said. As I said before, we are going to have a transparent EIS process. Those members should know that.

I have already spoken about the member for Grayndler. I am not going to talk any more about that because I want to turn to the New South Wales Labor Party, the New South Wales ALP government—the great hypocrites in the debate about Badgerys Creek. The member for North Sydney mentioned some of this last night, but I will take the opportunity to do so as well. On 28 November 1994:
State Labor has a strategy to build Badgerys Creek airport by the end of 1997.
On 10 May 1995:
Fast tracking Sydney west airport will create thousands of new construction and service industry jobs in Sydney's west.

Thousands of jobs in Sydney's west, yet the state ALP wants to destroy jobs, destroy the economy, destroy tourism, destroy exports. You name it, they want to destroy it. Backflip Bob. The Daily Telegraph of 21 May:
Mr Carr said that Badgerys Creek was the best site for a second airport and the government needed to set the plan in motion immediately.
I will quote the member for Kingsford‐Smith too—this is fairly interesting:

The major beneficiaries of these developments are the people of western Sydney. There will be a significant direct and indirect employment opportunity available in western Sydney and Macarthur region flowing out of these works. The establishment of a major airport is also likely to attract other industries to the region, again with consequent employment opportunities for western Sydney.

But who has been driving the anti‐Badgerys Creek process? Minister Knowles and a few of the ones that are sort of weaseling around over on the other side there, giving Knowles a bit of a push along: `Go on, mate. Go on, you do it. We can't say much about it because we're fully compromised on this, but you go and do it.'

Within minutes of the Holsworthy decision being made, the New South Wales planning minister, Craig Knowles, said that the New South Wales state ALP government would at all costs be opposing Badgerys Creek. Who is going to pay for that? Not Backflip Bob. You know who is going to pay for it as well as I do. The New South Wales taxpayers are going to pay for this. They are going to pay dearly for it if you continue to oppose it. Of course, all this happened when Backflip Bob was overseas. Knowles came out and said, `We're going to put our full resources into opposing Badgerys Creek.'

Premier Carr has got to make it quite clear, once and for all, whether he does or does not support Badgerys Creek. Roger, you know that as well as I do. He either puts Knowles down or he supports him. If he is going to support him, he had better come clean and tell the people of New South Wales. And he ought to tell you guys as well. At the moment your strict policy is Badgerys Creek—you know it as well as I do—but Backflip Bob and Knowles are trying to squeeze it.

Let us have a look at what this means. Let us cut to the quick on this and look at what it means. It means quite simply that, if you do not proceed with the second airport, Bob Carr needs to explain to all those voters in Labor's inner city heartland that this is code for lifting the curfew, lifting the cap of 80 movements per hour, building a fourth runway and squeezing more than 60 million passengers into Sydney airport—three times more than there are now. To quote the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), `Bigger, noisier, nastier.'

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 September, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Gareth Evans moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1) native title rights, including on pastoral leases, are fundamental legal property rights, acknowledged and upheld as such by the High Court, and entitled to the same respect and protection as the property rights of non‐Indigenous Australians: any amendment of the Native Title Act in response to the Wik decision or for any other reason must fully reflect that reality;

(2) it is in the national interest that the Act balance and reconcile to the maximum possible extent the interests and reasonable expectations of both Indigenous Australians and other major stakeholders—farmers, miners and Australian taxpayers generally;

(3) it is both in the national interest, and in the interests of Indigenous Australians, farmers and miners, that there be the maximum possible predictability and certainty about the status of the Act and its practical operation;
(4) there is a need, in particular, to guarantee the constitutional validity of the legislation, by ensuring that legislation operates for the net benefit of Indigenous Australians;

(5) it is also in everyone's interest that the processes established by this legislation to deal with the registration and determination of claims, and the reconciliation of competing interests, be as effective and expeditious as possible;

(6) there are aspects of the Bill which may advance these objectives, in particular by encouraging and assisting the entering into of agreements, and by setting a stricter regime for the registration of claims;
(7) nonetheless, the Bill is seriously deficient, and requires substantial amendment, in many respects, including:
(i) the reach of the validation provisions beyond that which is necessary for the practical redress of post‐Wik problems;
(ii) the manifestly unacceptable over‐reach of the provisions purporting to confirm the extinguishment of native title where exclusive tenure has previously been involved;
(iii) the unnecessarily broad application, in relation to coexistence on pastoral leases, of the statutory authorisation of non‐pastoral activities;
(iv) the unnecessarily broad application of extinguishment in relation to the provision of government services and public works;
(v) the indefensibly limited test for allowing statutory access rights for registered claimants;

(vi) the dramatic limitation of the right to negotiate, and in particular its effective elimination in relation to mining on pastoral leases, which (along with the provisions amounting to direct or de facto extinguishment) significantly tilts the balance of the legislation against Indigenous Australians;
(vii) the unacceptable limitation on the effective enjoyment of the right to negotiate which is involved in powers of early ministerial intervention;

(viii) the absurd and counterproductive sunset clause, which will simply ensure a proliferation of ambit claims under the Act, and the pursuit of future claims through expensive and complex common law processes;
(ix) the inappropriately rigid and legalistic constraints on Registrars in the management of claims; and
(x) the inappropriate introduction of formal rules of evidence, and limitations on the extent to which cultural and customary concerns can be taken into account, in the Federal Court claims process".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish today to associate myself with the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in this debate and to support the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans). I will be more general and briefer in my remarks than usual, given the lengthy list of speakers on our side and our undertaking to the government and publicly to ensure that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 goes from the House to the Senate by the end of October.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope to participate in the consideration in detail stage of the debate, which will occur after the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund reports on 27 October, by which time this House and the members of it will have had the chance to contemplate the submissions made to that committee, the evidence received and the committee's report.

At the heart of our attitude to the bill before the House today is the desire to make native title processes more certain, to make the act more workable, to make sure that the act is fair, and to make sure that the act is predictable. They are the hallmarks that the Leader of the Opposition has set down for our consideration of this bill. We want to see a native title process which is more certain, fair and workable.

In my own case, I take part in this debate as a member of the parliament when the Native Title Act 1993 was passed by this House; as a Western Australian whose state, in practical terms, is the state most affected by the provisions of the Native Title Act; and as the shadow minister for resources and energy.

The starting point for this debate is the Mabo No. 2 decision of the High Court of June 1992. The essential element of that decision by the High Court was that native title was recognised as a common law property right—a legal property right. That raised fundamental property and constitutional questions for the parliament to respond to. The subsequent High Court decision in the Wik case, which made the point that native title is not extinguished by pastoral leases, has seen this set of amendments come to the House. The key starting point is native title being recognised by the High Court as a fundamental property right.

One of the difficulties that the then government and this parliament faced in 1993 was that this recognition came a couple of hundred years too late. In comparable jurisdictions such as the United States of America, Canada and New Zealand, the notion of a native title property right had been recognised much earlier. What this parliament and the previous government had to do was to grapple with the insertion of a legal property right into our property law framework 200 years after the event, and try to grapple with that in a much more compressed timetable.

The High Court also made the point in the Mabo case that, whilst it was open for native title to be extinguished by valid government activity with an intention to so extinguish, there was no right of compensation at common law. However, any extinguishment had to be consistent with the Racial Discrimi nation Act. That was a view that the High Court took by a majority of six to one.

It is interesting to make the point that it was only by a four to three majority that the High Court in Mabo No. 2 said that compensation was not payable for any extinguishment of native title from inception. In other words, the High Court was one vote away from saying that native title, however so extinguished from the first moment of European settlement in this place, was compensatable. That is an important point which I will come to subsequently.

So what the parliament had to do then and what the parliament has to do now is to work through a fundamental property right. There is one of two ways that the parliament or a government can go: either you can say, `Let us leave it to the courts,' or you can say, `Let us try to find some statutory process to manage this fundamental property right.' That was the attitude that the previous government took and that saw the enactment of the Native Title Act of 1993 through this parliament.

If this parliament wants to legislate, this parliament can legislate only if it finds a valid head of power. In this area, given that until the decision of the High Court in Mabo No. 2 property rights had effectively been managed by state and territory jurisdictions, you need to find a Commonwealth head of power. There are only two Commonwealth heads of power that this parliament can resort to in this matter: the external affairs power and the race power as a consequence of the referendum change in 1967.

So what are the limitations that the parliament then and the parliament now finds upon itself? It is dealing with a fundamental property right. It has got limited Commonwealth power and, therefore, constitutional limitations and implications. And, in a practical sense, it has to find a statutory regime which is attractive enough to the parties concerned to use it, because it remains open to any party to go to the courts to pursue a common law claim for native title.

So, in addition to grappling with constitutional problems and in addition to grappling with a fundamental property right, you have to make the process attractive enough so that people want to use it. It is also desirable to ensure that whatever process you establish encourages agreement rather than litigation. So they are some of the legal hurdles and some of the practical hurdles which this parliament now finds before it.

The Native Title Act of 1993 has seen some good outcomes and some bad outcomes. I think the best outcome is the Yandicoogina agreement entered into between Hamersley Iron, a company operating in the north-west of Western Australia, and three local Aboriginal tribal groups who formed a corporation, the Gumala Aboriginal Corporation, to represent them. The end result of the agreement between Hamersley Iron and the Aboriginal communities represented by that corporation sees a $705 million iron ore development go ahead, a maximum $60 million royalty stream to that Aboriginal community and, most importantly, commitments to ensure that the investment which goes to that Aboriginal community is an investment by way of jobs, by way of training, by way of community infrastructure and by way of improvements in education.

I think that is the best example of a regional agreement that we have. On the other hand, you have the worst aspect of the Native Title Act of 1993, which has seen only one out of 600 claims proceed through the tribunal. In reference to a visit that I and the Leader of the Opposition made recently to Kalgoorlie, the Leader of the Opposition made the point in his speech that Kalgoorlie is perhaps the worst example where we see multiple claims, overlapping claims and an uncertain process.

So on the one hand we see a good utilisation of regional agreements and on the other hand we see the need to massively improve processes. How do we fix this process? How do we on the one hand continue to encourage regional agreements with those organisations that have the resources to do it and on the other hand fix the processes? This gets to the heart or the fundamentals of the bill that the government has placed before the House.

The great difficulty for this House and for the parliament is that the government's bill does not make it better; the government's bill makes it worse. The government's bill has serious constitutional question marks attached to it, will raise serious questions of just compensation and will encourage common law claims and the pursuit of claims before federal courts, state supreme courts and the High Court rather than discourage them. So the solution which the government has put before the parliament will make it worse rather than make it better.

I alluded earlier to the compensation point and I said that the High Court in Mabo No. 2 was one vote away from saying that native title, however so extinguished, from inception was compensatable. If you have a look at what the High Court has recently said on compensation for property law entitlements, and a case that it has currently before it, it is clear that the High Court is in a mood to view very seriously the extinguishment of property law entitlements and to apply a very rigorous test so far as compensation is concerned.

The most recent example we have seen coming out of the High Court was the compensation decision in respect of Coronation Hill.
