The High Court currently has before it a case dealing with Western Mining Corporation and the expropriation by the Commonwealth of petroleum exploration permits in the Timor Gap, expropriated by the Commonwealth to help enable the Australia-Indonesia zone of cooperation to go ahead in the Timor Sea. It will be interesting to see how that case is handled by the High Court, but there is now the question that the High Court these days is treating very seriously the notion of just compensation for the expropriation of property law entitlements.

The view which has been expressed by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and is reflected by the amendment which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has placed before the House outlines our view of the very serious constitutional and legal difficulties attached to this bill. Our view has been sustained in recent days by the public release of a legal opinion prepared by the Australian Law Reform Commission. As the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) last night described it on the ABC, the Australian Law Reform Commission is an `independent, impartial and objective body'.

BREAK.PARA: What has the Australian Law Reform Commission had to say about the government's native title bill? It is not as if the government has been rushing off its feet to make this public, but on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday there is a reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission's opinion on the government's native title bill. The Sydney Morning Herald reports as follows:

The submission, obtained by the Herald , said the Wik plan to effectively extinguish native title on pastoral leases is unconstitutional and "will yield more, not less, litigation and compound uncertainty and lack of confidence in Australian real property law".
Most damaging for the government, it says the compensation payable would cripple taxpayers and hinder rather than promote mining development.
It goes on to quote the opinion of the Law Reform Commission:
The compensation implications of the bill are potentially so substantial that the Government ought to think very carefully before making such a large‐scale commitment of taxpayers' funds . . .
You do not need to go much further than paragraphs 1.7 and 4.10 of the Australian Law Reform Commission's comments on the Native Title Amendment Bill. At paragraph 1.7 the commission says:

. . . the mechanism by which legal certainty for non‐exclusive leaseholders is to be achieved will almost certainly fail on the grounds that it will yield more, not less, litigation and compound uncertainty and lack of confidence in Australian real property law.
At paragraph 4.10 the commission, in respect of the compensation point, goes on to say:

The Commission considers that the compensation implications of the Bill are potentially so substantial that the Government ought to think very carefully before making such a large scale commitment of taxpayers funds to the extinguishment of the property and cultural rights of indigenous Australians.
The view reflected by the opposition's amendment is buttressed and supported by the Australian Law Reform Commission's opinion and view.

The other day, in the course of debate, the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) referred to an article that I had written for the Australian Gas Association's quarterly journal where I made the point—quite openly—that on our side we regarded the Native Title Act 1993 as not producing a perfect result. The member for Cowan referred to this as if this were somehow a stinging point. I would like to draw his and the House's attention to a speech I gave to the Australian Petroleum Producers and Exploration Association in April of this year, shortly after I became shadow minister for resources, where under the heading of `Native Title' I said:
The opposition will work in the national interest to seek an acceptable outcome to native title. Kim Beazley has made that clear both publicly and privately.

The Native Title Act of 1993 is not perfect. However, when you are breaking new legislative ground, as we did with native title, that will almost always be the case. As well, Federal Court and subsequent Tribunal decisions since have not helped the process or the procedures.

Our proposed 1995 amendments reflected our own recognition that the Act was not perfect and that the procedures and processes needed to be improved and made more workable. These were not dealt with before the dissolution of Parliament and the election.

One of the reasons the Act is not perfect is that the Senate amendments to the original Bill are imperfect. As Kim Beazley has said, we don't have a dog in the manger attitude to this issue, unlike the then Coalition Opposition, who in 1993 walked away in the Senate, leaving the Bill to the Greens (WA) and Democrats.
There is a clear national interest in an amendment Bill in the main being supported by both major political parties. That was the case in 1993, and it is the case now.
If, however, you go down the extinguishment path, you will end up in the High Court forever, tying up development forever.
There is in my view a better way through—we need a better, more workable process which will provide certainty and validity and which is fair to all the stakeholders.

Those comments are reflected in the contributions made by the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. On our side we are committed to making sure the procedures under this act are clear, efficient and timely, but they will not be achieved in the form of the bill that the government has presented to the House.
I will conclude my remarks by quoting briefly from the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition on 21 September when he opened the debate for the opposition. He had this to say:

The Wik case is a common law claim. It has been in the courts since June 1993. It is still there, with matters of substance related to it yet to be determined. That is four years down the track. Think of the 600 or so claims currently registered with the tribunal. The collapse, in the face of High Court challenge, of a badly amended act . . . by an unthinking government, would see all those cases, and more, clogging up our courts indefinitely. The pastoral industry might survive such a scenario but not the mining industry.

The bill that the government has put before the House will not make matters better but make matters worse. It is a recipe for uncertainty, it is a recipe for multiple claims before the High Court and it is a recipe for massively clogging up the system altogether. The government should pay heed to the second reading amendment which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has placed before the House and should ensure that these matters are uppermost in its mind when it comes to, I hope, a proper, full, objective and fair consideration of these matters in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with a great deal of interest to what the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) had to say on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , but I can only take into consideration all that has been said before in regard to native title amendment and the bill that is before us. I would say to the honourable member for Perth: you as part of the team got it very wrong in 1993 when the Prime Minister of the day clearly enunciated in his second reading speech that pastoral leases extinguished native title. You all voted on it.
—And you are going to make it worse, mate.

—I am not making it worse. I am just saying that you were wrong then and you are wrong now. You will not let, and you will not give, the 10‐point plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), which is now being translated into legislation, an opportunity to work.

BREAK.PARA: It does give me a great deal of pleasure to rise this afternoon to discuss this very important piece of reforming legislation. The amendments will fix the diabolical mess left by the Labor Party in relation to the state of the land tenure system in this country. We all know that in 1992 the High Court ruled in the landmark Mabo case that indigenous Australians' native title to land has always existed under common law. The High Court declared that native title held by indigenous people may survive, regardless of new laws enacted by a colonising government. Of course, the Mabo case specifically related to the Murray Islands. However, the court noted that common law is the same across Australia and, therefore, native title may still exist on the mainland as well.

This judgment by the High Court threw all existing land tenure systems in Australia into total disarray. Confusion reigned as to the status of leases held by pastoralists, miners and indigenous people, and there was concern about the ruling's impact on future development and access. The High Court's Mabo ruling dictated that the parliament issue an urgent and comprehensive legislative response in order to restore certainty. The Labor government acted when it introduced the Native Title Act in 1993, the most ill-conceived piece of legislation I think Australia has ever seen.

In 1993 the coalition consistently declared the legislation unworkable and incomplete. I stand here today speaking on these amendments as proof that the opinion has sadly been proved correct. Four years and 600 native title claims later there has been only one determination of native title on mainland Australia. Meanwhile, thousands of honest hardworking Australians have had their lives turned upside down by claims over their family farms and property.

Companies wanting to develop land which would benefit this country's economy have had projects halted indefinitely by native title claims. Major developments in the Northern Territory worth hundreds of millions of dollars have had native title claims slapped on them and so cannot proceed. The Native Title Act was in urgent need of reform even before the coalition came to government. Once elected, the Prime Minister made it one of his priorities to fix this mess and appointed his parliamentary secretary, Senator Nick Minchin, to undertake a review of the act with a view to restoring certainty for both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

The government started work on the amendments to the act immediately and waited with interest to see how the result of the Wik decision would affect the government's position. In December last year the High Court complicated matters further with the Wik ruling, which determined that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguish native title.

The government is determined to react responsibly to the challenges this ruling presents. The bill before the House today will reduce the uncertainties regarding land tenure, simplify the whole process in determining the existence of native title, improve the workability of the act, and increase the community's understanding of native title issues and processes. This bill is a result of the Prime Minister's and Senator Minchin's extensive consultation process. They have worked tirelessly to ensure that all interested parties have been consulted on the amendments proposed.

At this point I would like to acknowledge the role the Northern Territory government played in these negotiations. I commend their efforts to ensure the situation in the territory was always prominent in the minds of those preparing this legislation. Out of these consultations came the government's 10‐point plan which this legislation incorporates. Before commenting on the implications of this legislation for my constituents, I would like to remind honourable members of the exemplary record the Northern Territory has in the field of land rights for Aboriginal people.

I got a bit sick of hearing from those Labor members opposite that the territory government is racist, and I think this is an opportune time to inform members of the real situation in the territory. Forty‐eight per cent of the territory is covered by the title granted under the Aboriginal land rights act. That is almost 700,000 square kilometres of the Northern Territory. An Aboriginal benefits trust account allows for the progressive purchase of land throughout the territory, up to $20 million per year. There is $1.4 billion in the Indigenous Land Fund, which should be sufficient to address the land needs of Aboriginal people.

The Northern Territory already has community living areas legislation which has resulted in living areas for Aboriginals being excised from pastoral properties. The territory has a comprehensive and effective sacred sites legislation, the single most important issue for traditional Aborigines. Aborigines have a statutory access regime in place for access to pastoral lands for traditional activities like hunting and fishing. There is also a separate regime in place to allow access to sacred sites. The territory provides for the co‐management of parks. There are now parks under joint control that would meet an international benchmark.

In addition to these points, I would also like to add that, since the introduction of the Aboriginal land rights legislation, Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory have been paid some $350 million in royalties. The evidence shows that the territory already has in place the mechanisms for recognition of indigenous people's traditional links with the land.

Despite ATSIC spending $90 million of Commonwealth money on native title claims, the act has not delivered any tangible benefits to Aboriginal Australians. In fact, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator John Herron, has informed me that the state of Aboriginal affairs under Labor did not result in any gains in the area of Aboriginal health. There may have been gains in the area of land claims, but I have been informed by the minister that 30 per cent of Aboriginal children in Alice Springs still suffer from malnutrition. Meanwhile, someone in ATSIC decides that $90 million is better spent on land claims. This is why it is so important that the coalition government has a policy of quarantining ATSIC funds for health, housing and education programs, as it is clearly not always their priority.

In addition to the 48 per cent of the territory already granted to Aboriginal groups, there are now extensive native title claims over our towns, beaches, public parks and the coastline. How can we forget the chaos that exists over the status of our pastoral leases? The previous Labor government developed the Native Title Act on the assumption that pastoral leases extinguished native title.

The former Prime Minister stated that the government's view was `under the common law, past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title. There is therefore no obstacle or hindrance to the renewal of pastoral leases in the future.' The High Court's Wik ruling proved him wrong. The Labor government's native title legislation was drafted on the assertion that less than 36 per cent of Australia's vacant crown land could be claimed. The Wik decision means that 78.6 per cent of Australia can now be claimed.

State and territory governments will be able to legislate to allow the continuation and the protection of all existing activities defined as primary production under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These activities can be carried out without interference of native title holders. The coalition has worked very hard to fix the mess left by the Labor Party and this legislation is good for the territory. It addresses the concerns that territorians have about land tenure and delivers appropriate returns to Aborigines. The package guarantees the validity of any acts or grants issued on vacant crown land between the passage of the 1993 Native Title Act and the Wik decision.

The territory government, acting in good faith, issued some exploration licences on the previously accepted premise that a pastoral lease extinguished native title, and these remain valid. State and territory governments will be able to confirm that native title is extinguished by `exclusive' tenures like freehold, commercial and public works in existence on or before 1 January 1994. It is this provision that will ensure that most parts of the current claims over Darwin and Alice Springs will fail. Agricultural leases are also covered to the extent that, where it is reasonable to suggest through the purpose of the grant or the nature of the land use, exclusive possession is assumed. Any current or former pastoral lease conferring exclusive possession would also be included.

Land grants from the Northern Territory government to bodies such as town councils would extinguish native title, meaning our parks and reserves could not be claimed. This legislation ensures that the provision of government services like pipelines, roads, railways and municipal services may not be impeded by native title claims. There will be a continuation of statutory access rights for native title claimants. This does not conflict with the current access rights enjoyed by Aborigines as a result of territory legislation.

One of the most controversial aspects of Labor's legislation was the right to negotiate provisions in respect of mining and certain compulsory acquisitions. The right to negotiate has delayed many important commercial and mining developments Australia-wide. There have been no gains for Aboriginal people at the grassroots level through the right to negotiate. It often seems to be the case that Aboriginal land councils are more interested in achieving the right to negotiate for extraordinary amounts of financial compensation than in securing native title to land.

A higher registration test will be required for claimants seeking the right to negotiate on future mining activity. Proof of attachment to a particular piece of land will have to be provided and claimants will not be able to impede mining exploration as there will be no negotiations on exploration licences. There will only be one right to negotiate per project.

States and territories will be able to introduce their own mining regimes for dealing with land under their jurisdiction as long as the access rights of native title holders are not compromised. There will be no right to negotiate over vacant crown land outside towns and cities required for government type infrastructure. This is good news for high population growth areas like the territory as it means the government will have the ability to plan for schools, health clinics and powerlines with certainty.

The ability of the territory government to regulate and manage airspace plus surface, subsurface and offshore waters would be put beyond doubt. The native title claim in Alice Springs claims subterranean waters in and around the area. This legislation would make that part of the claim invalid. It would also ensure that amateur fishermen continue to have the right to enter and fish in territory waters unimpeded. The legislation would also facilitate negotiations of voluntary but binding agreements as an alternative to proceeding with the requirements under the native title legislation if the parties would prefer.

In summary, the coalition has introduced a bill that fixes the mess left by the Labor Party. It is my optimistic hope that the Labor Party will support these amendments in order to restore certainty for all Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous. I am concerned, however, that the ALP has indicated that it does not support all of the amendments proposed, supporting instead regional agreements similar to those promoted by the Northern Land Council and Central Land Council. This idea is completely unworkable in terms of administration and financial arrangements. It is the kind of idea that the former member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, often promoted as the self‐interested bureaucrat that he was and still is.
He used to stand up in this place and boast about his previous life before politics when he was a bureaucrat with the Central Land Council. He even said, and I quote from Hansard on 23 November 1993:

Fundamentally, we had the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to do this right. What gets up the nose of the opposition is the fact that the Prime Minister spent the time to get it right when the opposition has no hope of getting it right.
How wrong he was. No wonder the people of the territory got rid of him. He also used to talk of ATSIC's prestige and the gains it had made in securing social justice for Aboriginals.

I note when I read his old speeches in Hansard that he never talked about social justice for non-Aboriginals. He never talked about achieving a fair and balanced outcome for all concerned in relation to native title. He never talked about the waste of $90 million on land claims while Aboriginal people still suffer terrible health problems. The former member had no interest in representing terri tory pastoralists, businesses or families affected by native title claims. That is why in March last year territorians threw him out of office.

I notice that the former member, Mr Snowdon, has been looked after by the Aboriginal industry in the Northern Territory since his departure from this place in March last year. He popped up last week as a representative of the national indigenous working group at a committee meeting here in Canberra to discuss these native title amendments. He was naturally quite hostile towards any suggestion of reforming the Native Title Act as his mates in the land councils thrive on this environment of litigation and uncertainty for both indigenous and non-indigenous members of the Northern Territory community.

I have worked hard as the new member for the Northern Territory to achieve some equity in the amendments to the Native Title Act for all territorians. As secretary of the government members committee on Aboriginal affairs, and as a member of the joint committee on native title, I hope to represent the views of both indigenous and non-indigenous territorians on the enormous problems we face with the current native title legislation. These amendments outlined in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 restore the balance. They deliver a fair result to both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal interests.

As one moves around the country on the committees that one serves on and listens to the various groups talk about the proposed 10-point plan and the latest amendments that have now been circulated by the government, one can only wonder about some of the information that is coming back. Some people support the amendments the government has proposed, but those organisations that have a vested interest are mostly the ones that have no intention of supporting the government's amendments, and they have said so.

I have listened with a great deal of interest to those communities, but the important thing we all have to remember is that, until such time as this particular problem is sorted out, it is really not going to have any benefit to any members of the community—whether they be indigenous or non-indigenous Austral ians. We now have to start focusing on the real needs of our indigenous communities—that is, the provision of health, education and housing.

I have said on many occasions in this parliament that there are communities in Central Australia—for whom the Labor Party had responsibility for over 13 years—that do not have water or even electricity. They do not have electricity to run a fridge to keep their food from being spoilt so their children can have a decent diet.

You can sit opposite and say, `We don't like what the government is doing because it does not accord with our plans.' You had a go at doing it in 1993, you did not do it properly and now you are trying to stop the coalition government from putting its amendments—amendments decided on after six months of consultation with many organisations throughout Australia, both non-indigenous and indigenous.

The Aboriginal communities have a right to get some kind of direction, and that is the direction this coalition government is going to provide. With the amendments to the Native Title Act, there will be certainty for them and for other people as well. Let me just say once more that there are communities in Central Australia that do not have water and do not have electricity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) made an interesting point in his contribution. He suggested that, in his travels, he had had a diversity of views put to him regarding the government's amendments. He suggested that those who did not have, as he put it, a vested interest supported the government's position. The reality is, I fear, rather different.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality we are starting to see is that this government has engaged in a pattern of suppression—behaviour intended to prevent critical comment by bodies which have a public responsibility to advise the government and the parliament. These bodies have been prevented from putting their scepticism about this legislation before the community. It now appears that there is a pattern, with key Howard government ministers seeking to stop critical independent comment from their key advisory bodies becoming known to the public.

It has become known, because of the controversy of recent days, that there was a successful attempt by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) to nobble the Law Reform Commission—to prevent the Law Reform Commission, which for decades has played a role of providing advice to government committees, from providing its independent advice to the parliamentary committee established to review the proposed legislation we are presently discussing.

We know now that that intervention by the Attorney-General was preceded by certain conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We know that the Prime Minister raised with the Attorney-General his concern about the impact the Law Reform Commission's submission to an internal working group of the government had had. The Law Reform Commission's conclusions essentially said that key elements of the government's proposal would not work, would not provide certainty and would cost the community enormously through compensation payments.

The full detail of how this matter has worked its way out is yet to be revealed. But certainly, at the very least, there would appear to be questions about whether or not the Attorney-General's specific instruction to the Law Reform Commission to withdraw its submission was at the direction of the Prime Minister, or at the direction of others acting specifically on his behalf or with his authority, to prevent the public from becoming aware of those damning criticisms.

If this was an isolated instance, one might merely say that it was an appallingly poor set of judgments by both concerned. But it was not isolated. Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, intervened in May to prevent Professor Roger Kitching from issuing on behalf of the Biological Diversity Advisory Council a press release which called on the federal government to address the environmental consequences of its 10-point response to Wik as a matter of urgency.

Senator Hill's cover-up was revealed in Senate estimates hearings, but the full signifi cance of that cover-up has only now become clear. This is a government that has become mired in the suppression of matters that the public is entitled to know.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with the bill?

—The media release that Senator Hill suppressed said that the Biological Diversity Advisory Council was concerned that the government's Wik response would lead to increased activity in clearing of native vegetation and a general loss of biodiversity. Let us put this in context: the Biological Diversity Advisory Council is saying that the legislation that is now before this parliament—
—If you want me to take a point of order, I will.
—Don't take a point of order. Sit down, you idiot, and listen!

—Order! The parliamentary secretary was interjecting in a disorderly manner. But I suggest the best course for the member for Denison is to ignore him and certainly not to use the sort of language you did.

—I concede you are correct. The importance about this matter is that the legislation currently before this parliament is framed around a set of proposals which the government's key environmental advisory body, established by the minister and said by the minister to be the government's prime source of advice on biological diversity matters, has criticised as posing a threat of great significance to general loss of biodiversity. This was not a frivolous act by the Biological Diversity Advisory Council. The council prepared a press release because of its concern. I have a copy of that press release which was suppressed by the minister. In that press release, the chairman proposed to say this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has been asked to address the environmental consequences of its 10 point response to Wik and native title in general as a matter of urgency.

The Biological Diversity Advisory Council, established to give advice to the Minister on the conservation of Australia's biological diversity are concerned that increased tenure to pastoralists will lead to diminished government control on the 42 per cent of Australia under pastoral lease.

Chairman of BDAC, Professor Roger Kitching, said it was not the committee's role to debate the social justice elements of native title and its extinguishment but rather it is to focus on the consequences for biodiversity conservation.
Following a two‐day meeting, Professor Kitching said:
"The tenure and control over pastoral leases will be one of the biggest decisions government has made in recent history about the future of Australia's environment . . .

"Loss of biodiversity is recognised as Australia's number one environmental issue. The principal loss of biodiversity is occurring through broadscale clearing and poor land management practices in regional Australia.

"The committee was of the view that loss of biodiversity is advancing at an increasing rate despite an increasing level of awareness throughout the community and some outstanding examples of biodiversity conservation within some communities, landcare groups and local government areas.
"For example the Qld Government has issued permits to clear 500,000 ha of native vegetation in Qld in the last twelve months.
"Our concern is that diminished control over publicly owned land leased for grazing—
a consequence of this Wik legislation—
will lead to increased activity in clearing, pasture improvement and general loss of biodiversity in the interests of increasing production.

"At a time when the Natural Heritage Trust is making vegetation management and reversing the loss of native vegetation as its major objective it would be foolish to allow other government decisions to undermine these objectives.

The press release further stated that the BDAC had also met with the Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission, Don Morris, who told the committee that the environment and culture are the major drawcards for overseas tourists visiting Australia. Mr Morris said that the value of that industry is $14.1 billion and that its resource base is, in the words of this release, `largely environment and cultural'. So that was the framework of an advice that was first tendered to the minister, but then proposed for public release by the chairman of the council.

Let us look at who comprises the council. The council is not a bunch of eggheaded scientists. The council is the government's principal advisory group on biodiversity. It includes representatives of the scientific community, certainly, but it also includes representatives of local government, representatives from the pastoral industry and representatives from the mining industry—right across the board. I understand that the vote in relation to this matter was nearly unanimous. Only one member of the council did not assent to the proposal, not only to speak to the minister in the strongest terms about the biodiversity consequences, but also to assent to the release of the media statement.

We find now that we have a Minister for the Environment who suppresses advice to him and a public release of that advice from his own principal advisory body on biodiversity; we have an Attorney-General who suppresses advice from the Australian Law Reform Commission which was intended to be issued to the parliamentary committee looking at this legislation; yet we have the member for the Northern Territory popping his head up and absurdly saying that anyone who does not have a vested interest is in support of the government. The truth is that anyone who does not have a vested interest is the subject of a cover-up and a suppression by this government to prevent them putting on the record facts that the government does not wish to be known in relation to the proposals that it has put forward.

The very issues that concern the Biological Diversity Advisory Council—the increased flexibility of land use that would emerge from a more relaxed view, if I might put it that way, in relation to uses to which formerly land applied only to grazing purposes could be put; that is, the extension of those purposes—are also drawn attention to by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its draft, which I also have. That draft is a document which this government intended to suppress. No doubt other speakers will draw attention to particular components of this document. But one component is particularly relevant to the comments that I wish to make on the environmental hazards that this bill also represents for the Australian community—the threat to biodiversity.

BREAK.PARA: Might I just interpolate again so that the full impact of what Senator Hill did or did not do in relation to this matter is evident. Not only did he suppress the document but he did not pass on the council's concerns. When he appeared before the Senate estimates committee, it is transparent from his answers and from subsequent briefings that I have been provided with that the minister took no steps to pass on the concerns of his pre-eminent advisory body either to the task force which was considering the government's position, or to the Prime Minister, or to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) or to any other minister who was relevant to these proceedings. The Minister for the Environment noted it. What does that mean? He ignored it; he back pocketed it; he suppressed it; and he wished it would all go away.

The Australian Law Reform Commission looked at the financial implications. They noted that the government has underestimated the cost to the Australian taxpayer of what is involved. There were three components mentioned: firstly, validation of past acts; secondly, confirmation of extinguishment on exclusive tenures; and, thirdly, upgrading of pastoral leases. They said this:

The effect of the upgrading of non‐exclusive agricultural and pastoral leases valid at 23 December 1996, permitting additional activities that fall within the definition of `primary production' will further reduce native title rights and lead to additional compensation liability. Likewise, the permanent extinguishment of inconsistent native title rights, rather than their suppression during the life of the lease may be influential in determining the quantum of compensation; lessees benefiting significantly at taxpayers expense—
and let us understand this—
. . . lessees benefiting significantly at taxpayers expense instead of benefiting Consolidated Revenue by paying for their improved tenure.

Now we are not talking about hundreds of little farmers here; we are not talking about the poor peasantry of Australia; we are talking about some of the biggest ever foreign‐owned land‐holdings and a few squattocracy families, including some who are represented on the front bench of this government. It is those people whose personal income, whose person al capital, will be increased as a result of this framing of the legislation, rather than it benefiting consolidated revenue.
As the commission concludes, it is seriously concerned:
. . . that the government has . . . underestimated the extent of compensation that will fall due as a consequence of the Bill.

So there are two reasons for concern in relation to these issues that relate to the way in which what were previously grazing properties will be able to operate in the future should this legislation have effect.

Firstly, there is an environmental concern which hitherto has been suppressed, despite advice to this government by its key biodiversity advisory body. Secondly, there is the cost of it, and the transfer of wealth from taxpayers to a handful of rich pastoralists—not ordinary farmers. This has been suppressed as a consequence of the Attorney's suppression of the Australian Law Reform Commission. So there have been two acts of suppression, two acts of cover‐up—one on the environmental front, one on the Attorney's front—both designed to withhold from the Australian public the full implications of what this legislation intends.

This legislation does not give either certainty or fairness. It is legislation which has been brought forward without proper consultation with those who wish this government well in finding a solution, and that includes the opposition. There is no interest in finding, with those of us on the other side, an effective outcome that benefits all stakeholders in this particular complexity.

It now increasingly seems to be the case that we have a government that will not open its ears to independent critical comment, including comment that goes to the constitutionality, the legal validity and the compensation in the bill, or to the on‐the‐ground effects, particularly the environmental consequences. More than that, not only does it wish its own ears to remain deaf but also it wishes the Australian community to have its ears remain deaf.

So we have the wise monkey approach: we have hear no evil and see no evil, but we have a government that is perfectly prepared to speak the evil, and to speak it repeatedly. It is prepared to malign those who raise any criticisms about the way it approaches this matter, and it is prepared to use language which is entirely inappropriate in terms of its hostility and the conflict it is prepared to stir up within the Australian community on this matter.

So we get no certainty. We will find ourselves mired in more litigation. We find the cost to be underestimated. We find the government unprepared to recognise the impact this will have on the environment. We find an unwillingness on the part of the government to allow the work of those who have a critical and public role to play in Australia's community debate. Those who are tasked with these responsibilities by government—the Biological Diversity Advisory Council and the Law Reform Commission—are having their work suppressed, and the Australian community is prevented from hearing what they are entitled to have put before them so they may put their views on these important public matters.

Because of the way in which we are seeking to facilitate the conclusion of this debate within a reasonable time, I recognise that I should cut short my remarks at this point. I will conclude by saying that this government is mired in cover‐ups of its own making which go not merely to its morality but also to public policy, and which now show the full impact of the malice that is behind it.

The government is not prepared to deal with matters that we in opposition have been talking about for a long time, which they have been criticising as coming from a partial commentator, whereas the fact is the impartial commentators who would otherwise have spoken have had their mouths silenced, quite improperly, by this government in a way which smacks of cover‐up. Indeed, particularly given the pecuniary interests of certain frontbench members of this government, it almost suggests the smell of corruption.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is doubtful if there has ever been a more controversial, divisive, costly and relatively non-productive decision in the history of the High Court in this country. I do not say that lightly. I represent a rural electorate. I represent more Aboriginal people than anybody else in south-east Australia. I have lived through this debate over the last few years at the coalface, so to speak.

SPEECH.PARA: There may be some of us who do not like the High Court decision, but it is now the law of this country. Native title is now part of our common law, and we must live with that and work with it. That is what I believe this bill reflects quite accurately.

In 1992 the Mabo decision was brought down by the High Court and they went on to say that native title may exist on mainland Australia. In December 1996, the High Court brought down what is known as the Wik decision whereby they said that native title may exist on pastoral leases, and that was a surprise to everybody. Even the present opposition did not factor that into their original native title bill.
Native title still has not been precisely defined by the High Court. I will use the words of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) when he made his second reading speech on this present bill. He said:

Despite more than 3½ years of the operation of the current act, for most of Australia we do not yet know where native title exists and, if it does, the identity of the native title holders or the nature of their rights.

Of course we have to have rules for all this work, and this present bill clarifies these rules and adds some additional provisions to deal with the new concept of coexisting native title on pastoral lease land.

Up until now there has been an expectation out there—especially amongst Aboriginal people—that native title, including on pastoral leases, virtually equates to ownership. It does not, of course. But as a result of this the Aboriginal industry has hurled money at making claim after ridiculous claim. There has been no limit on the size of the claim and who may be registered. We have overlapping claims. One poor fellow with a mining lease in Western Australia has 26 overlapping claims on his mining lease.

I am told that if you add up the size of the land involved in all these claims it amounts to 143 per cent of the Australian land mass. Six hundred and twelve claims have been registered, over $100 million in legal fees has been wasted and we still do not have one square centimetre of native title land owned by Aboriginal people in Australia. In fact, there has only been one of the 612 claims resolved and that was for a few acres of land at Crescent Head on the North Coast of New South Wales and that was immediately sold back to the people who occupy the land.

The land councils are forever claiming that they want funds for quite proper activities that need to be done amongst the Aboriginal people. But they have gone totally berserk on paying lawyers to chase frivolous native title claims. The Cape York Land Council is spending in excess of $12 million doing that now. The Kimberley Land Council has spent in excess of $12 million. Even in New South Wales, up to 30 June this year, the New South Wales Land Council has spent $4,433,475, including $2 million last year—a total waste of money in the main.

The red soil country around Brewarrina, Bourke and Wanaaring in my electorate where claims have been put in is selling for an average of $8 an acre. It means that, if they had put that money into buying the land, they could own in excess of 550,000 acres now and own it outright. Even if native title were granted—and it will not be on the claims that have been put in so far—all they can do is go onto the land and hold a corroboree, which nobody is interested in doing in New South Wales, throw a line in the Darling River to fish or spear a goanna or something like that. Whereas if the money had been spent to purchase the land like every other Australian, they could own the land outright. Money is being wasted. It has caused incredible anguish, particularly amongst the landowners throughout my electorate, and it has set reconciliation back years. It is a wicked waste of money.

There is a myth afoot in this country that Aboriginal people own little or no land. The 1996 census showed that there are 353,000 Aborigines in Australia—that is, 2 per cent of the population—and they owned 15.3 per cent of the land mass or 117 million hectares of land in Australia. That is greater in size than the total land mass of New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory or—if we can take an overseas example—greater than the land mass of Northern Ireland, Scotland, England, Wales, France and Germany, both East and West, put together.

On top of this there is a certain amount of private land ownership. They own 341 properties and the last 200 that were purchased had an average value of $454,000 for the land alone. For example, that alone is more than double the land value of the property that I own. So we are not talking about insubstantial properties.

In addition to all this, the New South Wales government puts aside 7½ per cent of land tax collected to purchase properties. On those properties they also own all mineral rights, except for gold and silver, as well as oil and coal, and they get royalties from any mining conducted on those properties. There is also the indigenous land fund which is worth $1,289 million in 1994-95 dollar terms. The money put aside from that alone would purchase 100 farms for Aboriginal people every year forever—farms worth twice the value of my own property, for example. There have been other sources of funding. For example, the Northern Territory mining royalties to Aboriginal people now amount to more than $350 million.

Under this legislation before the parliament today, 78.6 per cent of the Australian land mass is available for claim under native title legislation. One wonders if we have our priorities right. I saw a recent Medical Journal of Australia article on death rates in the Northern Territory. The most common cause of death amongst Aboriginal females was homicide. The most common cause of death amongst Aboriginal males was car accidents, closely followed by homicide, and the premature deaths of Aboriginal infants were four times the Australian average. It is an absolute disgrace.

These are the sorts of things that we should be concentrating on and debating in this country today. But I see that ATSIC just recently funded an extra $80,000 to put a challenge up against the Hindmarsh Island Bridge legislation, which everybody knows has absolutely no chance whatsoever of succeeding. It is doomed to fail, and $80,000 is totally wasted when they could be spending money in these proper areas that desperately need funding.

My point on this bill is that the High Court decision was supposed to deliver something beneficial to Aboriginal people. So far it has delivered virtually nothing—certainly nothing on mainland Australia. In fact, it has wasted many millions of dollars. It has become an instrument of divisiveness. If you look at it objectively, it has become a curse to Aboriginal people in diverting these large sums of money to chasing ephemeral rainbows.

I want to talk about pastoral leases, particularly those in New South Wales. The High Court said in the Wik decision that unless you have exclusive possession on leasehold land then native title may exist on leasehold land. This has caused much angst in New South Wales, but there has been a total misunderstanding of what the High Court said by both sides of the argument—Aboriginal on one side and pastoralists on the other.

The New South Wales Farmers Association has attacked the coalition quite unfairly, I think, in calling us `spineless, gutless, shallow' and just about every other colourful adjective that you can think of. I believe that they have whipped some people into an unnecessary frenzy on this. They have been asking for the grazing leases in the Western Division of New South Wales to be included in the schedule. They have done that almost to the exclusion of all other debate about the bill.

There are a couple of points I would make. The schedule never existed until the coalition invented it, and it is attached to this bill. Of course, if the grazing leases are listed in the schedule, there is the belief that this makes them exempt from native title claims. That is true only if all sides of the debate accept that they should be in the schedule for proper reasons.

There is a lot of legal advice around that there is some doubt as to whether these leases should be in the schedule. The New South Wales government's legal advice on two occasions said that they should not be scheduled. The Commonwealth took its own legal advice from Professor Butt, an expert in property law who works in the law department at the University of Sydney, and Grahame Tanna, who is the Principal Solicitor of the Attorney‐General's Department. They clearly said in their legal advice to us that Western Division grazing leases do not confer a right of exclusive possession and should not be included in the schedule.

We asked the New South Wales Farmers Association to get some legal opinion on this. They have eventually come before us with four opinions, but those four opinions have some doubt about them. For example, the first opinion from David Bennett QC said in the conclusion:
In these circumstances it is simply not possible to express with anything resembling certainty what view the High Court will take in relation to leases under the Western Lands Act.
Further on in his conclusion, when talking about granting exclusive possession, he said:
. . . the prospects of the High Court taking that view must be regarded as fairly evenly balanced.
The second opinion that they obtained was from Peter McEwen QC. Regarding the conclusions he had come to, he said:
I have done so on the basis of relatively limited information.
He also said:
. . . it is not possible to prognosticate the view the Court—
that is, the High Court—
would take when applying the principles enunciated in Wik to leases under the Western Lands Act with certainty or precision.

The third opinion they put to us was from Dennis Rose QC who said that the leases should be scheduled but the arguments he seemed to use were the very arguments that were rejected by the High Court majority judges in the Wik decision. To some extent, that is also valid for Sek Hume's opinion, who was the fourth QC that the New South Wales Farmers Association put before us.

On balance, with all this conflicting legal advice, it would have been quite silly for us to schedule those leases, as the New South Wales Farmers Association wanted. I can understand and appreciate why they would want them scheduled. However, to do so would have destroyed the credibility of the schedule. It would have invited the other states who did not try this on to also have their leases which were excluded from the schedule included, and that would have collapsed the schedule. You may as well have taken out your Tippex, whited out whatever it was that was listed there and written in `Australia', if that was the attitude.

Also, it would have given the Labor Party a classic case to vote against everything in the Senate. Even if it had passed the Senate—which it would not have—you would have immediately had a High Court challenge on the validity of the schedule. That would have delayed getting certainty into Western Division pastoral leases for many months, which is against the good interests of the people who occupy grazing leases in the Western Division who have been subject, in many cases, to a great degree of anguish and uncertainty.

The New South Wales Farmers Association have said that we are going to need 5,000 test cases in the Western Division to resolve this. I believe that that is a gross exaggeration and not true. They have also said that we will see paralysis of agricultural production. Again, I do not believe that is true at all. They have said that, if it can be shown that the grazing leases should be added to the schedule later on, it cannot be done. Again, I believe that is not true. If it is shown that grazing leases do extinguish native title, as I believe many of them would, then they can be added to the schedule later on.

They have also used a Queensland comparison, saying that Queensland leases were included on the schedule where New South Wales comparable leases were not. Again, that is not quite correct. The small number of grazing homestead perpetual leases—small in area; I think it amounts to about 12.7 per cent of the state—are quite different from Western Division grazing leases. They have the right to apply to freehold the leases. They have the right to turn them into cultivation leases without permission. Their rents are calculated on the unimproved capital value instead of the livestock carrying capacity and so on. They are quite different leases from New South Wales grazing leases.

Having said all that about the schedule—because it has been such a contentious area—I do say that the bill, which is based on the 10‐point plan that we present to the parliament today, will fix everything that the New South Wales farmers want. There will be certainty returned to grazing because the primary production rights of the leaseholder predominate 100 per cent over the native title rights, even if they are shown to exist on some New South Wales grazing leases. No‐one can come on to your property and interfere in any way whatsoever with your legitimate activities. Even if you want to do other things in the future—if you can get permission, as you have to do now, to carry on cultivation activity, agricultural activity, tourist activity, or even running a helicopter flying school base if you wish—if that conflicts with the native title right, then we have made provision in this bill that the native title right can be bought out and compensation paid to the native title holders. The cost of the compensation will be picked up 75 per cent by the Commonwealth government and 25 per cent by the state government.

So the farmer, the pastoralist, the grazier will have no expense whatsoever. In fact, we will pick up 100 per cent of the cost of legal aid, if it is needed at any stage, for test cases to be run. I believe you would probably want only one or two and you could just about solve the problem in the Western Division in the future.

I do believe that if we can get this bill through virtually unamended and have it all finished by Christmas then this time next year all the difficulty and sorrow and everything else that has been associated with the present native title bill will have evaporated, because most of the claims in the Western Division, if not all of them as I have seen them, just cannot stand up. They will fail the registration test. Under our registration test you have got to have a proper identification of the area and proper maps. You have got to have a proper identification of the native title claim group under section 190 and you have got to have a proper description of the native title you are claiming for. It must be presented on a factual basis and you must have a prima facie case. Mineral rights are not included. Also, the physical connection with the land must be established. I will just read this:
The Registrar must be satisfied that at least one member of the native title claim group currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with the area covered by the application.

This connection must amount to more than a transitory access or intermittent non‐native title access. In other words, your grandfather cannot just have held a picnic there in 1920, or your relatives cannot have come in on a motorbike from South Australia, or you cannot just claim you have had a spiritual connection with the land. You must be able to establish a physical connection. I would have liked to have seen that a bit tighter, but I believe it is far superior to what exists in the present act and it will largely solve the problem. Overall, I do believe this legislation reflects accurately what the High Court wanted and it respects both sides of the debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some sorrow that I rise to speak in this debate. I say that because I believe that the thrust of this bill is an endeavour to turn the clock back. I think it was with some pride that, in the last couple of years, Australia as a nation has sought to make a statement that it really wanted to deliver and develop the concept of one nation—a nation committed to doing something for the betterment of all Australians irrespective of their background.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, I say that I very much support the thrust of the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Evans. The problem for the House today is that the thrust of this bill is really an endeavour by the Howard government to force a debate about Wik and native title, and it is a guise to launch a major attack on some of the most needy and disadvantaged people in our nation. That really is what the thrust of the bill is about—turning the clock back and walking away from the needs of the most disadvantaged of this nation.

For many years Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were the people who were out of sight and out of mind. They very much sought the help of many members of the Howard government. But the Howard government considered them out of sight and out of mind, and had the capacity to turn their backs on the needs of the most disadvantaged people in the nation while they feathered their own nests in government.

My position is that I think the Australian community at large is of the view that it is no longer possible to argue that they are the forgotten Australians. The tide has turned. It is not just the alarming issues of poor health, appalling living standards, shocking education levels and the lack of employment that have kept indigenous Australians in the public consciousness.

The broader Australian community has come to look with pride on the expressions of a unique and vibrant culture which has correctly attracted international attention through artists and musicians and people such as Yothu Yindi and Christine Anu. Wherever we go as a nation now we stand with some pride when we consider the achievements of our indigenous people. But the problem with this government is that it likes to embrace the Olympic champions, the international artists and the international musicians, but when it comes to the nitty gritty of really trying to do something about the most disadvantaged in the community, it wants to drive a wedge between mainstream Australia and those in the most disadvantaged places in Australia.

I take, for example, Yothu Yindi in particular. Through their songs they have popularised the ambitions and struggles of indigenous Australians for land rights as an expression of their culture. Long years of deprivation, dispossession, abuse and neglect have left enduring scars, and so they ought to. None of us can be proud of those scars, but it comes back to an endeavour and a commitment to actually do something to ensure that we overcome those scars in the future.

But,despite those scars, a vibrant culture is attracting the attention and support of the wider Australian community and the world. The Howard government has got to understand that, with respect to this debate, not only are Australian eyes on the House of Representatives today but also, more importantly, the international community is monitoring what happens with respect to this bill.

I suggest that the government's mishandling of the debate over Wik will reverberate around the world. No longer does Australia walk tall internationally. We have a Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) who has no international standing at all. The debate about Wik will further diminish Australia's standing internationally.

I refer, for example, to the action in part of the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) which I suggest is part of a pattern of activity which reveals that this government see native title as an intrusion—an encumbrance—which they want to get rid of any way they can if at all possible. It is a problem that they want to sweep under the carpet because they are not committed to doing something to assist the indigenous people—some of the most disadvantaged people in this nation.

It really is a massive irony that this government is acting firmly and resolutely against property rights just because the property holders, on this occasion, are not white. That is what it is all about—property rights for the white community but not for those with black faces.

The Liberal and National parties, after all, are the parties that trumpet their core ideological belief in property rights—yes, property rights for the whites but not the blacks. The Liberal and National parties, after all, are the parties which strut the Australian political stage declaiming their belief in law and order.

In the Wik decision, the High Court, I would suggest, has decisively ruled that, yes, all Australians are entitled to property rights whether they have a black face or a white face. The High Court decision recognises the property rights—and correctly so—of indigenous Australians. The government might not like it, some pastoralists might not like it, some miners might not like it, but it is the law of the land and so it ought to be. It is the only way forward for Australia—a sense of security, a sense of opportunity for all Australians.

Yes, the ruling might be inconvenient to the coalition government. That is why they are prepared to ignore the High Court decision as they run off to church and profess that they want to do something about the disadvantaged in this country. But, when it comes to making hard decisions and taking decisive actions, the real problem is that they will go missing in action in the same way that they have historically gone missing in action when it comes to leadership, commitment and a willingness to do something.

I suggest that the government's pig‐headed attitude to Wik may actually become a very costly enterprise to Australia at a time when we need stability and security so as to attract investment and create jobs. I refer to the Australian Law Reform Commission and the fact that it has pointed out and warned that the government's plans for native title will not deliver legal certainty but only deliver very costly litigation—all the way back to the High Court.

My colleague the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Melham, has correctly tried to constructively argue this same case through the long months of public debate about these amendments, but the government, for some strange reason, has turned a deaf ear to these warnings. I might also say that the government has become very sensitive when it comes to the Wik bill because there is not a favourable legal opinion lodged with the joint committee on native title except—and we are not surprised—for the legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department, from an Attorney‐General who has a huge question mark over his head today not only with respect to his future capacity to serve in the Howard government but also, more importantly, with respect to his standing in the legal community. And that is not to be dismissed. It is a major problem for the government and it is a major problem for law and order in Australia.

One of the greatest strengths of the Native Title Act as it now stands is that, wherever possible, it minimises the role of lawyers and it minimises the adversarial system of the courts. The Native Title Act, as it now stands, allows for a resolution of differences in a non‐adversarial, informal setting with emphasis on mediation.

The coalition now wishes to undermine this important process and introduce a costly legal process. Litigation will not only hurt indigenous Australia but hurt the mining and farming communities and the wider economic interests of this nation. This is what this is all about: not just the needs, aspirations and rights of the Australian indigenous community but also the economic needs of a great nation—the Australian nation—a nation that ought to be committed to ensuring that we all have the same rights, irrespective of whether they are property rights or opportunities for decent health, education and training.

The right to negotiate, I suggest, has been a key part of the Native Title Act and it has been the opposition's contention all along that the decision to extinguish this right will be constitutionally invalid. I believe that this right to negotiate is a crucial element in allowing meaningful input by indigenous people into real decision making—a sense of emancipation and encouragement to participate—about the development of their communities, their lands and their futures.

Since the right to negotiate was established, we have seen the indigenous community come up with some creative uses of this new‐found right. Win‐win solutions for all Australians have been the end result of that right to negotiate, especially, for example, the negotiated regional agreements which have put a heavy emphasis on a range of core needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

My commitment to native title is based on a strong belief that we can only expect to achieve this important goal of reconciliation if we see native title as being part of a wider package which fronts up to the other stark problems that the indigenous community faces in Australia as we approach the 21st century.

Regional agreements front up to exactly that issue. People negotiate, through regional agreements, ways to resolve crucial health, education, housing and job issues for indigenous Australians. The ability to come up with regional agreements, based on the right to negotiate, has empowered many indigenous communities with the right to determine, often for the first time, their own priorities. A right to have some control of the future will, in time, impact on the stark statistics which confront us when we look at the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population.

I refer to these statistics today because, as far as I am concerned, you cannot separate the Wik debate and the issue of native title from your commitment to do something about the basic issues of health, education and jobs. Reconciliation and an effective Native Title Act should be used by all sides—yes, all sides—to ensure that, as we go into the 21st century, we develop acceptable and effective plans to resolve the stark statistics of Aboriginal life.

The release of the findings of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander survey in 1995 has widened our knowledge of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. The survey shows that, while a high incidence of health problems such as asthma, hearing problems, heart problems and diabetes were widely reported, access to health care, especially in rural areas, was severely limited.

Aboriginal people start life smaller and finish it earlier, with the life expectancy for indigenous females at about 62 years compared to an Australian average of 81 and the life expectancy for indigenous males at 57 compared to an Australian average of 75. At any age, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are more than twice as likely to die as non‐Aboriginal people. At the most crucial age of 25 to 44, the risk is five times greater.

But not all the Aboriginal health statistics are gloomy. The death rate from cardiovascular disease has declined among Aboriginal males. Death from lung cancer is declining among Aboriginal men, although not among women. Alcohol related deaths are declining sharply as are male deaths from car accidents and homicide. The infant mortality rate continues to decline, but its rate of decline appears to have slowed.

Many of the health problems I have talked about can be tackled if we work with local communities to improve the standard of Aboriginal housing, which is an acute problem. An indigenous family is 20 times more likely to be homeless than a non‐indigenous family and four times more likely to be in overcrowded accommodation. At least a quarter of the community lives in unsatisfactory housing. In rural areas, this proportion is roughly one in three. Overcrowding is particularly acute in rural areas where one household in three comprises six or more people, and three‐quarters of these households had three bedrooms or fewer. In rural areas, about 40 per cent of these houses require major repair or replacement.

I am pleased to say that I have witnessed a number of places in Queensland, confronted with those difficulties, where this issue is now being effectively tackled by local Aboriginal communities. The communities are using the local housing crisis to provide new skills and to create job and training opportunities for their people and, in doing so, are resolving health problems for their old and young people.

Just outside of Townsville is the Shalom College which is run by the remarkable Uniting Church minister, Shayne Blackman, who has trained young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the skills to build appropriate housing in rural areas. As part of the hands‐on training at Shalom College, the teenagers and young adults have built nursing homes for their elders and classroom facilities for the younger people attending Shalom College's primary and secondary school. It is about practical outcomes because they have a sense of capacity and opportunity. There are a number of other examples that I could refer to today, but time does not permit.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest to you that there are solutions. But the biggest problem confronting indigenous Australia is employment. In some localities, the unemployment rate exceeds 50 per cent but, in the early 1990s, employment opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people grew more rapidly than non‐indigenous employment. This was largely due to the major expansion by the Labor Party of the community development employment projects scheme, under which participants have the opportunity to work on community projects funded by forgone unemployment benefits. Most of the CDEP work was low skill and part time and, overwhelmingly, it was rural and remote based.

Because of the lack of jobs, the lack of education and the lack of skills, the annual income that indigenous Australians earn is very low. Three‐fifths of people aged 15 or over receive $12,000 or less, while one in nine receive more than $25,000 per annum. Government payments are clearly the main source of income.

In conclusion, I suggest that the Wik ruling provided new and vital opportunities for indigenous Australians to confront their major social problems, their unemployment problems and the need to skill and train their people for new jobs that could be created by the rights invested in indigenous Australians by the Wik decision. If we are to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to create new opportunities for themselves, the Howard government should not be actively campaigning to undermine the High Court's Wik decision.

The government should act with respect for both the High Court rulings and the newly revived property rights of the first Australians. Some people on the other side might not like it, but the indigenous Australians are the first Australians and they have some rights and entitlements. The High Court has recognised them. It is about time the other side of the House recognised and respected the right of the High Court to make such decisions.

The Wik ruling can be a godsend for all. I know the `God squad' on the other side of the House do not have a lot of respect for the High Court when it comes to hard decisions. The Wik decision provides a path to help the reconciliation process, a path to help to resolve two centuries of disempowerment which has created the awful statistics which are all too often repeated in discussions about Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities.

The time has come to take the hand off the prayer book, the hand off the heart, and to actually do something. Get your hands dirty. Respect the High Court decision, empower the indigenous people, respect the fact that in Australia black people as well as white people are entitled to property rights. Give them the capacity to further develop themselves. Give them the capacity to negotiate local arrangements and to do something in a practical way about health, education and the all important employment issues of jobs and training. Take your head out of the sand, stand on your high heels and actually do something rather than just talk about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech just delivered by the shadow minister, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who is at the table, is undoubtedly one of the most offensive, odious and outrageous speeches ever to be uttered in this place. There is no doubt whatsoever that Aboriginal people are disadvantaged. There is no doubt that much needs to be done to bring their state of health up to the standard of those in the general community.

SPEECH.PARA: We were treated by the shadow minister to a range of Aboriginal health statistics. They were sad statistics. Quite often those statistics were correct. The shadow minister has the hide, the audacity, to come in here in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill and refer to those matters. The shadow minister is a member of a party which, for 13 years, controlled the treasury benches in Australia. For 13 years, that government did absolutely nothing.

The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has referred the current reference into Aboriginal health to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs, which I chaired before my appointment as Government Whip by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The government is absolutely determined to make sure that Aboriginal health and other disadvantage are redressed. The former government spent taxpayers' dollars and loads of this parliament's time talking about the problems of Aborigines and talking about native title but, at the end of the day, Aboriginal health, housing, infant mortality and educational standards remained as they always have been, and that situation is totally unacceptable.

BREAK.PARA: I think the Australian people will reject the hypocrisy of the now opposition. They had the hide to criticise this government when this is the first government to do anything. The shadow minister also suggested that we are trying to destroy the High Court decisions in Mabo and Wik. There is no doubt that, prior to the Mabo No. 2 decision in 1992, nobody thought that native title survived. We all believed that the concept of terra nullius was in fact the law.

When the High Court brought down the Mabo decision, it obviously exploded the certainty in land law that was previously there, and the former government brought in the Native Title Act. We then pointed out that that Native Title Act was an unworkable response to the High Court decision. When one listens to speakers from the Labor Party, one would think that that particular piece of legislation is a paragon of virtue. We, in opposition, pointed out that the Native Title Act 1993 was not going to work. Up until the present time, some 612 applications have been lodged before the National Native Tribunal and only one mainland determination has been made.

We have listened to opposition speakers saying how the legislation before the House will destroy the workability of the Native Title Act. What an absolutely sick joke! The Native Title Act has no workability whatsoever. What is more, one of the basic fundamentals on which the act was predicated was exploded when the High Court brought down its decision in the Wik case. It is interesting to look at what the then Prime Minister Keating had to say in the parliament on 16 November 1993 in his second reading speech on the then Native Title Bill:

I draw attention also to the recording in the preamble of the bill of the government's view that under the common law past valid freehold and leasehold grants extinguish native title. There is therefore no obstacle or hindrance to renewal of pastoral leases in the future, whether validated or already valid.
There it is was in black and white in the preamble to the legislation. The then Senator Gareth Evans, when talking about preambles said:
We all understand these days the role that preambles have in legislation as an interpretive tool for the courts and as a useful way of expressing the intended scope of legislation.
The parliament, in the preamble to the Native Title Act, expressed the view that native title was extinguished by leasehold and freehold grants but, obviously, the court decided otherwise.

This government accepts the decision in the Mabo case. We also accept the decision in the Wik case, but this legislation seeks to make the Wik decision more workable. Justice Michael Kirby, one of the judges in that case, pointed out that the decision in Wik could well bring about uncertainty. This government has had to redress the uncertainty delivered by the High Court.

It is quite wrong for the honourable member for Batman to suggest that this government has had a pig‐headed attitude to Wik. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin) ought to be congratulated for the exemplary way in which he has consulted with all stakeholders in Australia on achieving a situation which means that we are able to bring this bill before the parliament. He has consulted with pastoralists, miners, the indigenous community and with the general community.

He ought to be praised for bringing forward this measured response which will seek to reduce uncertainty. It will improve the workability of native title processes and find a balance among the interests of all parties and it will, most importantly, maintain respect for native title. The government said in its election policy that it would amend the Native Title Act to improve its workability, and this legislation before the chamber is the delivery of yet another election promise.

Far from those people opposite coming in here and seeking to condemn and criticise this government for this bill, they ought to sit back and say that this is another occasion when we did not create the problem but we accept the responsibility to fix it up. This legislation is balanced, reasonable and takes into account the needs of pastoralists, miners and the general community, as well as the Aboriginal community.

I want at this stage to refer briefly to the allegations made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) against the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in relation to the Australian Law Reform Commission. It ought to be recognised that the Australian Law Reform Commission operates on references given to it by the Attorney‐General. The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), was Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the last parliament. I have to concede that he was a pretty good chairman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
