—The member for Melbourne interjects. He was a much better chairman of that committee than he is shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. Both the Attorney‐General and I were members of that committee. There was a report brought down in relation to the Australian Law Reform Commission and the chairman, the honourable member for Banks, signed off on that report which indicated that the commission ought only be able to operate in accordance with references given to it by the Attorney‐General.

BREAK.PARA: With respect to the Australian Law Reform Commission, we have a gratuitous act by the commission in seeking to buy into the Wik issue and native title. There was no reference given by the minister. The Australian Law Reform Commission takes an extraordinary amount of time in many cases to report on references given to it by the Attorney‐General of the day. Yet, despite that, it was able to find within its resources the time to put together a submission on Wik.

The Attorney‐General has pointed out that the Australian Law Reform Commission is supposed to act on references given to it by the Attorney‐General. That is the position which was confirmed by a committee chaired by the Labor shadow minister in the last parliament. It has always been the position. Simply put, what has been said is that the Australian Law Reform Commission, in this instance, have overstepped the mark. They have forgotten what their legislation says. They have bought into something where they do not belong. They do not currently have any reference in relation to native title, yet they have decided to put aside the references given by successive Attorneys‐General and intrude into something which is not currently their responsibility. I think that is very unacceptable and most regrettable.

The honourable member for Banks uttered a few things in his speech that indicated what was wrong with the former government. He showed how out of touch the former government was and the opposition now is with the community. He was divisive. It is very clear that the honourable member for Banks listens only to certain interest groups and does not consider the interests of mainstream Australia.

The honourable member for Banks even managed to suggest somehow that the Native Title Act is workable. How on earth could anyone suggest that the Native Title Act is workable when there have been 612 applications lodged, yet only one determination by the National Native Title Tribunal with respect to mainland Australia?

We all know about the paralysis that has hit economic development as a result of the Native Title Act and because of spurious and multiple claims over the same piece of property. What this government has done is bring down a situation which will reduce uncertainty. We want to improve the workability of native title processes. We seek to find an appropriate balance among the interests of all parties and we aim to maintain respect for native title.

One would have thought that the opposition would have said to the government, `Thank you very much for fixing up the mess that we created in 1993.' But, regrettably, we find that once again the opposition are playing politics. They are showing simply how irrelevant they are.
It is curious to look at the comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) in the second reading debate on the bill. This really is the understatement of the year. He said:
There are some problems that were created in the aftermath of the Wik decision. We, on the opposition side, are fully prepared to cooperate in their redress . . .

I call upon the shadow minister to put up or shut up. Is he going to cooperate? Is the Labor Party going to cooperate? Are they going to urge their senators to collaborate in making sure that we are able to fix up the appalling situation in relation to native title that we inherited upon attaining government in March 1993? Are they going to do that, or are they going to do what speaker after speaker has said in this particular place? They are seeking to frustrate this attempt by this government to bring our 10‐point plan to fruition, a 10‐point plan that is fair not only to Aborigines but also to other sections of the community.
Mr Tanner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Melbourne ought to be ashamed of himself. Once I used to think that he was a person who had some ability. Clearly, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is still concerned about the member for Melbourne. On this issue the member for Melbourne is totally wrong. He ought to support the position enunciated by the government.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, we had the Mabo decision in 1992, we had the Native Title Act in 1993 which, I might add, was opposed by the then opposition at the time, and then we had the Wik decision brought down this year. This government has not rushed into a quick fix solution with respect to Wik. As I said, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister has consulted widely right across the Australian community with a view to obtaining a balance. I pointed out that he has spoken to pastoralists, indigenous interests, states and territories and also to industry.

These proposals currently before the parliament seek to achieve a number of outcomes. Those outcomes include legal validity for acts done between the commencement of the Native Title Act in January 1994 and the Wik decision on the assumption that pastoral leases and other tenures extinguished native title. The proposals also seek to restore certainty to pastoralists so that they can carry on primary production activities.

We seek to have respect for native title, preserving the principle of native title as established in the Mabo case in allowing claims to proceed. Of course, that explodes the suggestions made by the honourable member for Batman who tries to point out that we are seeking to destroy the Mabo and Wik decisions. The proposals also will confirm the common law relating to native title and, in particular, that it is extinguished by current and historical freehold, residential leases, commercial leases, and those agricultural and pastoral leases providing exclusive possession.

We also aim to improve workability through removing impediments to developing and building on the government's proposed amendments to improve the processes of the Native Title Act 1993. The proposals also include devolution to the states and territories and, in particular, allowing for alternative state and territory processes for granting mining leases on pastoral lease land. We also aim for a speedy and sustainable resolution of concerns and uncertainty.

Some people were not happy with what the Prime Minister included in the 10‐point plan. It is interesting that some people said that the government did not go far enough and others said that the government went too far. That probably indicates that the government has it exactly right.

The Prime Minister has shown exemplary leadership in relation to Wik. It would be very easy for us to rush off and urge wholesale extinguishment of native title by pastoral leases. It would have been easy for us to be populists and to go out there and say what many people wanted to hear. But the Prime Minister on this issue, as on the guns issue, and as on so many other issues, has shown himself to be a statesman. He has been prepared to spend an inordinate amount of time working out a position which is fair and equitable to all sides. That is why I am particularly proud to support this legislation which is currently before the House.

Some people have said that there ought to be wholesale extinguishment. I can understand the superficial attractiveness of that approach. However, to have blanket extinguishment would undermine the very certainty and security sought to be brought about by this legislation. Our pastoralists, in particular, would be affected in a number of ways. Were we to go down the extinguishment road there would be legal problems, and it would considerably increase the likelihood of a successful constitutional challenge to the validity of the legislation.

Claims, of course, would not disappear, they would simply manifest themselves as claims for compensation. There would be more time lost and there would be more paralysis. There would be substantial compensation paid for extinguishing native title. The courts, on a case by case basis, would have to decide what compensation would be paid in individual circumstances and there could be millions if not billions of dollars paid out.

Also, one really has to be practical in politics. Life is not the art of the possible, it is the art of the attainable. While we achieved a massive majority in the last election—the people of Australia resoundingly voted for the Howard coalition government—regrettably, owing to vagaries in the Senate voting system, we did not obtain a similar majority in the upper house. As a government we had to be aware that we must bring in reforms to the Native Title Act but it was important that, if they were going to be workable, if they were going to come into effect, we get them through the upper house. It was made very clear by the Labor Party and by the minor parties in the Senate that, were we to go down the wholesale extinguishment road, our legislation would be unlikely to be passed by the Senate and there would be an indefinite continuity of uncertainty.

There are very many proposals in this legislation of a technical nature which substantially improve the workability of the Native Title Act, and there was no point in our making a great big noise and bringing forward proposals for wholesale extinguishment which would have resulted in increased legal cases. It would have resulted in an enormous amount of financial outlay, even if we could have got the proposals through the parliament. But it is obvious we would not have got them through the parliament and so there really is a very practical as well as a moral reason for not proceeding down the road of wholesale extinguishment.

Also, there were downsides for the Australian community generally if we were to go down the road of wholesale extinguishment. It would risk the reconciliation process. The honourable member for Batman said that we were not committed to reconciliation. That is absolutely untrue. This government and ministers have pointed out that we are committed to the reconciliation of Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal Australians, and I think the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) would agree that this is a bipartisan approach.

The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) actually sits on the national council with respect to reconciliation. So it is quite wrong, it is very dishonest—and I am pleased to see that the member for Melbourne is nodding—to suggest that this government does not support the principle of reconciliation.
As far as our international reputation is concerned, it would also have been damaged were we to go down the road of wholesale extinguishment.

To sum up, as time is short, this is a very important piece of legislation. We are seeking through this legislation to fix up a problem which was left to us by our predecessors. This bill is balanced, it is fair, it is workable, it is equitable and it will be to the benefit of the indigenous people of Australia. It will also be to the benefit of miners; it will be to the benefit of the tourist industry and also of pastoralists. So this bill is a win/win/win/win situation. Those opposite stand condemned for their negativity, for their failure in government to do anything about Aboriginal people and for their bringing to Australia the Native Title Act, which has proven so far to be absolutely and completely unworkable. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today this House will debate whether we are to be one people belonging to one nation or many peoples belonging to many nations. For many years Australia has been divided through policies of multiculturalism and an unfair view of history that have led to the impracti cal, discriminatory and stupid notion of land rights, and special treatment for so‐called minorities at the expense of everyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: Today you may very well collude to enshrine that division despite even the previous Prime Minister's view of past validated freehold grants, residential, commercial, pastoral, agricultural and validated crown actions extinguishing native title. This extinguishment should be extended to cover vacant crown land as well.

There is a need to put the High Court back into its rightful place of interpreting the law, not creating the law. We must question who is running the country when seven judges, not elected by the people, presume to make such monumental decisions. It is imperative that the people of Australia understand that native title is, as is said, the `thin edge of the wedge'.

In conjunction with the Canadian government, the indigenous people of Canada have recently created Nunavut, a separate indigenous state within the nation of Canada. Originally, Nunavut was to be a tract of semi‐autonomous land of some two million square kilometres. However, a further deal was done and the two million square kilometres of semi‐autonomous land of this state within a state became 350,000 square kilometres of freehold land. This will be formalised in 1999, and will in effect leave Canada with another country bigger than the state of Victoria within its borders.

It is imperative that the Australian people know and understand the international forces driving the Aboriginal industry and the flawed and divisive concept of native title. It is crucial to realise that the underlying blueprint and inspiration behind the creation of a separate indigenous nation within Canada and the impending creation of an Aboriginal nation within our own country is the United Nations Draft Declaration of the Rights of Indigenous Peoples.

The Australian people, and through them the parliament, must be given the widest possible opportunity to understand the massive and irrevocable changes to Australia that will occur when this United Nations treaty, like so many before it, is ratified and imple mented—as always, to the detriment of ordinary Australians. The report Indigenous peoples and environmental management: a review of Canadian regional agreements and their potential application to Australia, part 1, by Richardson and others, states:
The Canadian experience is one strategy that Aboriginals might use to resolve the issues raised by the creation of native title in Australia.
In the words of Mick Dodson, ATSIC Social Justice Commissioner, on 25 October 1996:
We believe that in the process of adopting the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, time is on the side of Indigenous peoples.
We continue to believe that through perseverance with this process, it will be possible to achieve consensus on the provisions of the declaration, as it presently stands.
Or let me quote Peter Jull, a former adviser to the Canadian Prime Minister and now a research fellow of the Northern Australian Research Unit and consultant to the Central Land Council, who said:
Nunavut has prophetic meaning when viewed in an international context.
It heralds a new world order.
A hunter‐gatherer people, with a stubborn sustainable development philosophy and no visible modern industrial economy, are taking over one‐fifth of the world's second largest nation state.
Such a breakthrough provides practical inspiration for other indigenous peoples. This does not mean it should be copied precisely elsewhere, but it can be usefully studied as a precedent.
There is an undeniable link between the events in Australia and Canada. The man who was the architect of Nunavut in Canada is now living in Brisbane, and planning a Nunavut for Australia.

There is no doubt the long‐term goal of the Aboriginal industry is to create a separate indigenous nation within Australia: a separate country that the allegedly guilty non‐Aboriginal Australians will pay for. This is a clear and indisputable fact that will disturb all Australians who believe we are working for the future as one people. The concept and general understanding of `indigenous' has been created with dubious purpose and dangerous intent. The true and much broader meaning of `indigenous' is not generally understood, and as it stands it is meant to confuse and deceive.

It is most important for us all to be Australians. How long you or your ancestors may have been here is irrelevant. It is a flawed argument to essentially suggest that some people are more Australian than others when some of us were born here and others have chosen to become Australians—either we are equal in all things or equal in none. When what is indigenous, what is Australian and levels of Aboriginality are mixed with the fact that the greater majority of so‐called indigenous people are of mixed ancestry, often with only small percentages of Aboriginal blood, confusion of identity and entitlement reigns supreme. What is certain however is that, to progress together as one people, we must all be treated equally and not separated for special treatment.

In Australia, Aborigines comprise less than two per cent of our population yet, under native title, they will claim perhaps as much as 75 per cent of land that is supposed to belong to us all. It is beyond belief to even consider giving less than two per cent of the population of Australia a stranglehold over 75 per cent of Australia, yet that is the issue before us.

It is true that many Aboriginal people are not working and that they are living in appalling conditions. The current situation, with the corrupt and inefficient activities of ATSIC, does not allow much opportunity for improving their lifestyle. However, they do not have a monopoly on being disadvantaged, as it is also true that a million other Australians are not working and, although they feel little hope for the future, no‐one is giving them land. Rather, you are taking the land that belongs to us all and making it the sole property of the few.

I am accused of trying to turn back the clock to the 1950s but the government, by refusing to extinguish so‐called native title, is turning the clock back to the 1780s. Those who fear fairness and decency applying for everyone call me a racist, but by embracing so‐called native title this government and its predecessors are advocating the ownership of land purely based on race.

BREAK.PARA: Let me remind members of this House of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Section 9 of that act makes it unlawful for a person to do any act involving a distinction, exclusion, restriction or preference based on race which has the purpose or effect of nullifying or impairing the recognition, enjoyment or exercise on an equal footing of any human right or fundamental freedom. Section 10 of the act provides that if, by reason of a law of the Commonwealth, state or territory, persons of a particular race, the first group, do not enjoy a right that is enjoyed by persons of another race, the second group, or enjoy a right to a more limited extent then, notwithstanding that law, the first group are to enjoy the right to the same extent as the second group. The noble intent of the act has however been nobbled by section 8 which allows special measures for ethnic and racial groups and hence discrimination against white Australians.

We must be one nation. We must not have an Aboriginal or any other nation within our nation. The path of native title will eventually divide Australia into many nations of varying ethnicities: an Aboriginal nation will be just the beginning. We must extinguish native title, without penalty to the Australian taxpayer, through an amendment to the Australian constitution. This should be put to the Australian people in the form of a referendum to be held concurrently with the next federal election. If I had the opportunity to move an amendment to the Native Title Bill, I would move that consideration of the bill be deferred until the electors of Australia are given the opportunity to express their opinion by way of referendum. If our country must face division, let the people have their rightful chance to stop it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the evening of Thursday, 25 November 1993 I rose in this House to oppose the Native Title Bill, as it then was. I asked the assembled members of this house a question: could it be that once again regional Australia had been asked to carry the heaviest load? Over those intervening years the answer has reverberated a very clear yes.

BREAK.PARA: That evening in Canberra in l993, I pleaded with the parliament to understand that the ideas and the concepts they were playing around with were highly dangerous. The legislation that the government was supporting would divide this nation and the Aboriginal people of Australia would not gain one iota from the passage of that bill. Unfortunately, and I say this with no sense of pleasure, I believe that I was right. That evening my arguments were intended for the ears of Labor's then regional members. One characteristic shared by those honourable members at that time is that at the subsequent election they were unceremoniously thrown from office partly because of, I believe, the betrayal in that summer of l993.

The disastrous effects of the astonishing judgment of the High Court of Australia in the l996 Wik decision and the deceit of the Keating‐Beazley government in passing the Native Title Act have engulfed all quarters of our nation, not simply the entire regional section of the parliamentary Labor Party. Let us look at the native title impact on Australia today. The facts are obvious. Seventy-eight per cent of Australia is potentially subject to native title claim. That is undisputed. There has been only one negotiated successful claim in five years despite $88.8 million worth of funding through the representative bodies. I understand that is something like 600 claims and that everyone is aware of the overlapping claims issue. For instance, in my own electorate of Grey there is more native title claimed than actually exists.

The most obvious effect has been the shutdown of minerals and resource development in this country. Already, in the three years from the Mabo judgment, offshore mining increased as a percentage of mining activity by Australian companies from 27 per cent to 41 per cent as Australia's miners were forced to halt activity in their own country. This is equivalent to around $486 million flying out of Australia in a single year. Yet Labor's Special Minister for State, the then member for Robertson, Frank Walker, now replaced by my colleague Jim Lloyd, told the House, `I think that those who are suggesting that there will be some loss of investment are simply wrong.'

Were that were so. Our farmers have been devastated by the High Court's decision and the subsequent acts of the Commonwealth. Even advocates such as Rick Farley, who many believe sold out his fellow farmers in l993, have been forced to admit that farmers have been stymied by the Native Title Act. The Wik decision of last year has exacerbated such concerns.

I come to the impact on my own electorate of Grey. By its very nature, my electorate has borne the brunt of much of the uncertainty of native title, remembering that it is 92 per cent of the land mass of South Australia. To be truthful, I wonder if my very presence in this parliament did not prejudice the efforts of my electorate to get a decent hearing from the previous government. Would they have had such disregard for the people of the north of South Australia if there had been a Labor member for Grey at the time? Regrettably the answer is yes for even the protestations of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) who was dumped by the ALP for his efforts was unable to shift the Keating‐Beazley mind‐set.

The farmers of Grey have been frightened, intimidated and provoked by the legal advocates of native title—advocates who are usually not Aboriginal; they are usually from Adelaide or Sydney and have no interest in the productive use of pastoral land.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Native Title: Australian Law Reform Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. I refer the Attorney-General to his claims that the Australian Law Reform Commission has no power to comment on the Native Title Bill because it has no current terms of reference directly on that subject. Why then did the Prime Minister's parliamentary secretary, Senator Minchin, involve the commission in discussing native title amendments from early 1996—a period of over 12 months—including by writing to the commission on 3 July this year on the bill? Exactly when, and in what circumstances, did the Attorney-General first learn that Senator Minchin and the government have been using the commission as a source of advice on amendments to the Native Title Act?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My point of order relates to standing order No. 142, which states that ministers are responsible to this House for matters over which they have public responsibility. Ministers explicitly are not responsible for statements made by senators in the other place on this or any other subject.
—Order! There is no point of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition refers to my claim that the Law Reform Commission has no power. The Law Reform Commission must itself think the same because, under the previous government, it sought a reference on native title, which was declined. Earlier this year, there was correspondence in relation to the subject of new references. The commission sought another reference on the subject of native title, and it was not given. I cannot answer for the involvement of Senator Minchin; I do not know.
—When did you find out about it; that's all you were asked.

—What I can say is that the submission that went to the Wik task force was not, to my knowledge, sought by the Wik task force, except in so far as it was sending out copies of the bill for comment. This all goes to an allegation that we are seeking to suppress the opinion of the Law Reform Commission. Mr Rose, the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission, does not seem to think that that was what was occurring. There was no direction given. There was no suggestion that any direction would be given that their opinion not be provided to the Wik task force or to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title.

ANSWER.PARA: In the discussions that the acting secretary of my department had with the president of the commission, it was left on the basis that it was ultimately the commission's decision whether or not to comment on the Native Title Bill. But, if they were to do so, they knew that it was my view that they would be doing so without statutory authority. I would have been remiss in my duties as Attorney-General, responsible for the Law Reform Commission, if I had not drawn that to the commission's attention. Let me just say that it is not the content of the submission which is in issue. My position would be exactly the same whether the position was favourable or unfavourable. I expressed similar concerns in relation to a submission that the commission made to another committee of this House, in this case on copyright law.

You have also raised the issue of why I only raised concerns about this submission, and some of the interjections seem to be directed at that. I was not, in fact, aware until earlier this week that the commission has been making submissions on a wide range of issues that are unrelated to any current reference. I was not aware of this practice when I initially wrote to the president to put my view that making submissions on matters not the subject of an existing reference required my authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you would give a direction.

—Why, I ask the opposition, did the Law Reform Commission not advise on the Native Title Bill 1993? Why did they not advise on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1995? Why did they not advise on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996? Why did they not offer advice to the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund inquiry into the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act? The opposition has rushed off to the Clerk of the Senate and sought advice on the conduct of—
—He's a better lawyer than you.

—Let me respond to the member for Batman by saying that my understanding is that the Clerk of the Senate has no legal qualifications. I question the judgment of the clerk in rushing out on Monday two opinions based on hypothetical facts. The second of the opinions actually refers to me. So the set of facts in the first letter was not hypothetical at all; he was intending to refer to the situation regarding me, the commission and the committee. What he advised on was not fact. What I have done is endeavour to ascertain the situation on the basis of a proper statement of the facts. I have sought advice. The Chief General Counsel has advised that I am perfectly correct in asserting that the commission has no power under its act to offer a submission on a matter on which it has no current reference, in particular on the Native Title Bill.

ANSWER.PARA: I also sought advice on the true situation regarding the discussion between the acting secretary to my department and the president of the commission. The acting secretary has, as a result of that discussion, decided the commission would not offer a submission.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't have much choice, did he?
—He did have a choice. Let me just tell you what the acting secretary has told me. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I told him—
that is, the president—

that he was "at a cross‐roads"—the Commission could go forward with the submission to the PJC and he would receive an "unhappy letter" from the Attorney. Or they could not go forward, and he would not receive any letter—instead he and I could sit down and try to work out a set of ground rules relating to submissions which would satisfy all the parties. AR expressed concern that I might wish to suggest that the Commission should be limited to only making submissions on matters relating to current references. I told him—
that is, the acting secretary told him—
that it was not my wish to be so restrictive.

I then suggested to AR that he think about what I had said to him and that I would call him later in the day. In fact, I was not able to speak to him until the following day, when he indicated to me that the Commission would not be going ahead with its submission.
Conversation was generally quiet and friendly.

You might say, `Well, what would the Clerk of the Senate have said if he had known those facts?' Let me tell you that the Chief General Counsel says that there is no suggestion of a breach of the Parliamentary Privileges Act on those events.

You have been running around for the last four days raising issues in the Senate. Yesterday you did not even ask me one question on the subject. You did not have one question. You allowed it to be asked in the Senate where they do not have the facts. I had the facts. You let them go on. This can now be seen for what it is: it is really just an exercise in attempting to smear and besmirch. I reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a supplementary question. My supplementary question to the Attorney‐General is: then in your view that conversation that you had with the assistant commissioner does not constitute an effort to influence him?
—The question is out of order.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the Attorney‐General table the notes he was reading from.
—Was the Attorney‐General reading from notes? Were the notes confidential? The Attorney‐General says that a number of the notes were confidential. The unclassified note has been tabled.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of criticism of Australia's greenhouse position? Has the criticism led to a reconsideration of the government's position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to a report in today's Australian of some criticism made of Australia's position by Denmark. I will take the opportunity in replying to the honourable member for Hindmarsh to mention to the House that Denmark's environment minister, Mr Sven Auken, has criticised Australia's claims for what he describes as `special consideration'. Let me start by saying that Australia is not seeking special consideration; Australia is merely seeking fair consideration. I notice the Labor Party is once again siding with foreign criticism, as they always do. They always side with foreign criticism. Whenever the Australian national interest is at stake they always agree with those who criticise Australia. But may I take the opportunity of saying that, of all those who might choose to criticise Australia's position, Denmark is in a particularly vulnerable position.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason that Denmark is in a particularly vulnerable position is that Denmark herself is part of some special arrangements that exist. For example, Danish statistics relating to CO2 emissions claim that emissions of CO2 fell by 0.5 per cent in 1996. However—and this is the interesting part, Mr Speaker—this was achieved by deducting 13 million tonnes of emissions from energy exports to Norway and Sweden. Denmark's electricity, therefore, went into a black hole. While they talk about Nordic power sharing, neither Norway nor Sweden counted the emissions either. So, somehow or other, some of the European countries who, with Labor Party support here, adopt this self‐righteous position and point the finger at Australia and say that Australia is asking for special treatment, themselves have some extraordinary special arrangements. According to my advice, if we adopted the Danish method we could all get our figures down but the environment would be no better off. Mr Speaker, can I say to Denmark, can I say to the energy minister of Denmark, and can I say to all the supporters of the Danish position who sit opposite that we are sticking up for the Australian national interest.

What is involved in this greenhouse gas debate is a threat to 90,000 Australian jobs. What is involved in this greenhouse debate is an attempt by the Australian government to stick up for the Australian interest. Those who criticise our stance and those opposite who support the critics of our stance are doing the Australian national interest in the eye. What I am arguing for, what I will continue to argue for and what my government will continue to argue for is a fair deal for Australia: not a special deal for Australia, not a Labor deal for Australia but a fair deal for Australia; a deal that will protect Australian industry and, even more importantly, protect and generate Australian jobs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Native Title: Australian Law Reform Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice. Did the Attorney‐General personally authorise the tabling of the Australian Law Reform Commission's 1996 annual report which lists 24 wide‐ranging submissions made that year by the commission to various government agencies and parliamentary inquiries, consistent with a tradition going back 21 years? Will the Attorney‐General confirm that, since the commission had already written a lengthy report on the Native Title Amendment Bill in response to Senator Minchin's letter in July, no further resources would have been necessary to prepare a submission to the parliamentary committee? Isn't it true that the only reason you stopped the commission making a public submission to the parliamentary committee was that the government did not want the commission's criticism of the bill to become public, and that the Prime Minister would have ensured that you had absolutely no future in the government if you hadn't?

—It is a nice try from the member for Banks. He aspires to be one of the young Turks, one of the young restless. The problem is that he is not a Turk, and youth has passed him by. What he has got to offer his frontbench is restlessness in buckets. I table annual reports in significant numbers and I would not pretend that I have read every part of those annual reports.
—You don't read them?

—I have not read in detail the AUSTRAC report, the AFP report or the NCA report. That is done by members of my staff. What I was aware of was that the commission had made submissions on a number of issues, but I did not know that they were making submissions on matters on which they had no current reference and on which they had delivered no report. I only became aware of that earlier this week. I became aware of their submission to the Wik task force only after they had delivered it. I did not know that beforehand. When I did find out about that, I queried it. My concern has always been, having been a member of the 1994 Melham committee that said that the Attorney‐General should be the sole source of references for the Law Reform Commission, that it do its job and not somebody else's job.

—My question without notice is addressed to the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Would Senator Sherry be entitled to claim capital city rates of travel allowance when staying at his mother's house in Opossum Bay, outside Hobart?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that this matter has been raised by the senator in another place today. The Remuneration Tribunal has determined that senators and members are entitled to a capital city rate of travelling allowance when staying overnight in a capital city. In making his claims for travel allowance, Senator Sherry has consistently specified `Hobart' in relation to Tasmania. The Remuneration Tribunal does not define a capital city. In processing claims for payment of travel allowance, the Department of Administrative Services accepts the claimant's statement that it is a capital city. It appears to be a matter for Senator Sherry to decide—

ANSWER.PARA: Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Prospect!
—It appears to be a matter for Senator Sherry to decide—

ANSWER.PARA: Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Prospect.

—It appears to be a matter for Senator Sherry to decide whether he should be claiming capital city rates of travelling allowance for possibly 144 days at $300 a night while staying at his mother's house 49 kilometres outside Hobart at Opossum Bay.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain the significance of recent indicators on imports, housing approvals and retail trade? What do they indicate about the economic outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The honourable member will be aware that retail turnover figures for August released yesterday were better than expected following a very large 2.6 per cent rise in July. Although there was a 0.4 per cent fall, the trend growth rate in August was 0.6 per cent—the highest monthly growth rate for two years. Trend retail turnover was particularly strong in South Australia—0.7 per cent for each of the last three months. Throughout Australia only the ACT has performed better. The pick‐up in imports in August also points to strengthening activity. Total exports of goods and services reached a record high in August, growing by three per cent in the month.

ANSWER.PARA: The Drake International hirings intention survey also released today presents more good news. It reveals that employment is now on the up, led by Australia's hospitality, sales and business services sectors. Drake also had good news for South Australia. South Australia is `now back in hiring mode' with job opportunities forecast to increase by 1.6 per cent over the next quarter. The pick up in retail trades and employment in the state of South Australia will be very much welcomed by the South Australian government, led by Premier John Olsen.

Building approvals in August also showed a strong 13.5 per cent rise, suggesting that underlying conditions in the housing sector remain firm. Strong increases in approvals were recorded both for houses and medium-density buildings. On Monday, I also referred to the fact that housing affordability is at its best for years. I suggested that some senators and members who did not own houses could perhaps think about getting back into the housing market. I suggested that the Bedouin from Burnie, Senator Sherry, might be somebody who should buy a house.We now find out that Senator Sherry does have a house—it is his office in Burnie. Senator Sherry both lives and works in the building, which is both his home and his office. That means, according to Senator Sherry, that if he is not at the office he is away from home. He can claim an away from home allowance every time he leaves the office. Most people claim pay to go to the office. Senator Sherry claims pay to leave the office.

We know that, in leaving the office, Senator Sherry spends some 140 nights in a place he calls Hobart—49 kilometres away at Opossum Bay. So we have weekend at Burnie and then we have week days with mum in Opossum Bay. Senator Sherry claims $300 to stay with mum at Opossum Bay while he is on parliamentary business. Can you imagine the kind of welcome he gets? He gets paid $300 to go home to mum's. Can you imagine the welcome? `Oh Possum!' she says; `Oh Possum, you're home!' On Sunday, the Leader of the Opposition said, `If Labor people are rorting, Labor people go.' It is time for Senator Sherry.

Has the minister checked his travel records and have these checks revealed any further errors? Will the minister now table his travel records for the second half of 1996-97? —In the last few days the opposition, via the media, have thrown at me allegation after allegation. They have tried to smear my name by innuendo without any basis. They have been on a fishing trip and they have found nothing. I have answered more than 25 questions which have found nothing for the opposition. I will continue to answer your questions, but if you have got an allegation, why don't you make that allegation and come up front with it? At the same time, why don't you say it out of the privilege of parliament? I have got nothing to hide.

BREAK.PARA: Through your briefing of the media yesterday you started to bring a third party into it—an innocent person, a good ordinary person, a person I have used as a commercial pilot on four or five occasions. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of initiatives by the government to provide rollover relief from capital gains tax for Australian small business? Who will be eligible for this relief?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before this government was elected, it said that it would introduce a family tax package. We did. Before this government was elected, we said we would reduce the provisional tax uplift factor. We did. We said that we would reduce the fringe benefits tax compliance burden. And we did. We said that we would give small business capital gains tax rollover relief. And we did. We delivered on all of those tax commitments that we had put to the Australian people before the last election.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to capital gains tax rollover relief, we said that where a small business sold an asset to buy another or sold a business to buy another the capital gain should allow it to be rolled over capital gains tax free. The Labor Party had never thought about small business in this way before. Not only did we deliver—we delivered in full, on time. What is more, it is not just rollover relief for small business, it is not just allowing you to rollover in relation to an asset or a business while you are in the business of business; we also wanted to allow small business people to rollover into their retirement. For many small business people all of their savings go into their business. They ought to have the opportunity when they retire to come out and have that capital gains tax free.

We moved an amendment to allow a $500,000 waiver of capital gain in relation to small business rolling over in retirement. Who do you think tried to stop that coming into effect? The Australian Labor Party, led by Senator Nick Sherry in the Senate. Get a load of this: he thought it was too generous to allow small business people to rollover into retirement! He probably thinks, `Why don't small business people go home and stay with mum and claim money to do so?' The Australian Labor Party tried to put a test in relation to that which would include personal assets over $5,000 to disqualify small business people from getting that relief.

For 13 years the Australian Labor Party sat in office and what did they do for the small business community of Australia? Nothing! You get a government which is elected on a platform, which comes in to introduce its tax plans on time and in full, and what does the Australian Labor Party do? It tries to stop it, led by Senator Sherry. You will recall also the Leader of the Opposition said in this place that the Labor Party would support the government in reducing concessionality for high income earners in relation to superannuation. But he was overruled in the Senate, wasn't he. He was overruled by? Senator Sherry. Senator Sherry overruled you once; it is time you overruled him. Tell him: when Labor people rort, Labor people go, and if you cannot do it, get somebody in that office who can.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Travelling Allowance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, I refer to your statement yesterday, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: ‐ quite often a charter will return to its base when I have been dropped off at a point . . . That is the dead leg.

Minister, on the weekend of 19 and 20 October, at a cost of $1,690, you chartered a round trip originating in Brisbane, overnighting at Orungal, then back to Brisbane, where you have said you took a commercial flight to Canberra. Why did that charter then return to Dalby at Commonwealth expense? Given you were not on the flight, Minister, can you guarantee that this was a genuine dead leg and that no‐one else was taken back to Dalby?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is just another one of those baseless allegations to try to smear me. I will not be diverted by your smears and your innuendo from doing my job.
—Are you going to answer it? You said you'd answer it.
—I warn the member for Hotham!
