TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware that many farm businesses, which at the best of times can support only one family, are having to support two because the current asset test arrangements applying to the age pension discourage older farmers from gifting ownership of the family farm to the younger generation? Would the minister please outline to the House the changes to the gifting provisions relating to the transfer of ownership of the family farm, as announced recently by the Prime Minister and the minister in the Agriculture—Advancing Australia package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know it is of great importance to him and to many other members. The gifting arrangements are a new policy and they are part of Agriculture—Advancing Australia. It sees the government delivering on a longstanding commitment to address a very real need: the welfare need of aged farmers and the very difficult circumstances which have confronted Australian farmers over the last decade or so. The fact is that there are thousands of older farmers living on farms with the next generation, and sometimes the generation after that—their sons and daughters, and sometimes their grandchildren—where that farm can no longer provide what ordinary Australians would regard as a decent standard of living for more than one family. And certainly not for two or three, as is sometimes the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Many of those farms once would have been able to, but relentlessly declining terms of trade have overcome many farm families, despite the sector's legendary reputation for improving productivity and doing the job more effectively. Many of these people find that they are just unable to live decently, yet they cannot access the age pension because of the way in which the asset tests impacts on them. Our policy will enable farmers in this situation to transfer ownership of the family farm to a younger generation who are actively involved in running the business and then to receive the age pension immediately instead of, as currently applies, five years down the road. This will benefit not just those older farmers but also the younger generation taking over. They will be able to pick up the reins, relieved of a substantial financial pressure. They will be in a better position, so will those farms and so will the national economy. This is a carefully targeted package which is not available to wealthy farmers but which will be of real value to those many, many hard‐pressed farmers out there in real need.

BREAK.PARA: I would be particularly interested to know just what conclusions about this gifting provision my opposite number, the shadow minister for primary industries, has now reached. His reaction to this package, which was so widely welcomed by the farm leaders in this country, was that it was a cruel hoax and constituted a few things which were a pale imitation of what they had in place. It would be interesting to know what his attitude is now.

I think it is time we started to gain a bit of an impression for the benefit of rural Australians as to where he is up to in his policy formation. It is 19 months since they lost their position. I think Australia's farmers would like to know a bit about it. We know a couple of things. He has been out there saying that the Leader of the Opposition has given them a blank page on which to start setting out a rural policy. In fact, he recently said, `Kim Beazley has given me a total blank sheet.' It is probably very much like the one they took to the last election. It was a blank sheet. There was nothing on it. They did not have a primary industry policy.He quoted the Leader of the Opposition as having said, `Rural and regional Australia is at the heart of Labor's comeback.' He said that he sees it as a `huge charter and a challenge to rebuild credibility', whatever that means. We have a blank page here. This is their policy. I wonder, Mr Speaker, could we table the Labor Party's rural policy? Could I have your permission to table it?

Filling in the gaps would be a very worthwhile exercise on the part of my opposite number over there because we need to know what it is about. All we know at the moment is that, from his reaction to this package, which has been so widely welcomed in rural Australia, the blank page will not have on it gifting, farm management deposits, farm family restart, Farmbis or anything else that is in the AAA package, the Agriculture—Advancing Australia package, because he says that it is just a cruel hoax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Family Services advise a retired constituent of mine whose elderly, seriously ill husband resides in a nursing home what she should do to offset the effect of the increases in daily fees on their joint disposable income which may affect her capacity to maintain the family home? Is this the type of complaint that Senator Campbell was referring to on the 7.30 Report last evening?

—I cannot comment in detail on the honourable member's question. I would be happy to take the detail of that and come back to him with an answer. What I do want to say is that the aged care reform policy this government has put into place, which is implemented today and which means this government will start rebuilding the nursing home sector in this country today, is designed to protect financially disadvantaged people in the community. The bill also has within it a hardship provision. The key plank of this policy is that no person in this country who cannot afford to pay bonds or who cannot afford to pay fees will be asked to do so. People who are financially disadvantaged or who cannot afford to pay will be protected by this legislation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, what reaction has there been to the government's small business policy announced yesterday? What will this additional protection mean for small businesses? Will it lead to more costly court cases as some have claimed? What is the government's actual objective with this new initiative?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: THOMSON

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: House of Representatives Practice , third edition, at page 517 says:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . questions without notice which are substantially the same as questions already on the Notice Paper are not permissible.

I draw your attention to question No. 2321 to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business seeking his response to community and business sector reaction to the government's announcement yesterday of its response to the fair trading inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is in order. There are differences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were in the opposition I would be pretty worried to hear about the endorsements that we got for the small business statement. They are some of the strongest statements in support of a government policy initiative that I have seen in a decade or more. In fact, if you look at the Service Station Association press release, their heading reads `Federal government's "new deal" a winner for small business'. They described it as the `most comprehensive small business package in history'. Marcus Kollington said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . thousands of service stations would be saved from closure and their employees saved from unemployment.
The MTAA said:
The Federal Government has acted in a decisive manner which shows genuine leadership.
They said:
These are the most exciting decisions made on behalf of small business for many decades.
I like this one; this is true and an important statement—Michael Delaney, well known to all in this House, a person of longstanding political experience, said:
The Coalition Government has returned to its roots and remembered the "forgotten people" of small business.

Absolutely right. The heading of the Australian Small Business Association was `The policy passes small business test with flying colours'. The heading of the Australian Retailers Association was `Retailers welcome government proposals'. Bob Gardini is a name associated with the franchising business. He is the one who gave you a report telling you what to do. You failed to do it. When he read our package, this was his heading: `Historic day for small business'—a very authoritative one. The Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association said it:
. . . welcomes the "New Deal:Fair Deal" package . . . and congratulates the Government in producing a well balanced and focused initiative.
The package deals with the problems that APADA and other small business participants have identified for many years.
It went on to say:
. . . the . . . reforms can be expected to change dramatically the operating environment for small business, and for the better.
It is a long list but it is worth hearing. This government has been very interested in, and worked hard with, the Pharmacy Guild. This is what they said:

. . . the Government's willingness to keep faith with the small business community by deciding to undertake a range of forthright and excellent public policy measures to address the disadvantage small business proprietors have faced for decades, is a credit to the Prime Minister . . .
And quite right they were to say that. They—that is, small business employers—look at the consequences of the policy and say:
This can only lead to better work relations, the growth of the small business sector and an increase in employment for young Australians.

That is good news really for everybody. Part of the reaction we have had is that small business now has the confidence to go out and give people jobs, to grow their business and to really get this country going.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did VECCI say?
—ACCI, the federal body—
—No, VECCI.

—I do not mind talking about VECCI. ACCI's heading was `Strong response to fair trading report'. Trevor Griffin is the well-respected Attorney-General in South Australia. I was very interested to hear his remarks on our proposal to change the Trade Practices Act, because there will be a bit of commentary from certain interests on that. Trevor has a very well‐deserved reputation and he said this about the unconscionable conduct measure:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Federal Government's decision will be met with wide ranging support from small business and is something in relation to which I can indicate my personal sympathy.

That is high praise from a very experienced Attorney-General at the state level. Even Senator Andrew Murray from the Democrats says that `this package is welcome in many respects and shows what can be done'. Yes, VECCI had their concerns, but they also said:
. . . VECCI endorses most of Peter Reith's action plan to protect small business . . .

I am pleased they say that, because they represent a lot of small businesses. I would like and encourage them to look very closely at the trade practices change because we think it is a fair deal and it is very good for the vast majority of people who are the constituents of that organisation. From the office of the Minister for Small Business in Victoria, Louise Asher said that she strongly supported a special meeting of territory and state ministers. That was on retail tenancy, which is another very important part of the package. Wherever you look, there have been very positive responses to the government's package.

I just want to conclude by correcting an answer that I gave yesterday. I am afraid I do appear to have slightly misled the House. I said that Labor had in their last set of initiatives—in fact, their 17 last initiatives—in one way or another proposed a review, a committee or whatever. Actually, I was not quite right because when they were talking about retail tenancies yesterday I thought I had better get out their latest statement on these very issues. This one is a sort of Labor policy statement on small business. I said there were 17 reviews. This has been issued whilst Labor has been in opposition, so this is their latest policy—but one, which I will come back to. The headline under the name of the Leader of the Opposition is that the Labor Party today announced it would conduct a complete review of its small business policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister seen reports that from today nursing homes intend charging up to $98,000 in entry fees? Is the minister aware that for most elderly people the only way they can pay such large sums is to sell their homes? Why should thousands of elderly Australians have to pay nearly $100,000 to get a nursing home bed?

—The government is extending Labor's hostel policy introduced in 1988, 10 years ago almost, whereby the amount providers can charge is not prescribed. It was not prescribed under their policy. This is an issue for agreement between the resident and the aged care facility. It has never been prescribed by government. It will not be by this government; it was not by their government.
—Ninety‐eight thousand dollars.
—Order! The member for Jagajaga has asked her question.

—There are many people, contrary to the shadow minister's allegations, in hostels today who have dementia, who are very frail. They are in hostels. They are paying bonds. They have been paying bonds for the last 10 years. They have not been able to look after their own affairs. They have had to have their families, their legal advisers or the guardianship boards in each of the states and territories, look after their interests. The policy has worked well in hostels. Nothing will change in that respect when it is transferred to nursing homes as well. The government will, however, be monitoring the new arrangements, and we will act firmly if there is any sign of providers abusing this system.

BREAK.PARA: What we have done is establish a complaints hotline in every state and territory in this country, something Labor never did in their hostel policy. In addition to that, we have established a complaints committee in every state and territory in this country. That is why I am amazed at the hypocrisy of the shadow minister for aged care. She feigns despair, when she was part of the government which introduced the same policy for hostels.

Furthermore, let me remind the House that it was Labor which allowed hostels to charge any level of additional daily fee they wanted to. They could take everything from the resident over and above the pension and the little bit of money a pensioner could earn before their pension was affected. If they earned $20, under their policy the hostels could take $10 of that money. That was the kind of policy that that mob over there introduced when they were in government. We have put a stop to that. Basically, Labor failed. They failed the aged sector in this country. They failed the frail elderly in this country. Labor left the state of many nursing homes in total decay, and we are cleaning up their mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. In the very positive reaction from the small business community, their industry associations and the media to the government's fair trading reform package, it has been implied in some predictable quarters that we are not addressing business conduct issues in the retail tenancy area. Can you please inform the House what actions the government is taking to assist small retailers experiencing retail tenancy problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member again for his work and also for his question. I must say that I was rather surprised that the opposition made some comments about what they claim to be the inadequacy of our package when it comes to retail tenancy issues, but I would have to say that I have been in their situation before. If the government does something really good, the pressure is on you to find something in it that you do not like so you can at least be an opposition for the sake of being an opposition. But I tell you what: you picked the wrong issue.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite remarkable that opposition members should have said what they said yesterday—namely, that the package was inadequate in respect of retail tenancies—because this is not a new issue. This issue has been around awhile. In fact, it was on your plate when you were in government. I think it is timely that we remind you of the things that you said when you were in government. In fact we might even remind you of what you have been saying in opposition.

Before I do that, let me say that we have taken very strong action when it comes to the question of retail tenancies. We have done that which Labor was never prepared to do—that is, exercise some national leadership on this issue. We have been prepared to get the parties together, set some benchmarks and set up a process to get the state and territory ministers together.We had another classic yesterday. In the shadow minister's response to my ministerial statement on legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act, he said, `I want to wait and see the legislation to see whether or not they are tinkering around the edges.' Three and a half hours later, we brought in the legislation. There was egg on your face again. This issue has been around before. When Labor responded to this issue of retail tenancy matters, the then small business minister, Mr Beddall, said:

Given that this issue covers state and territory responsibilities, the government proposes to have this matter referred by the Minister for Small Business and Customs to the proposed Commonwealth-State ministerial meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did.
—That is right. Now you are arguing for more, and I will give you some more.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I like the interjections, thank you very much. Ask me about travel allowances. Here is another quote:

ANSWER.PARA: The former Small Business Minister, Senator Schacht, said in April this year, "Under the constitution, retail tenancies themselves are a matter for the state, so there is a matter of getting good legislation at the state level."
That is in more recent times. But only two weeks ago, the Leader of the Opposition was saying that we needed to get the states onside on the retailing issue. This is what he said:

Of course, all the states have got to be gotten in the basket for decent, decent treatment. I know your problems go way beyond that and many of them are with local government. There's not a great deal we can do about that at the federal level, but we ought to do what we can.

We are doing what we can, and I tell you what: it is a lot more than you ever proposed to do when you were in government. So do not give us this cant and hypocrisy that the package does not go far enough. This package has left you absolutely for dead, left you in our wake, left you irrelevant, as you have been on this issue for many years.

Just to add final insult to your policy position, after you had your review when you went into opposition, you turned up with a statement of so-called policy principles. It is a one‐pager and it has seven principles. Yesterday, you said that retail tenancy was the No. 1 issue that we had failed to properly address. Here is your piece of paper. Tell me where on this you have any proposal in respect of retail tenancies. I can tell you the answer: absolutely nowhere. There it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Given that the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business is collecting pieces of paper in respect of his bill that was introduced yesterday and inviting us to comment about the devil in the detail, I seek leave to table a press release that points out there is devil in the detail, in that it does not do what he claims it does.

—My question is to the Prime Minister and it also concerns a matter affecting small business. Will the Prime Minister explain why he has apparently now ruled out absolutely accepting any proposal from the tax office to stop small business minimising or avoiding tax through the use of trusts? Can he explain to this House why some small businesses should be allowed to minimise or avoid tax entirely because they operate through trusts, while the bulk of the small business community operates through companies and pays corporate tax? Prime Minister, why shouldn't there be a level tax playing field for all small and medium size businesses, regardless of the legal vehicles they use to operate a business?

—It is quite apparent that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is not only deprived of relevance but also deprived of advice and deprived of attendance at this House because, after question time yesterday, I made it perfectly clear that some of the press reports which had appeared in relation to this matter, particularly those so vigorously taken up by the Australian Financial Review , were quite wrong. What I made clear was that we were not going to make changes to taxation and we were not going to make changes to the general body of law that would significantly disadvantage the small business community. In fact, in a remark which I made in the party room, which was incorrectly reported in the newspapers, I said that we were not going to take any action to bankrupt small business. Obviously, the abuse of trusts, the use of trusts under the taxation system, is something that ought to attract the attention of any responsible government.

BREAK.PARA: I want to make it clear to the parliament and to the Australian community that, in addressing the issue of taxation reform, we intend to match the test of fairness to all of the Australian people. In addressing the issue of taxation reform, we will build a taxation system for the 21st century that will generate jobs, promote exports and attract investment. It is very interesting that I should be asked a question about taxation by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, because it is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who really wants a GST. He was dropped upon from a great height by the Leader of the Opposition within a couple of hours of making that statement. The longer this debate goes on about taxation, just as you were made irrelevant and left in our wake on small business reform, so you will be made irrelevant and left in our wake on the issue of taxation reform.

Your response to the challenge of taxation reform is to say that all you have to do is fiddle at the edges and that basically the system is okay. You had 13 years to fix Australia's taxation system; you made it worse. Now, 18 months into opposition, what is your response to the challenge of taxation reform, which is the greatest single area of economic reform that is needed in Australia to take us into the 21st century? Your response is to say that no reform at all is needed.

Let me simply say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the taxation reform proposals that we will bring out will give to the Australian community, to the business community and to the ordinary taxpayers of Australia a modern, fair, incentive‐driven system that will promote jobs, will attract investment and will free the exporters of Australia from the crippling burden of an old-fashioned, ramshackle, out‐of‐date wholesale sales tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question. I do ask the Prime Minister: will he clarify, because he didn't in his statement yesterday, whether it is the case that he proposes to exempt small business from any change to the taxation law which would treat trusts in the same way as companies for taxation purposes?

BREAK.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is in order.

—I am perfectly happy to repeat everything I have just said to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I am perfectly happy to do that. I know you are a mile behind on taxation reform, you are a mile behind on small business reform and, after the tipple of Sherry that you have had at question time today, you are a mile behind on travel rorts too.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Trade and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. What assistance has Australia offered the Indonesian government to help tackle the increasing environmental and human toll as a result of smog enveloping a large part of South-East Asia from forest fires on the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Borneo? Will Australia be offering longer term support and expertise in emergency and technical assistance, given Australia's long history of bushfires?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Fisher for his question on this important issue involving the horrific firestorm in Indonesia and the smog which has settled over a great deal of South-East Asia. I am now pleased to announce that the federal government is doubling its assistance to the Indonesian people and Indonesian government with regard to this circumstance. An additional $1 million for the provision of a package of aerial water bombing services to Indonesia has been approved following consultations involving Minister Downer, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in New York; the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Andrew Thomson; AusAID; and other organisations involved in this matter. Following consultations with the Indonesians, and that was most necessary to make this a worthwhile response, it has been agreed that, due to limited water availability and poor visibility for flying—
—New South Wales has offered assistance for weeks.

—You might joke about this but this involves human lives, Australian and Indonesian. Whilst I will concede you at least know where Opossum Point and Opossum Bay are, you might otherwise remain silent on this issue. The federal government has been moving, in consultation with the Indonesians, as quickly as we can in relation to these matters. I want to make it clear the aircraft will not be deployed against the large fires burning in Kalimantan and Sumatra but will be used for a specific role requested by the Indonesians. It has been agreed that our water‐bombing aircraft can be more effectively using containing newly emerged spot fires in eastern Indonesia. I am pleased to say that the South Australian Country Fire Service will be providing this function as the contracting body and moving through that body so there is a clear-cut change of command to utilise aircraft, which will also involve maritime and other units.

ANSWER.PARA: There are quite strong safety and related concerns in relation to this smog problem. It has only been after a careful examination—but a quick examination—of the requests that the Australian government has agreed to this. It does reflect the very positive bilateral relationship that Australia has with Indonesia and our desire to provide what we can, realistically and reasonably, to help turn the tide in the extraordinary situation which has settled over too much of South-East Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Did the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Carmody, clear with you or your office before it was delivered his speech of 10 September which advocated taxing trusts for everyone in the same manner as companies? Did you or your office approve that speech in the knowledge that it contained that section relating to the taxation of trusts?

—He could well have, and, if he did, I would have said to him he is quite entitled to make that speech. He is quite entitled to put forward views in relation to tax, and I have put forward similar views myself. The Prime Minister just stood here and said quite clearly that he is prepared to look at the issue of taxation of trusts. We have made it clear, in response to the matters that were raised by the member for Gellibrand before the election in relation to high wealth individuals, that we will be publishing a position paper in relation to trusts looking at the treatment and the taxation of trusts. That will be coming out shortly, and we will be putting that out for public discussion.
—Have you said anything about a small business plan?

—Come on; don't interject. The old Clarence Darrow is over there asking these penetrating questions at the end of question time when they have given up asking about travel rorts. It is pretty noticeable, isn't it? There have been no questions about travel rorts today. I wonder why that is? It is because all roads lead to Opossum Bay, to Senator Sherry down there at Opossum Bay claiming that the taxpayers should pay him $300 a night to stay with mum. That is what is happening. We have the Leader of the Opposition here, and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. Might I draw your attention to the question of relevance and the relationship to the taxation of trusts. I suggest that the bow is getting a little long.
—There is no point of order. The Treasurer is canvassing a very wide tapestry.

—We have here the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition who were in control of the travel allowances of Senator Mal Colston in 1983. They overruled legal opinion and said he needed to be counselled. They set him on a 10‐year career. The Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—and I have said this before—the 1983 Mal Colston defence team, cannot ask a question because they know they are deeply implicated in all of this. I tell you, there is one question before this parliament today: does the Leader of the Opposition have the ability to sack Senator Sherry? That is the great question that is before this parliament today. If you do not have the strength to do that, old son, you do not have the strength to do anything.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr Speaker. The supplementary question to the Treasurer goes back to the question he did not complete answering: what are his views on the exemption of small business from any new taxation regime treating trusts in the same way as companies?
—The question is out of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. After years of neglect and no action on the sensitive subject of child support, many non‐custodial parents in my electorate of Gilmore are relieved to hear that this government has had the guts to make some very necessary changes that will make life more bearable for both parents and their children. Could the minister advise those parents in Gilmore, and throughout Australia, just who will benefit from these much needed reforms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for her question. This is a matter of very considerable interest on this side of the House. Yesterday the government announced some important reforms to the child support scheme to take effect in 1998‐99. The package represents a balanced approach, and it focuses on the interests of children and the balance of responsibility between both parents and fairness to taxpayers generally. The fact is that there are 155,000 payees who will benefit from the introduction of a minimum child support payment of $260 a year. This initiative will reinforce the message that parents have primary responsibility for the financial support of their children. Three hundred thousand payers will pay less child support as a result of an increase in the exempt income amount, and 96,000 payees will have some of this reduction offset through increased family payments.

ANSWER.PARA: The additional relief will be provided to blended families through allowing child support payments to be taken into account for family payment purposes. Furthermore, the amount of income the payee will be allowed to earn before it affects child support will be significantly reduced. The non‐agency payments in arrears received with the first regular payment of child support will be treated in the same way as other child support under the maintenance income test.Other reforms include allowing parents to use the most recent taxable income assessment for the calculation of child support and broadening the income base to ensure that payers are not avoiding their responsibilities through minimisation.

Further administrative reforms will be introduced to the Child Support Agency to build on the significant reforms that have already been made. We recognise that these measures are a second important step in the process of child support reform, and that continued consultation is required. I can assure the honourable member and members such as her who are interested in this matter that we will be seeking to inform at the next stage. I am sure honourable members will be very pleased to note that, after 13 years of inactivity by the former government, this is a government prepared to address these sensitive issues.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Dismissal of Chief Executive

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Do you endorse the dismissal of Civil Aviation Safety Authority Chief Executive LeRoy Keith by the four new CASA board members who have all signed secret resignation deals with the former minister for transport?

—Mr Speaker, it is my understanding that it is a matter for the board under an act of parliament which, in relation to the powers of the board, has not been materially, if at all, altered from the act put in place by the government of the party of which you are currently a member. It enables me to contrast the magnificent reforms that have been achieved by my government in the area of transport, and particularly in the area of aviation. For the first time we have brought a bit of fairness and justice to the noise‐afflicted people of the city of Sydney, instead of dumping all of that noise that Laurie Brereton did over all those Labor voters in the inner suburbs of Sydney.

BREAK.PARA: One of the interesting things about our reforms for Sydney airport is that the greatest beneficiaries have been people living in safe Labor seats. It is the people of Petersham, Leichhardt, Newtown and Stanmore who have really benefited. I think a few chardonnay socialists live in those suburbs now and a regular columnist of newspapers like the Sydney Morning Herald. It does not alter the fact that we have delivered a fair deal to the residents of Sydney and that is but one of the many transport reforms that has been carried out by my government. It is my understanding that it is a matter for the board and, gee, that was a wasted question, wasn't it?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister detail to the House the steps that have been put in place to improve the accountability of members of parliament? Are there any further steps that should be undertaken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I could start answering that question by saying that the text for today is: why doesn't Kim Beazley have the guts to sack Nick Sherry? That is the text for today, Mr Speaker. If you think that I am endeavouring to impose—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This bloke opposite is very, very sensitive. The member for Hotham really did you a great service when he started this little exercise. For the Leader of the Opposition and those who sit opposite—who by the volume of their interjection merely proclaim their sensitivity on this issue—let me remind them that the standard that I have just asked of the Leader of the Opposition is not only a standard that I endorse but interestingly enough it is also a standard that has come out of the mouth of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. This is what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition so helpfully and so lovingly had to say at a doorstop this morning as he arrived at Parliament House, and I ask everybody to listen to it:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that we were quite likely to suffer a little bit of collateral damage with all the flak flying around—
you are not wrong, Gareth, and it gets even better—

and as Kim Beazley made absolutely clear from the outset, to the extent that any of our people, whether politicians or staffers were involved in doing anything wrong, they would have to bear the consequences.

What we have demonstrated is that this is a bloke who, by any measure of the men and women in the streets of Australia and the clubs and pubs of Australia, has absolutely and shamelessly rorted the system. To suggest that Opossum Bay, with its gentle streams and wandering sheep apparently meandering down the main street of Hobart, is really part of the city of Hobart is like suggesting that Katoomba and Blackheath are part of the city of Sydney.

The reality is that you have been caught out on this. You have demonstrated deplorable double standards. You have sought to impugn the decency of members who sit opposite. By contrast with your gutless low standard, we have been prepared to enforce standards. I have been prepared to endure the difficulties personally and otherwise in relation to the action that I took last week. I took that action because I knew it was necessary to uphold and proclaim greater standards. At the first test of leadership on the issue of standards, the Leader of the Opposition has fallen over. No, worse than that; he has not even got into the starting blocks on the question. He shows no guts. He is without principle on this issue. He has demonstrated double standards and on that note, Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Travelling Allowance

TALK.START.PARA: —On the day of 19 October I commenced a charter flight in Brisbane after a media commitment and a veterans' engagement in Brisbane. The flight went on to Dalby for an official commitment. I was then joined by my staff member to fly to Stanthorpe, where I had a meeting with fruit growers and a function at a retirement home.

BREAK.PARA: The charter then continued on to Orungal because I had a speaking engagement in Texas that night. Early the following morning, at approximately 7.30 a.m., the charter flight departed for Brisbane with me and a member of my staff on board. I disembarked in Brisbane to catch a flight to Canberra in order to keep afternoon commitments. A member of my staff continued on the flight to Dalby, which was in any case heading back to its base at Orungal, near Texas. It was a dead leg anyway. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's failure to protect thousands of Australians from having to pay nearly $100,000 to enter a nursing home from today.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —From today, older Australians and their families will know what this Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and this government are doing to nursing home care in this country. Today it gets real for this minister. From today, nursing home care will no longer be available to all Australians on the basis of their health need. From today, older Australians too frail and too sick to care for themselves will no longer be automatically guaranteed a bed in a nursing home as the means of getting the care they need. From today, the traumatic process of arranging nursing home care for an older relative has just become more traumatic.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now clear that, from today, older frail Australians will be paying up to $98,000 to get a nursing home bed. Most people can find that sort of money only in one place: their family home. They do not have it tucked away somewhere else. They do not have it in their back pocket. They have it in one place: their family home. Their family home will have to be sold from today.

This Howard government slashed more than half a billion dollars from aged care in the 1996 budget, and that is at the heart of the problem. Half a billion dollars has been taken from the aged care budget. In order to make up this deficiency and to find the capital necessary, the Howard government has come up with this appalling user-pays system of new fees for nursing homes. This Howard government and this minister have introduced this up-front fee, the so-called accommodation bond.

In November, the extra daily fee will begin. The extra daily fee is, of course, just a tax by another name. It really rubs salt into the wounds of older people. The money goes straight to the government, and the residents get no benefit from that payment whatsoever. This minister has been steadfast in her refusal to acknowledge the facts about where the money will come from to pay this $98,000 entry fee. As the facts mount from today, she is looking more and more like King Canute in her efforts to deny the obvious.

The money for the entry fee will come from the sale of people's homes. Let us just briefly walk through the facts one more time. The majority of people in nursing homes are pensioners. Pensioners, Minister! More than 70 per cent of pensioners have only one asset: their family home. Yes, there are exemptions—I am sure the minister will talk about them—when a spouse lives in the home. But the facts are that 90 per cent of the people who need to go into a nursing home live alone before they go into that nursing home. They will have to sell their family homes. You might like to say that nobody will be forced. This is the biggest playing with words that I have ever seen. Of course it is not compulsory, Minister, but where does compulsion end and coercion begin? The nursing homes will coerce older people to sell their homes so that they pay the $98,000 in entry fees. The fact is they will have to sell their homes.

Let us not forget which people we are talking about here. This is a generation of people, unlike my generation, which has lived through the Great Depression and the Second World War. They have scrimped and saved to pay their bills to give their children—people of your and my generation—advantages that they never had. One of the major objectives of that generation, one of the major objectives of their lives, was to pay off the family home. Minister, part of the cruelty of this legislation is that you do not seem to understand the psychological impact of what you are doing to this generation of Australians. You are trashing the values of a generation. The action is arrogant and contemptuous in its failure to understand the impact it will have on older Australians and their families.

Let me share one example with you. It comes from a personal friend of mine. I will not use her name because she would not want me to. Her mother and father have just gone through a very difficult time. Her father has very severe dementia and was becoming very violent towards her mother. They had to find a nursing home bed for her father. They went to many nursing homes in the local area—I think five or six. None of the nursing homes wanted to take this man because he is violent and disruptive. But something had to be done to protect the mother. They could not find a nursing home bed. Eventually, this man had to be committed.

This family is saying to me, `Imagine having to deal with a nursing home saying, "No, we're not taking him. He's too difficult a patient. By the way, you haven't got $98,000 either."' This is because the mother is still living in the home. `"You haven't got the money. He's too difficult a patient."' That is the sort of attitude that will take place in our nursing home system as a result of the changes that start today.

I have another example. A letter came into my office from a lady who is 64 years of age. She has looked after her father, who is 90 years old, for three years. He has dementia. As she says in her letter:

Try caring for a dementia stricken person for 3 weeks and tell me you can do it forever. I am on anti depressants for the first time in my life. I no longer have a life. Why should it end at 64? I was a healthy, active, alive person—not any more.

`Don't tell me that I won't have to sell my home because I have only been looking after my father for three years, not for 5 years.' This woman is not protected by your legislation. She will have to sell her home to get her father into a nursing home because she can no longer look after him. That will be the real effect on families of this abominable piece of legislation that has been introduced.

But of course the tragedy and the farce of this legislation do not end there. We will eventually go from a system of care that guaranteed a place to people on the basis of their health needs to one where different levels of care will emerge, depending on how much people can pay. What an abomination. What an un‐Australian way of looking after people in their last years of life. It is inevitable that raising money through the entry fee system will produce a system that reflects where the money comes from. In other words, it will reflect the capacity of nursing homes to tap into the value of people's homes. Nursing homes in wealthy areas—as this article in the Daily Telegraph clearly shows—where there are high property values will be able to get the $98,000. The government has talked about getting $1.5 billion from this system through the sale of people's homes.

What about the nursing homes in poorer areas, in country towns or the poorer parts of our cities where they can only pay a smaller amount? As is made quite clear in the article in the Daily Telegraph, it is about to start; it will start today. There are places in Sydney that will charge only $30,000. Those places will, of course, end up as second‐rate nursing homes. Those that charge $98,000 will be very nice, thanks very much. We have seen from the newspapers today that nursing homes are already saying that poorer areas and lower fees will go together. We have evidence, Minister, that you are responsible. This minister will stand condemned for introducing a two‐tiered system into our nursing home care: one system for the rich and another much lesser system for the poor.

Of course it will take time for these controversial changes to work through the system. We know what that means, Minister. Over the next 12 months or so this generation of people who pay their $98,000 to get into a nursing home will not get anything for it because, unfortunately, it is the case that people do not live for a very long time in nursing homes. They will pay these huge up‐front fees and get no benefit whatsoever. The nursing homes will not be upgraded in their lifetimes. They will have sold their homes, sold the one thing that they own, and will get no benefit whatsoever in their lifetimes.

The government keeps trying to talk up a crisis in nursing home care to justify its actions. Minister, there is not a crisis yet but, sure as heck, one is coming. The way this government is going about these changes there will soon be a crisis in our nursing home system, because the other thing that has become very clear in the newspapers today is that about 15 per cent of homes have failed the certification test.

This brings in the big catch‐22 in this legislation: the test that means that if you need capital to upgrade you definitely will not be able to get it because you cannot charge an accommodation bond. While it is true that substandard homes should never be condoned, this government has shown the height of irresponsibility by being willing to wash its hands of the problems it will create. The minister was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald today saying:
It is unfortunate. Some of those homes will close because of being unable to charge accommodation bonds.
This minister is completely irresponsible because she has not allocated anything like enough money to make sure these nursing homes have the capital they need to upgrade.

I am sure she will say that the government has allocated funds. Let me tell the public: it is $10 million, which might build 2½ nursing homes. That is all. Where will the people go who have to leave the 300 nursing homes which are expected to fail the inspection? Where will the nursing home residents go?

This minister just wants to wash her hands of it. She is not going to provide the funding for the 300 nursing homes that will close as a result of her incompetent legislation. Minister, you cannot walk away from the ripple effect that this is going to have throughout the whole nursing home sector. Where will the residents from the nursing homes that are closed go? Will they stay in public hospitals?

They will not be able to stay in public hospitals. The Australian Medical Association are going to put paid to that idea. They will not stand for nursing home patients staying in public hospitals. They wanted your legislation deferred for 10 years. That is how concerned they are about what will happen to public hospitals.

Governments are elected to govern, not to shrug their shoulders and look away and say that it is up to market forces. That is what this minister is doing: leaving it to market forces; leaving it to user pays. If you have got $98,000 it will be just fine for you. You will be able to get into a nursing home, you will be fine, you will be looked after. If you have got $30,000, you might get into a second-rate nursing home. But, if you have nothing, you go to the back of the queue. That will be the result of this minister's new legislation.

Not only will they get nothing, but if they do manage to get into a nursing home they will get second‐rate care. That is an abomination to the Australian people and something that we should be totally ashamed of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to proudly mark the commencement of the government's aged care reforms. Today is the day when this government begins to rebuild Australia's nursing homes: a day that never dawned for Labor in the nearly 5,000 days that it was in government. For 5,000 days, Labor sat and watched the state of Australian nursing homes decline and deteriorate. Labor has no credibility whatsoever on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The untruths and distortions spread by the opposition and vested interests have done nothing but scare and humiliate old people, making them political footballs. This debate today is the last‐ditch effort by the shadow minister for scares to throw a bit more mud, spread a few more untruths—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable minister will refer to the member for Jagajaga by her correct title.
—The member for scares.
—On a point of order: I ask the member, who is in the wrong place, to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you. I caution the honourable member for Longman to be in his place if he wants to open his mouth, and he will still be out of order.

—The untruths and distortions spread by the opposition and vested interests have done nothing but scare and humiliate old people, turning them into political footballs. This debate today is the shadow minister's last-ditch effort to throw a bit more mud, to spread a few more untruths to disgracefully scare some more elderly and frail Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: From the very first day of this debate, all the opposition has done is play a totally divisive and negative game. That has been the sum total of the opposition's contribution to this debate on aged care. Not once have we had any acceptance of the parlous state of affairs that nursing homes were left in as a result of the funding system so badly neglected under Labor.

Not once have we had any evidence that the shadow minister has been anywhere near some of the older nursing homes, particularly in her state, where a good proportion of nursing homes are simply old houses converted for the purpose. Until today, not once had we had any acknowledgment by the shadow minister of the totally inadequate funding provided for people with dementia under the current system, and the desperate need, as she highlighted—thus highlighting Labor's failure—to develop more appropriate funding and care for dementia patients.

Not once have we had any acknowledgment that they even care about the 40 per cent of residents that share wards with four or more people, the 11 per cent of facilities that do not meet fire standards or the 15 per cent that do not meet health standards. Does the shadow minister deny these figures and the disgraceful stories behind such statistics? Her silence to date indicates such outrageous denial.

Let me explain what these statistics mean, particularly for residents' quality of life. They mean that too many buildings have serious structural deficiencies. They mean that there are hazards which jeopardise residents' safety and security. They mean an unsafe working environment for staff.

BREAK.PARA: There are many institutional buildings with dark narrow corridors with inadequate lighting. This restricts residents' mobility, further hampering their capacity to enjoy a high quality of life. There are also small narrow toilets, perhaps shared between many residents.

Some buildings have multiple storeys with no lifts, further restricting mobility. Some buildings have a sterile hospital‐like environment which, despite the best efforts of the dedicated staff and providers, are far from homelike. Too many nursing home buildings are serious firetraps. There may be no firewalls, the fire exits could be blocked or even locked. The windows might not open, or perhaps the fire exits open to enclosed courtyards, not allowing residents to escape.

There are too many people living in a room with four, six, eight or more beds. This means rows of beds sometimes less than a metre apart—bed after bed after bed. This cramped accommodation means no privacy. It means barely any room for personal belongings.

Labor's response was an abject failure. It cut funding on capital expenditure while not allowing nursing home providers to charge bonds. The shadow minister was quite wrong when she said in the House that we have provided only $10 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —A year.

—We have provided $10 million a year, that is correct, but you did not say `a year'; you just said $10 million. What Labor did in 1992-93 was allocate $45 million for nursing home capital purposes. By 1995-96, this dropped to $10.7 million—a 75 per cent reduction in capital funding. Even worse, only $2.7 million of that was for upgrading old and substandard services. The rest went to build new services.

BREAK.PARA: From such a parlous state it is no longer possible to keep placing bandaids on the problem. The wound is festering and it is getting worse. Rather than just ignore it, as Labor did, our reforms will fix it. Our reforms acknowledge that, in stark contrast to nursing home buildings, hostels generally offer a much better standard of accommodation. This is no accident.

Labor's hostel policy introduced in 1988 and supported by us meant that hostels had an income stream to significantly finance their own upgrade and refurbishment. This income stream was called entry contributions and now accommodation bonds. Accommodation bonds across both hostels and nursing homes will provide an income stream of some $130 million each year after four years. This matches well with Professor Gregory's estimation that around $125 million a year is needed to bring the nursing home buildings up to reasonable community expectations.

It is painfully obvious that the opposition had never had any intention of being a constructive player in this debate and has no understanding of the conditions of the buildings that many residents find themselves living in today. Let me take this opportunity to put some facts on the table, given the shadow minister has decided to ignore them. The reforms that we will implement today will deliver on a number of fronts. I will briefly mention just 10 of those points. Nursing home building quality will improve. People will be housed in a safe environment where they will have comfort and dignity in their most frail years.

We will have improved funding for dementia. The new funding system will deliver a substantial increase to funding for dementia—about a 30 per cent increase on average to a hostel resident with dementia. This will relieve the financial strain on dementia-specific facilities and improve access to dementia care.

Higher levels of funding will be guaranteed for providers who care for financially disadvantaged people. Under the current system, providers receive a meagre subsidy of $3.50 per day for financially disadvantaged people. Under our system that amount will more than double to $7 a day and it will go to $12 a day if the provider cares for more than 40 per cent of financially disadvantaged residents. This will provide much greater support for providers in poorer areas and those who specialise in financially disadvantaged residents.

We will also provide greater services in rural and remote areas. The special viability assistance funding was previously available only to nursing homes. This has been extended to hostels as well. Facilities in remote areas in particular tend to have higher proportions of financially disadvantaged residents and so will benefit greatly from the higher funding levels.

In addition, facilities in rural and remote areas will be targeted by the government's capital grants program which provides additional assistance to help facilitates build or upgrade. For this $40 million was announced in the 1996 budget.

Facilities can also choose to broaden the range of care they provide and be funded for. So residents will increasingly be able to stay in their own towns rather than move to get the care they need. That is very important to rural and remote areas.

There will also be comprehensive access protection for financially disadvantaged people. Much stronger and clearer protection than ever existed in the past will ensure that older Australians get access to care according to their need, not according to their means.

When the shadow minister was asked on radio in Perth this morning what the Labor Party would do if it were to lay down a policy, she said, `We would make sure people get access according to their needs, not according to their means.' That is exactly what this policy does. All nursing homes and hostels will have to set aside a proportion of places for people who cannot afford to pay a bond. Providers will receive higher subsidies for those places.

There are also new rules for the family home. For the first time, they are designed to protect spouses, dependent children, close family members and carers who received no special treatment under the system Labor had in place.

The new accreditation arrangements, which will be supervised by an independent board, will ensure that all facilities meet standards. This will mean an improved quality of care and quality of life for all residents. The facilities that are failing these basic tests are a stark reminder of Labor's neglect of the nursing home sector and its appalling report card in properly caring for our frail aged.

The new system breaks down artificial barriers between nursing homes and hostels, and funds people according to their care need, not what sort of facility they happen to be in. The reforms introduce new and stronger consumer safeguards. We launched one of those products this morning which was very well received. These changes will ensure a system of quality care sustainable for the coming decades.

It is important also to look at the needs of elderly people outside of residential care and to put the reforms into perspective. Not once have we heard any comment from the opposition on the need of the other sector of our older population. Not once have we had any acknowledgment that only seven to 10 per cent of older people rely on residential care.

These people are the forgotten people from the previous government. But, finally, we have implemented many changes to assist people to retain their independence. We have established the Conference for Older Australians. We have established a healthy senior task force to develop programs and activities for older people in the community.

In conclusion, the government's age care reform package will bring significant and lasting reform to nursing homes in a way that will make them viable and sustainable well into the future. It will ensure that frail older people will have equitable access to high standards of care and accommodation and that, as their care needs increase over time, they will not have to face the trauma of moving to another facility to get appropriate care.

This package will introduce strong protections for consumers and create incentives for providers to continue to invest in maintenance and improvements to building stock. It will ensure that access to quality care is based on care need and not on means to pay. It is based on people's need, on the clinically assessed needs by the ACATS team—not on people's capacity to pay.

These are some of the pillars upon which our reforms are built, born of consultation and a responsible public policy approach—a far cry from what we get from the opposition, which is just a series of distortions and untruths day after day. I would just like to read out some of those endorsements. Betty Johnson, Australian Pensioners and Superannuants' Federation:
Your concern for low income residents and your quick action is greatly appreciated.
Dr Keith Woollard, Australian Medical Association:

The aged care reforms. . . is one way which Australia can come to terms with the massive increase in demand for quality accommodation and care of our ageing population. Now we have a government that is willing to make a tough decision that will ultimately benefit all aged care residents by providing proprietors of these facilities no excuse not to improve standards.
Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association Ltd:

Today's introduction of the aged care reforms is the culmination of many months of consultation between the Government, service providers, consumer organisations and unions. The resultant reform package will herald change in the delivery of aged care (and we are) confident that the changes will be for the better.
Denis Jones, Australian Nursing Federation:
Mrs Moylan has made a genuine effort to consult all groups involved in the massive overhaul of nursing homes.
Ashleigh Lodge Private Nursing Home:
We support your aged care reform package and appreciate the fact that you have listened to the sector and you have actually heard what we are saying.

Political reporter, Fleur Bitcon, National Nine news coverage: The Aged Care Bill is the most important piece of legislation since the government and the Democrats combined to pass the industrial relations reform.
Senator John Woodley, the Australian Democrats aged care spokesman:

We now have an agreement which has the stamp of approval from the three main church providers of the aged care facilities. I am confident that this improved package will deliver a better standard of care for Australia's ageing population.
Finally, Mr Gary Johns, a former Labor minister, on PM :

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.
This bill is one of a package implementing the government's decision to move the migration advice industry towards voluntary self-regulation through a period of statutory self-regulation.

The measures contained in the principal bill are consistent with the government's commitment to reduce unnecessary regulation of small business. At the same time, it maintains and strengthens consumer protection for those people in the community who are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous or incompetent migration agents. The measures will also contribute to the integrity of the migration program by actively promoting an ethical and competent migration advice industry.

A review of the existing scheme for registration of migration agents was commissioned by the government in June 1996. This scheme was the first regulatory arrangement to be reviewed by the Commonwealth as a party to the competition principles agreement. The review focused on the impact the scheme has had on consumer protection and on the costs of regulation borne by business.

The review was conducted by a task force within my department and was guided by a reference group of independent experts chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, the former Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The reference group also included:
. Ms Pamela O'Neil, Chairperson of the Migration Agents Registration Board;
. Mr Ian Tonking, a Sydney barrister and consultant editor of the Australian Trade Practices Reporter ;
. Ms Cheryl Webster, a grant-in-aid worker for Careforce, the Anglican Home Mission;
. Mr John Hodges, Queensland State President of the Migration Institute of Australia and a former immigration minister; and
. Ms Pauline Matthewson, National Committee Member of the Migration Institute of Australia.

The review found that the existing scheme had achieved a measure of consumer protection. It also found that its credibility had strengthened somewhat in the time since the scheme was reviewed by the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Migration in 1995. The review found that the existing scheme had not adversely affected competition in the migration advice market, although it recognised that there was a need to improve competency standards in a way that would not affect the level of competition in the industry.

In considering the findings of the review, the government concluded that, although it would be possible for the industry to be self-regulating in the future, this was not immediately achievable for two main reasons. The first reason is the vulnerability of the consumer group. This group may have difficulties making an informed choice about the quality of the migration advice they are purchasing. There is a history of exploitation of consumers of migration advice by a number of unscrupulous and unethical migration agents.

The second reason is the fact that the migration advice industry is not yet `mature', in the sense that there is limited cooperation occurring between the three main occupational groups and the Migration Institute of Australia. These occupational groups are lawyers, agents in the private sector of the industry, and agents in the voluntary sector. At present, the Migration Institute of Australia, as an industry association, covers only 10 per cent of registered agents.

The government has decided to introduce a form of statutory self-regulation as an interim measure for two years, commencing on 21 March 1998. This bill will provide for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to appoint the Migration Institute of Australia as the Migration Agents Registration Authority. The Migration Institute of Australia is willing to take on this role and strongly supports the government's intention to maintain a professional and ethical migration advice industry.

The institute has acknowledged strengths in the areas of competency, education and ethics. However, it will require time and support to develop the infrastructure to undertake the full range of regulatory functions and to achieve coverage of the whole industry.

The legislation before the House today will provide the necessary statutory backing for this to occur. In addition to the statutory backing provided by the principal bill, I intend to enter into a formal agreement with the Migration Institute of Australia.
The agreement will spell out the details of how the institute will carry out its function as the Migration Agents Registration Authority and will include provisions in relation to:
. performance requirements;
. financial accountability;
. complaints handling and discipline processes
. referral of instances of unregistered practice and fraud to my department for investigation; and
. support to be provided by my department.

The proposed scheme will be reviewed by the government before 21 March 2000. The review will determine the extent to which the Migration Institute of Australia has developed the capacity and infrastructure to undertake the role as industry regulator in a fully self-regulating environment.

This bill retains all of the important elements of the existing scheme for registration of migration agents. For example, it will continue to be a mandatory requirement for all persons who wish to practise as migration agents, including members of the legal profession, to be registered. All applicants for registration will be required to satisfy the registration authority that they are of good character and have the necessary knowledge to give quality migration advice and assistance. As is now the case, unregistered practice will be an offence. My department will continue to rigorously investigate and pursue those who provide immigration advice without being registered.

As with the existing scheme, the bill provides for the investigation of complaints made against migration agents who act in an unprofessional or unscrupulous manner. However, it will also introduce significant improvements in the complaints handling process to address the review's finding that the existing process was expensive, slow and insufficiently responsive to consumer concerns. For example, the bill provides for the registration authority to be able to refer a complainant and the relevant agent to a mediator. The intention is to enable the parties to a dispute to negotiate a mutually acceptable outcome without having to resort to lengthy and expensive disciplinary processes.

The existing legislation allows for disciplinary action to be taken against an agent who, for example, is found to have breached the code of conduct or is found not to be a person of integrity. Such disciplinary action can take the form of a caution or the agent's registration can be suspended or cancelled. These sanctions will remain.

This bill proposes changes to the way disciplinary action against agents who are also practising lawyers will be handled. The changes will make it possible for the Migration Institute of Australia to refer disciplinary matters involving lawyer agents to the relevant professional bodies for disciplinary action. This will place the responsibility for handling malpractice within the legal profession itself, where it properly belongs.

The bill also proposes a number of new provisions aimed at strengthening consumer protection and improving the competence of agents. The present definition of `immigration assistance' does not extend to migration advice given in relation to sponsorships or nominations. This means that a person can provide assistance and advice to potential sponsors or nominators without being required to be registered as a migration agent. Both the Joint Standing Committee on Migration and the recent review conducted by my department recommended that this loophole be closed, noting that a growing number of sponsors and nominees were effectively unprotected from poor advice or unscrupulous practice.

The government also recognises that travel agents, in advising non-citizen clients of the need to have a visa for travel to and from Australia, could arguably be required to register as migration agents under the existing scheme. This bill amends the definition of `immigration assistance' in a way which will clearly exclude the limited forms of assistance provided by travel agents and interpreters. The bill, therefore, removes an area of unnecessary regulation and uncertainty for the tourism industry. The government wants to ensure that all clients of migration agents are fully protected by the legislation.

Under the current arrangements, agents operating in the voluntary sector are not required to meet the same knowledge test for registration as agents operating in the private sector. Some of these agents have fully met the knowledge test and are recognised as highly competent and ethical practitioners. However, many have not. In practice, this has led to the development of two different standards of competency in the industry, with some of the most vulnerable clients receiving a lower standard of service.

The bill addresses this inequity by requiring all agents in the voluntary sector to fully meet the knowledge test in order to qualify for registration as a migration agent. Because many agents in the voluntary sector would be unable to meet the test without further educa tion and training, the bill provides for a six‐month period of grace to enable them to qualify. In addition, my department is making funding available for the provision of training courses to enable agents in the voluntary sector to obtain the level of knowledge required for full registration.

At present, agents operating in the voluntary sector and providing their services free of charge are not required to pay a registration fee. The recent review of the existing scheme found that this arrangement resulted in agents in the private sector cross-subsidising agents in the voluntary sector. It also found that fee levels were higher as a result because the cost of processing a registration is the same in all cases.

The two charge bills included in this package reduce this cross-subsidy by ensuring that charges are imposed on voluntary sector agents. The government proposes, however, that the regulations will provide a lower rate of charge for voluntary sector agents in recognition of their lesser capacity to meet the full costs of registration.

At present, once an agent is registered, there are no incentives for them to maintain or improve their knowledge and professional competency. Clients, therefore, have no way of knowing whether an agent has made the effort to keep abreast of changes to the Migration Act and regulations. The bill contains provisions designed to improve the competency and ethical practice of all migration agents. From 21 March 1999, all agents seeking to re‐register must demonstrate that they have met criteria in relation to undertaking continuing professional development. The details of this requirement will be set out in regulations.

Agents who fail to meet this requirement will be refused re‐registration and will not be permitted to continue to practise in the industry until they reapply and meet the requirements. I am aware that this is a serious measure. It potentially affects the livelihood of some people in small business. But it is necessary both in the public interest and in the interests of consumers.

Members would appreciate that the integrity of the government's migration program can be compromised by unscrupulous and exploitative practice by migration agents. Currently, consumers have no guarantee that the agent they are paying to give them professional advice is, in fact, fully competent. If this requirement for continuing professional development has the effect of dissuading some agents from remaining in the industry because they do not wish to improve their practice, then the industry and the community would be better off without them.

Two charge bills are being introduced in tandem with this bill. Together with the provisions in the principal bill, they will provide a more flexible vehicle for setting the level of fees applying to applications for registration. After appointment as the Migration Agents Registration Authority, the Migration Institute of Australia will be authorised to collect fees on behalf of the Commonwealth. The principal bill includes an appropriation to the Migration Institute of Australia to ensure that it recovers the costs of running the new scheme.

The Renewal Charge Bill will be repealed on 21 March 1999. After that time, renewal of agents' registration will no longer be automatic. Instead, agents will be required to apply for re-registration and meet the new continuing professional development requirements. The principal bill also includes a series of transitional arrangements. These are designed to enable a seamless transition to the new scheme.

Agents who registered under the old scheme will continue to have their registration and renewal dates recognised by the new registration authority. Those who submitted their application for registration close to the expiry of the old scheme will be able to be registered by the new registration authority. In addition, unfinalised complaints and disciplinary processes will be able to be brought to completion by the new registration authority.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasise that this package of bills provides a unique opportunity for government and the industry to work together to ensure the development of a competent, reputable and ethical migration advice industry. The government believes this will be of benefit both to consumers and the broader Australian community. I commend the bill to the House. I present the relevant explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION APPLICATION CHARGE BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Ruddock, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill imposes a charge on applications for registration as a migration agent. It replaces the provisions in the Migration Agents Registration (Application) Levy Act 1992, which will be repealed. The main feature of this bill is that it provides for the actual amount of the charge payable to be set by regulation subject to an indexed charge limit. This provides the government with flexibility to set differing levels of charge depending on the circumstances of the agent. It will allow, for example, lower levels of charge to be set for agents in the voluntary sector. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
