TITLE.XREF: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TRUST LOSS AND OTHER DEDUCTIONS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Miles, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill will insert rules in the income tax law to limit the circumstances in which trusts can deduct current year and prior year losses and debt deductions. The measures generally take effect from 9 May 1995. The government announced in the 1996‐97 budget its intention to proceed with the previous government's 1995‐96 budget announcement on 9 May 1995 that trust loss rules would be introduced.
Consultation

The government has consulted widely with taxpayers and tax professionals in developing the trust loss legislation. The government announced in the 1996‐97 budget that several significant changes would be made to the previous government's draft legislation. Those changes were set out in a press release issued on budget night. Most of these changes were made in response to the concerns expressed by taxpayers and tax professionals about the previous government's proposed legislation.

BREAK.PARA: In announcing that it would go ahead with the measures, the government committed itself to consulting widely with taxpayers and tax professionals before introducing legislation into the parliament. To this end, the government's draft of the legislation was released for public comment on 10 February 1997. A large number of submissions concerning the exposure draft were received. The government has considered these submissions and has taken them into account in finalising the legislation. The government has made many modifications to the measures in response to concerns raised in the submissions.

One of the main concerns raised was about the application of the income injection test to family trusts. In response to this concern, the government announced in the 1997‐98 budget that it would relax the application of the income injection test for family trusts but the definition of `family member' would be narrowed from the 1997‐98 budget time.
Purpose of the trust loss measures

The purpose of the trust loss measures is to restrict the recoupment of losses and other deductions of trusts in order to prevent the transfer of the tax benefit of the losses. This occurs when a person who did not bear the economic effect of the loss when it was incurred by the trust obtains a benefit as a result of the trust's ability to deduct the loss.

The measures achieve this aim by examining whether there has been a change in underlying ownership or control of a trust or whether certain schemes have been entered into in order to take advantage of a trust's losses or other deductions.

The tax law already contains tests which limit the deductibility of losses incurred by companies. The proposed rules that are to apply to trusts will differ in some respects from those that apply to companies, reflecting the different characteristics of trusts.
Changes in ownership or control of a trust

The tests to be satisfied before losses are deductible will vary depending on the type of trust. Each type of trust has to satisfy certain tests relating to ownership or control of the trust in order to be able to deduct prior and current year losses and debt deductions.

For example, while fixed trusts will be subject to a continuity of ownership test, non‐family discretionary trusts will be subject to continuity of ownership, continuity of control and pattern of distributions tests. This reflects the fact that it is not possible to apply the same beneficial ownership test to discretionary trusts.

Special rules will also apply to widely held unit trusts so that ownership will be tested generally only where there are abnormal transactions. These rules will help to minimise compliance costs for these types of trusts. Also, a listed widely held unit trust can apply the same business test if it fails the continuity of ownership test.

Special tracing rules are provided to overcome difficulties in monitoring ownership of trust interests where certain entities are interposed between the loss trust and the underlying beneficiaries. A special tracing rule applies for family trusts.

These tests do not apply to family trusts, some superannuation funds, deceased estates within a reasonable administration period and unit trusts with unit holders exempt from income tax. These trusts are called excepted trusts in the legislation.
Income injection schemes

If a trust is involved in an income injection scheme to take advantage of deductions, the income injection test may prevent the trust from making full use of the deductions. Under these schemes, income is injected into trusts with losses or other deductions so that no tax is payable on the income. This test applies to all trusts other than excepted trusts. However, the test does apply to family trusts in some circumstances.
Family trusts

Family trusts (as defined) that distribute only to members of the family group will generally not be affected by the proposed measures. The income injection test will generally apply to family trusts only where income is injected from outside the family group. A trust will become a family trust for the purposes of the measures if it makes a family trust election.

A consequence of making the election is that a special tax, called family trust distribution tax, is payable where a family trust gives income or capital to persons who are not members of the family group. This tax will be levied at the top marginal rate applying to individuals, plus Medicare levy. The family trust distribution tax is an anti‐avoidance measure designed to ensure that the tax benefit of a family trust's losses cannot be transferred to non‐family members. The government hopes the tax will never need to be paid.
Drafting of the legislation

The trust loss measures have been drafted so as to fit into the new income tax law being developed as part of the tax law improvement project. The proposed rules are lengthy but necessarily so. For example, there are many different categories of trusts. One way of dealing with trust losses would be to have a few standard rules that apply to all trusts. This would result in the rules themselves being unfair in their impact.

Instead, different rules have been applied to the different categories of trusts, depending on their nature. The result is that the size of the legislation increases, but this is matched by an increase in the fairness of treatment.

The length of the provisions has also been greatly affected by the changes made by the government in response to representations from taxpayers and tax professionals. This has resulted in a trade‐off between simplicity and equity.
Revenue gain

The estimated gain to revenue from the proposed changes is $90 million in 1995‐96, $185 million in 1996‐97, $160 million in 1997‐98, $75 million in 1998‐99, $20 million in 1999‐2000 and $20 million in 2000‐2001. I commend the bill to the House. I also present the explanatory memorandum to this bill, the Family Trust Distribution Tax (Primary Liability) Bill 1997 , the Family Trust Distribution Tax (Secondary Liability) Bill 1997 and the Medicare Levy Consequential Amendment (Trust Loss) Bill 1997 , and provide copies for the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill will amend the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (the SIS Act). The SIS Act regulates the conduct of trustees of superannuation entities to ensure the prudent management of superannuation moneys.
The amendments to the SIS Act will improve the flexibility of legislative requirements relating to the nature and timing of elections by superannuation funds to be regulated under the SIS Act.

To be eligible to receive concessional taxation treatment a superannuation fund must elect to be regulated under the SIS Act. There are a number of steps involved in making an election, including lodging a standard form with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and ensuring that the fund has a trustee that is a constitutional corporation or that the sole or primary purpose of the fund is the provision of old‐age pensions.

There are strict time limits within which superannuation funds must elect to be regulated. A superannuation fund, established after the commencement of the SIS Act, must make an election to be regulated at the same time that it comes into existence or shortly after that day. A superannuation fund that was in existence prior to the commencement of the SIS Act must have elected to be regulated at the latest by the beginning of the fund's 1995‐96 year of income. A superannuation fund that was in the process of winding up after the commencement of its 1994‐95 year of income could continue to receive concessional taxation treatment without making an election to be regulated, provided they were wound up by 1 July 1995.

Failure to elect within these strict time limits or to wind up by the prescribed date may result in the members of the fund suffering losses due to the removal of taxation concessions. In addition, given that there are a number of steps involved in making an election, a fund may inadvertently lodge a defective election. In this case, a fund is ineligible for taxation concessions until after they have made a valid election. This is despite the fact that the fund may have complied with the SIS Act and regulations in all respects apart from lodging a valid election.

The commissioner previously dealt with the shortcomings in the election process by temporarily modifying the SIS Act under section 333. However, the commissioner's temporary modification power expired on 1 July 1996. This bill amends the SIS Act to permanently reinstate the administrative flexibility which was previously achieved through the temporary modification declarations.

In particular, the amendments will confer a discretion on the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to extend the time within which the lodgment of an election must be made with the commissioner and enable trustees to rectify inadvertently invalid elections. The amendments will also address restrictive timing requirements for funds established prior to the SIS regime or funds who were in the process of winding up. By overcoming these technical rigidities, the amendments will enable superannuation funds who would otherwise be deprived of concessional taxation treatment in certain years to obtain access to such treatment, without compromising the security of members' benefits or fund compliance with the retirement income standards.

It is intended that the amendments will take effect retrospectively from 1 July 1996 to ensure that the eligibility for taxation concessions for funds in the period prior to amendment is not jeopardised. I commend the bill to the House and provide the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 9th and 10th reports of the committee for 1997 entitled Development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth, WA and Redevelopment of facilities for the 51st Battalion: Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed Development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth, WA . The base is located on North West Cape, WA, 1,235 kilometres north of Perth. The base covers an area of approximately 2,550 hectares, situated on the coastal plain between Cape Range and Exmouth Gulf. The nearest township, Exmouth, is 35 kilometres north of the base.

SPEECH.PARA: RAAF Base Learmonth is a bare base, which forms part of a chain of defence airfields across northern Australia and is vital to the air defence of north‐western Australia. The primary function of the base is to serve as a deployment base for combat aircraft in a contingency. The base was developed during the early 1970s and 1980s, and no further development or major maintenance work has occurred since.
The proposal examined by the committee involved the construction of:
. explosive ordnance loading aprons for fighter, strike and maritime patrol aircraft—one apron will double as an explosive ordnance apron for transport aircraft;
. alert facilities for fighter aircraft;
. operational and technical support facilities;
. ordnance preparation facilities;
. a central emergency power station;
. rehabilitation of existing airfield pavements;
. airfield lighting equipment; and
. airfield lighting, engineering services and civil works.
The estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed work was $69 million. The committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

After inspecting the base and conducting a public hearing at Exmouth, at which senior RAAF officers gave evidence, the committee concluded that there is a need for operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth to be upgraded to bring them into line with requirements designed to enhance its capabilities for the deployment of fighter, strike and maritime aircraft in a safe and flexible manner.

The proposal attracted interest from local government authorities who raised a number of issues relating to the use of the main runway for regular public transport aircraft as well as the siting of a number of facilities within the civil aviation area.

The downgrading of the runway's pavement classification number by Defence was a matter of concern, and the committee has recommended that Defence should enter into further discussions with the Shire of Exmouth about the practicalities of upgrading the pavement classification number of the runway. The project was the subject of an environmental impact assessment, and the report mentions a number of safeguards and precautions to be adopted during and after construction of the project.

The second report I tabled covers the proposed Redevelopment of facilities for the 51st Battalion: Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. By way of background, I should mention that this army unit, with its headquarters in Cairns, is a general reserve regional force surveillance unit.

The role of the unit is to conduct reconnaissance and surveillance operations in the Cape York Peninsula, the gulf country and Torres Strait. Elements of the unit are widely dispersed over more than 20 locations throughout its area of operation, which covers 640,000 square kilometres. During any move towards conflict, FNQR would be a vital element of the first three layers of land defence. The unit's observation posts or reconnaissance patrols would be a vital source of initial strategic information which would provide early warning of any changing situation.
Once other military forces are in place, the unit would operate in a zone well forward of any protected vital asset in Far North Queensland to provide a surveillance screen.

Before addressing the specifics of the proposed work, the committee sought to establish if the unit has an assured future following the restructuring of the army. The committee was advised that this unit, the Pilbara Regiment and Norforce—all regional force surveillance units—have an assured future.

The committee also sought to establish if the recruitment of reservists can be sustained. Again, Defence advised that a fundamental principle of recruitment is to recruit people from local communities who have specific knowledge and understanding of their areas and use this to support the surveillance capability. The history of the unit has been characterised by strong representation of members of local communities. At present, 40 per cent—200 members—of the unit are indigenous. It was also pointed out that the unit is currently manned to its full establishment. This is a good indication of the effectiveness of recruitment campaigns and a strong indicator of the support for the unit in Far North Queensland.

The proposal involves the provision of facilities which will enhance the unit's ability to meet its operational commitments and will involve the redevelopment of some existing facilities and the provision of new facilities. This work will address current deficiencies such as non‐functionality, size, non‐compliance with building and occupational health and safety standards and location. The proposal involves work at 22 locations.

The committee concluded that based on the evidence the general lack of modern storage facilities and poor working conditions at headquarters, company headquarters and patrol locations are having an adverse impact on the ability of the unit to undertake assigned tasks. The proposed work encompasses:
. construction of a new facility on the Queerah Meatworks site in Cairns for the Regimental Headquarters, Administration Company, Alpha Company and 134 Regional Cadet Unit;
. new company facilities at Weipa;
. new platoon facilities at Atherton and Normanton;
. upgrading of existing platoon facilities at Innisfail and Bamaga;
. upgrading of the camp on Horn Island;
. upgrading of existing facilities at Normanby Street and the construction of new facilities at the naval fuel installation site on Thursday Island; and

. provision of secure storage for vehicles, boats and associated equipment at 14 patrol locations at Cooktown, Coen, Kowanyama, Aurukun, Pormpuraaw, Lockhart River, Cloncurry, Burketown, Mornington Island, Badu Island, Boigu Island, Yam Island, Darnley Island and York Island.

BREAK.PARA: The estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed work is $22.5 million. The committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The committee sought to establish if there will be opportunities for the local construction industry to be involved in the project. The committee was advised that elements of the project will be packaged to maximise opportunities for involvement by locally based companies. Normal tendering processes will be followed.I commend both reports to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making the point earlier that the pastoralists of Grey have been intimidated and provoked by the legal advocates of native title; advocates who are not usually Aboriginal, are usually from Adelaide or Sydney and who have no interest in the productive use of pastoral land.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the bitter words of the Democrat senators in the other place, I am proud to include myself amongst the occupation of those people from the land. The pastoralists have been held to ransom. The legislation before us should clarify their position and protect their right to continue to make the soil of this land productive. There is no doubt that the new act and the changes go some way towards that.

The miners of Grey have been caught in the inadequacies of the Native Title Act. The larger exploration and development companies have been warned off vast tracts of my electorate and millions of dollars worth of opportunity has disappeared. Perhaps the worst treatment has been meted out to the opal miners of Grey. These men and women and the communities they live in—places like Andamooka, Coober Pedy, Marla and Mintabie—have seen their means of earning a living frozen while the native title process creaks through its many stages.

The South Australian authorities are unable to register a precious stones claim since the Wik High Court decision on Lambina pastoral lease. It has generated such frustration that there has been talk of violence and shootings. I do not say these things lightly. They are a reminder of the frustration and the real dollar and cents cost of native title to people of modest means and the families and communities of my region.

I spent much of the past 18 months putting forward the demands of the miners to the government. They have been put, I must say, civilly and reasonably, but they are, nevertheless, demands. I believe that with the passage of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 we will see a genuine improvement in the situation in the far north of my electorate.

I understand that the same stance taken by the Commonwealth on the opal fields of New South Wales has been taken by the Commonwealth on this issue. This legislation should allow for the resolution of that frustration to the benefit of those people in my electorate.

I come to the state of Aboriginal Australia. It would be absolutely wrong to suggest the reforms at hand are in some way a zero sum gain trade‐off between Aborigines and other Australians as if improving the lot of farmers and miners is only made possible by the disadvantage of Aborigines. After all, more than one in 20 of my constituents is Aboriginal, compared with the electorate of the member for Banks (Mr Melham). I understand only one in 250 of his constituents is Aboriginal.

I was able to visit the communities of Oak Valley, Ceduna and the Buttlingarra community at Whyalla not two weeks ago, in the company of the admirable senator the Hon. John Herron, Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Those constituents of mine do not want the feelgood romanticism of native title as it is represented by the ALP: they want running water, reasonable health, English literacy and employment opportunities.

More and more, many Aboriginal people are beginning to understand the folly of welfare. They want opportunities, not handouts—an option that was clearly denied to far too many of them under the hypocritical Labor Party and an option that is attainable and is being attained under this government. As the ALP should know, mining royalty payments to Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory alone have totalled $350 million in the past 20 years.

The ALP subscribes to far too many myths about this country's past. I am reminded that three years ago I had to strongly differ with the claim of the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) during the debate on the land fund bill that the Aborigines of Central Australia were only there because they had been pushed off better land in Australia. As I told the member for Charlton at the time, the land he talked so derisively of is top cattle country.

You might think it would only be Pitjantjatjara country. People have lived on that land for many thousands of years and they do not appreciate being told that their home and their land is a wasteland and of inferior quality to any other land in the country. It is ironic that the inalienable freehold title of the Pitjantjatjara land offers, under its current administration, less land access for Aboriginal people in the way that they would like to have access than the previous pastoral leases.

I come to reconciliation. The myths of the concept of reconciliation abound in this debate—one might even describe it as a mantra for the opposition benches. I believe that the central tenet of reconciliation—the idea that there is a gaping hole in the spiritual life of this nation that can be remedied only by prolonged apologising by white Australia—is not only an insult to this nation and its people but a dead-end for Aboriginal people. It is a road to nowhere and its pursuit is undoubtedly to the disadvantage of Aboriginal people.

Until we recognise that history is just that—history—and until we ask all Australians to take responsibility for the here and now, we can never be one people and our nation will still be divided, one Australian against another, to the detriment of ourselves and our nation. In fact, over the years that I have been in this place I have sadly come to the conclusion that the ALP has a vested interest in continuing division in a rather self‐righteous way.

BREAK.PARA: I move to the alliance against reform. Perhaps the most intriguing part of this ongoing debate is the distinct difference between the submissions of those who maintain that the Native Title Act is serving this nation well and those who recognise its inadequacies.

Firstly, those who oppose the government's reforms provide no alternative solutions to the problems we confront. Let us remind ourselves: we have had over 600 claims, one of which was successful—that is, if you want to call the exchange of money for some building blocks a success. That is the situation with native title in Australia: $88.8 million spent and in effect I would say no successful native title claims in mainland Australia. If that is success, please let us think again.

Secondly, the submissions of the opposed tend to be glossy, lavish and come from individual groups from Sydney and Melbourne almost exclusively—certainly from metropolitan Australia. To be frank, I have had a gutful of the self-righteous academics and the many Christian church leaders telling me—and by implication the people I represent—what is going on in rural and regional Australia.

I have sent a standard response to such correspondence asking that they come out to my part of the world and actually see the reality of Aborigines and rural people that is threatened by the present Native Title Act. I have asked them to come and speak with Aborigines, farmers and miners. I have not had a single response to my invitation. There is none so blind as he who refuses to see.

To balance that, I must add the encouragement that I felt when I read an account by Bishop Malcolm, an Aboriginal bishop, who made the comment that if we must go down the track of reliving our history—however coloured that may be in all its descriptions—Aboriginal people will need to acknowledge the acts of violence against the white people as much as the white people will need to acknowledge the acts of violence against Aboriginal people.

On the ALP's position, I have already touched on the negligent role played by the ALP and those of the party who once sought to speak on behalf of regional and rural communities. There is no voice for the regions in the ALP caucus in this parliament, and that lack of voice is reflected in the ALP stance on these reforms.

The fact that the member for Banks has been allowed to run his ideological agenda at the expense of the people of the regions is a disgrace. Those who have not stood up to him and sought a different, less biased viewpoint should hang their heads in shame. Those metropolitan Australians who are such vociferous opponents of this bill and yet hide behind the reality that the land they own and occupy is immune from any aspect of native title or the Native Title Act are nothing but hypocrites, and their opinions should be viewed as such.

I turn now to the legislation at hand. I spent the past 18 months working closely with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) and others in coordination with Senator Minchin. I would be lying if I said that those negotiations were at all times amicable and I would be dishonest if I said that I did not have some continuing concerns.

Those concerns include the priority given by this legislation to representative bodies in the right to negotiate process. I still have doubt about the capabilities of those bodies in such a process—doubts that I am sure are shared by the member for the Northern Territory, who knows better than most the adversarial approach often taken by these bodies.

In my electorate, the Aboriginal legal rights movement holds considerable sway. Its correspondence with miners in the region is notorious, as are its draft budgets which it bills miners for before exploration licences are granted. In order to clear a tenement area, it is expected that an applicant will provide for two anthropologists, one male and one female, at $600 a day; eight traditional owners at $250 a day; an interpreter at $350 a day; a vehicle at $125 a day; fuel costs; hire of GPS equipment at $320 a week; food at $40 per person a day; travel costs; and accommodation plus a 15 per cent administration fee.

That is simply amazing, especially for a body that has received almost $5 million in taxpayer funding over the past five years. If that is the sort of attitude struck by such a powerful representative body, then I must doubt the capacity of such bodies to manage the right to negotiate process.

There are obviously significant problems with the Native Title Act as it stands. This bill will go a good way towards remedying those problems. Many of the uninformed may criticise my stance as somehow racist or naive. While it may be naive to believe that we should not divide Australia on the basis of the colour of people's skin, surely there can be no other acceptable moral choice.

In closing, I would like to speak of an incident I encountered before I was a member of this House. I was out in the Pitjantjatjara land with the now Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) whose interest in Aboriginal affairs is longstanding. As a lowly candidate at the time, I was quietly listening along with many of the elders of Ernabella or Pukatja.

On my way back to the airfield, I travelled with one of the elders. After 15 or 20 minutes of silence, he quietly asked me, `Are you related to them Wakelins at Port Adelaide?' I told him I was, that my son was at the football club and that my nephews were also footballers.

In no time at all we were deep in conversation on the merits of Port Adelaide. He told me of a recent match played in Alice Springs that many of the people of Ernabella had gone to see. A centralian team was playing the Port Adelaide football team. The Ernabella people were barracking with the best, not for the almost wholly Aboriginal centralian team, but for Port Adelaide. Why? Because they shared the Ernabella football club's colours.

There was no racial divide, no bitter history, no talk of hate or despair. There were just people sharing in a common love of football. That kind of attitude must characterise our future direction for the benefit of all Australians and that attitude is reflected in the provisions of this just bill. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution from the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) to the debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 saddens me, and I will say a little about why in just a moment. We are coming in this discussion of the Wik legislation to what, hopefully, will be the culmination of what has been in modern times a 30-year attempt to grant to Australia's Aboriginal people the dignity of ownership of the land and the right to negotiate that goes with that land.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mabo decision of the High Court, subsequently further clarified by the Wik decision of the High Court, has made it very clear that there is only one way that this final stage can go. I think that was eminently well summed up by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in his contribution in this debate the other day when he said:

The government must come to understand that native title rights are a reality and that they are here to stay. They have been recognised by the High Court as fundamental legal property rights and are entitled to the same respect and protection as the property rights of non-indigenous Australians.

I think that is at the heart of the debate over this bill and that is why Labor wants to make substantial changes to the bill. We believe that this bill contains several measures which are a last-ditch attempt, either by subterfuge or quite openly, to extinguish native title as it has been decreed by the High Court. That being the case, we cannot accept it.

The member for Grey and others before him have said that the government and the nation should be focusing their efforts on eradicating the dreadful inequality in the treatment of Aboriginal people in Australia, particularly those living outside mainstream areas, and of non-indigenous people in relation to schools, health facilities, roads, transport and all the other things that go with our life and government investment in our life. I agree with that, but the point that I make is that we need to move on from this point about the ownership of the land and the right to negotiate. Back when the Hawke government was first elected it was called the power of veto and back when Whitlam tried to tackle it it was simply called land rights.

BREAK.PARA: The principles of the decision of the High Court have been opposed by the coalition at every step since Gough Whitlam tried to give it effect in 1972. Even now when the High Court has given up on the politicians and has responded in two decisions clarifying that there is a land right and that, provided certain conditions are met, that land right stands, we have this last‐ditch attempt to extinguish native title as it has been granted by the High Court.

Can I relate two or three instances in my experience as the member for Burke which have fortified my opinions and judgments on this issue. In 1986, not long after I was elected to parliament, I travelled as part of a delegation to Kakadu and witnessed the start of what was supposed to be a grand new era: the approval of the uranium mine and the package of dollar compensation that went with it. Everybody at the time believed that that money would produce opportunities in one form or other.

I went back to Kakadu last year, 10 years after the event, to look at other issues related to the expansion of mining. I found that, $20 million down the road, alcoholism and Aboriginal illiteracy were worse. We did not even have an Aboriginal school teacher for grade 6 kids, for heaven's sake! We did not have a hostel where kids coming in from outlying districts, sometimes travelling for anything up to two hours across the bush to school, could stay in the town. It became very clear to me that this is not about money.

I have to commend, in particular, the Australian mining industry. For the first year or so of our time in opposition I had the portfolio of resources and energy and I had a lot to do with the mining companies, including quite active participation in the negotiation of the solution at Century Zinc in Queensland. The Australian mining industry has impressed me; they too know that this is not about dollars. They know it is about negotiating: negotiating jobs, negotiating a role, negotiating dignity in partnership with the mining ventures.

We have seen a lot of examples of this falling into place. I observe, for instance, the recent publication from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the June quarter 1997 entitled Actual and Expected Private Mineral Exploration. It starts off by saying that the upward trend in exploration expenditure since the June quarter 1993 continued in the June quarter 1997. Here is physical evidence from the ABS that all these claims that native title is scaring away miners are just that—junk claims. The evidence from ABS is that it has been a consistent upward trend from the day the act came in. I think it ought to be exposed for that. What is at the heart of this is that 30‐year resistance to the concept of ownership of the land for these people. That was the first experience that I wanted to relate to you—the visit to Kakadu. The other was much closer to my home base at Kyneton.

In the bicentennial year of 1988 the then Shire of Metcalfe, a small rural council, which was amalgamated but does not exist any more, as its contribution to the bicentennial year commissioned a woman—I apologise to the House, I forget her name—to do a history of the Metcalfe Shire. This area is about 100 kilometres north of Melbourne. It is just south of Bendigo for those who wonder where it might be.

That history, when it was tabled and presented, shocked me. I had expected the normal thing you get in a shire history: these are the people who settled here first; this is who became the mayor; this is how the mayor's family have carried on right down through the last 100 years—all the wonderful stuff that we have with a history that starts in 1850. But this woman went right back and she gave a deploringly vivid account of the systematic poisoning, hunting and driving out of the Aboriginal community that existed in quite large numbers in central Victoria prior to the 1840s. I read that.

A couple of weeks later I was at one of the annual art displays held in the Macedon Ranges, which is in my electorate. It is quite a large annual display and gets a very big turnout. With this in my mind, I was giving an opening speech. I had looked at all the exhibits and I noticed not one painting or photograph that in any way tried to depict anything prior to 1850. In the following year, I was very pleased to see that a couple of artists had had a go at trying to represent what might have been happening in our area.

Near Lancefield we have a hole in the ground—a quarry that was used by our indigenous people, about 30,000 years ago it is estimated, for quarrying and making implements for cooking and hunting. That stone has been found in Indonesia and has been traded in other places in the world. We have no idea how it got there, but we know that this is one of three quarries in the world that have this history and it is obviously very significant.

I guess what I am saying is that it came as a shock to me to be confronted with the reality of what had happened, and we have to recognise this. We have to amend this legislation and once and for all recognise what the High Court has said. The High Court is right. Of course it is right. We should recognise what is right, put it in place, close down the issue and move on and do the things we all should be doing.

I will pick up on a comment the member for Grey made before when he deplored the fact that regional MPs within the Labor caucus were not expressing a different view from the view of the member for Banks (Mr Melham), Labor's spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, and we were not straightening him out. Let me say, as one of Labor's regional members—and there are not many of us left, I admit, after the last election; there are only two or three of us who actually survived, but I am one of them—

TALK.START.PARA: —And proud of it.

—Absolutely proud of it. I do not see my role as knocking over the member for Banks; I see my role as using his extraordinary understanding of this—and I want to come back to this—and the extraordinary understanding of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) of this to work my way through the issues for my people in regional Victoria and elsewhere. I have found that I can get up at a Rotary club or RSL club anywhere in regional Australia and explain Mabo, explain Wik, explain land rights and get not only what I call a positive response but also what we know in this place as a ripper response, because it is the first time these people have heard the other side of the story. I blame the coalition for that. It is the first time they are hearing the other side of the story. When they hear it they can relate to it and they can understand it.

BREAK.PARA: As shadow minister for primary industries, I want to say a couple of things in the time left available to me about farming, this whole process in this House and my attitude to the bill as it relates to the comments of the National Farmers Federation. One of the things that has absolutely disappointed me in this last 12 months is that John Howard, the Prime Minister, made the big statement in April, `I will have this bill in the House before Easter.' Do you all remember that? `We are going to get this through quickly. We are going to get it off the table.' Six months later it has finally arrived and it has been juiced up for another purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many ministers later?

—Several ministers later, too. It has been juiced up for another purpose. It is going to be used as an election platform: Labor versus the coalition; Labor is trying to close down country Australia; Labor is trying to give these Aboriginal people these land rights. That is what is going on here now.

BREAK.PARA: We went to the Prime Minister in November last year, and we made the point that Gareth Evans—I hope he is not listening to this—who I would say is probably the smartest legal brain in this House by a long way, and Daryl Melham, a former public defender in New South Wales who knows his law, have gone right through this whole Native Title Act 1993, and they know exactly what the High Court meant. They know exactly what the provisions mean. That was on offer to John Howard. The offer was made by Labor. We are prepared to sit down and take you through the intricacies and produce a bill for the parliament that will amend the Native Title Act and provide all the players with the certainty they are looking for.

The Prime Minister was not interested. So don't anybody talk about bipartisanship on the part of Labor. The offer was made and he was not interested, because he knew that any decent bipartisan settlement would not satisfy the National Party. He is absolutely right about that. So we were never in a position where we could get legislation through on Wik that satisfied the National Party and met the needs of the two major parties. I will challenge John Howard right now to defy or deny a single word that I have just said. Mr Beazley put that offer on the table. It could have all been over and done with by now. He could have actually met his objective of having this bill in here last Easter, but that is not the way it has gone.

In respect of the areas relating to pastoral leases, let me say again that I agree—I think Kim Beazley summarised our position very well—with what he had to say in his opening response to the Prime Minister's tabling document. It is true, in our view, that the measures which moved towards redefining what is meant by a `lease' and redefining what is meant by `farming activities' represent a massive overreach of what was defined by the leases when they were issued by the state governments and what is meant by a `grazing lease'. To expand that definition so that it covers a whole lot of things that were not intended when the lease was issued is, in fact, a granting of a new lease which expands the nature of the title and therefore extinguishes the rights of the Aboriginal people who would otherwise qualify. I keep making that point. That is an overreach we cannot support.

To use the tax act definition of farming for what essentially is a grazing lease, again, is a massive overreach and it does represent a clear curtailment of the common law rights of indigenous people. All it will do is finish up in the High Court. What is the point of our bringing a bill through this House, even if Labor went along with it, knowing very well that it would not stand up before the High Court and that we would be right back into that 10‐year process of uncertainty? That is why we are moving our amendments. We understand what will stack up. I go back to that fundamental statement that Mr Beazley made:

The government must come to understand that native title rights are a reality and that they are here to stay. They have been recognised by the High Court as fundamental legal property rights and are entitled to the same respect and protection as the property rights of non‐indigenous Australians.
In my view, that simple two‐sentence paragraph sums up this whole debate. It is that fact that the coalition have refused to accept for 30 years. I ask them to put an end to it tonight.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I wish to draw to the attention of the members of the House, in particular the member for Burke, standing order No. 80, which says:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Member may refer to any other Member by name, but only by the name of the electoral division he or she represents.

It is a very unambiguous standing order. I ask all members to comply with it. I did not interrupt the member's speech because he was not using the names of members in an inflammatory or antagonistic way. However, that is not an excuse. I just did not want to interrupt his speech. But, if any other members do not refer to members by their division, I shall interrupt them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to have an opportunity to speak on this very important legislation, the Native Title Amendment Bill , which the government has introduced in order that it may deliver on a commitment it made to the Australian people, both indigenous and non-indigenous, during the election and, of course, that it may also deal with some very important problems that have to be resolved following the unsatisfactory legislation introduced by the Keating government in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation that the government has introduced has a number of important objectives. First of all, it will reduce uncertainty. I was interested to hear the speech of the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), which I regret was a grave misrepresentation of this bill. It was an opportunist speech designed to cause people concern and to inflame those in the community who do not have a full knowledge of all the details. The facts will catch up with the member as the debate ensues. There is great uncertainty, and this legislation is designed to address that. It is also designed to improve the workability of the native title process and to find a balance in the interests of all the parties. I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and Senator Minchin, his parliamentary secretary, members of the government committee and others who have worked very hard to bring all the parties together in this very complex issue in order to find a balance in the interests of all the parties—something that will benefit Australia in the future.

Contrary to what the member for Burke was quite wrongly representing, this legislation is designed to maintain respect under the law for native title as determined by the High Court. If we study the words of the member for Burke in his contribution just a few moments ago, the conclusion would have to be made, if we were not aware of what the bill intends to do, that it was going to take away the native title rights and abolish the Mabo common law judgment. That is absolutely untrue.

I want to say from the outset that the government has reiterated and confirms in this legislation, if you study it closely, that it is committed to respecting the native title rights of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, as this parliament should. That is an absolute commitment and this legislation is designed to deliver that.

The government takes the view that the common law judgment of the High Court in Mabo, delivered some five years ago now, was a very important day for indigenous Australians and was recognition at last of the struggle of Eddie Mabo's family to have recognition of their common law rights in respect of the Mabo lands. The coalition government does not in any shape or form intend to be associated with the words of the member for Burke or to allow him to get away with the misrepresentation that this legislation is designed to destroy that judgment. It is quite the reverse.

I would like to record that I have a special interest in this issue not only as a member of the parliament but also as the Chair of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I am very proud to be the chair and to try to advance the interests of indigenous people and also to help bring about a better understanding of this great country between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

I want to mention that my family does have a very small number of shares in mining companies in Australia. I have disclosed those, of course, under the requirements of members' interests. I felt that I should mention that I have them because, obviously, part of this debate involves the activities of exploration and mining in Australia. Whilst my shares are very minute, nevertheless I felt it was my duty to just mention that I have that interest because mining and exploration are part of Australia's economic activity and are very important to its future. I am very concerned to ensure that Australia does have a vibrant, modern mining industry to go into the next millennium.

I also want to mention that I have seen the operation of the Keating Native Title Act 1993 in my own electorate of Indi. Members would know of the claim that is referred to throughout Australia now as the Yorta Yorta claim. It covers a substantial part of my electorate in north-east Victoria—not only a large mass of land in north-east Victoria but also the rivers and streams, and one of them is the great river, the Murray River. So you can imagine how much interest has been engendered in the constituency I represent and in my own mind about the workings of the Keating Native Title Act and how it has impacted on the lives and the communities of the indigenous people in my electorate.

Based on the Yorta Yorta's view of what the Mabo decision means, the processes of the Federal Court, the Native Title Tribunal and the registrars that were set out in the 1993 Keating legislation—which this bill amends—have defied, if you like, the best efforts of everybody to bring everybody together. The conciliation and consultative process failed. I think it is fair for me to say that the judge presiding in those areas finished up saying that it was absolutely impossible to bring the parties together because of the uncertainties of the legislation and the competing claims. As a result of that, regretfully, that case is now before the Federal Court and there are various estimates on the duration of that case, but it is estimated in some legal quarters that it will take five years to determine.

So for members of the opposition who spawned the 1993 legislation—and we had the member for Burke representing them a moment ago—to tell this House and the community that the native title legislation they brought in is good legislation and is working well in the interests of all indigenous people is quite absurd. I just wish the truth would come out and people would come down and analyse the Yorta Yorta issue to see how it is operating.

There are hundreds of claims now across Australia. More than 70 per cent of Australia's land mass is subject to a potential claim. Sadly for the indigenous people, I think only one claim has been settled in the five years the Keating legislation has been in operation.

As chair of the committee and as an Australian, I express my alarm at the damage that that inadequate, unsatisfactory legislation is causing our Australian indigenous people. It has heightened their expectation in some quarters. It has led to these massive, frightening legal sagas. These cases are just rolling on and on and on for years and years at huge cost. Regretfully, in some areas of our community, this has caused division between Australians—indigenous and non-indigenous—because some people, rightly or wrongly, have felt threatened by applications for native title, and the Yorta Yorta claim is no exception.

People from various backgrounds and communities have felt antagonism, and some disrespect has been developing between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians as a result of the way in which the 1993 Labor Party legislation has failed Australians. It has let them down.

I feel very strongly about that because, let us face it, it is hard enough for indigenous people. They face great disadvantages in our country, and all of us care very much about how we can resolve their problems, help them and bring all Australians together. It is our duty—as legislators who are honoured to be in the parliament now and who will be honoured to come here in the future—to do that. It really makes me angry to think that the disadvantages and difficulties of our indigenous people have been heightened by the failure of the Keating legislation.

For any member of the Labor Party to stand up and belittle the Prime Minister's efforts to resolve those difficulties, to put obstacles in his way and to misrepresent his work is shameful. I believe that what they are doing is capitalising on the political heat that has generated from such irresponsible statements, and it is not in the interests of indigenous people, non-indigenous people or Australia for them to get away with it. This legislation is an opportunity for people to be non-party political and to work together to resolve the mess that the Labor Party created in bringing in legislation which it said would do certain things but has not.

For example, the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in his own preamble to the 1993 legislation, declared that pastoral leases would extinguish common law native title. As a result, many people accepted that, came together and agreed to compromise. In some sense, they supported the 1993 legislation. As it has transpired, that statement about the question of extinguishment by pastoral lease is under a legal cloud and it needs to be addressed to give certainty.

No caring Australian could argue against that principle. It needs to be addressed openly, transparently and in a positive way to remove uncertainty. What do we find? We find the opposition—responsible for the legal problem and the mess that they have put on the shoulders of indigenous and non-indigenous Australians—trying to capitalise as politicians by continuing to divide and confuse. I think that is shameful.

The next point I want to make is that, if you study the systems of land tenure in Australia since white settlement, you will see that there has always been a need for people in the public interest to compromise so that when you have legislation like this, which attempts to settle the differences between competing interests and parties, you should balance it against the historical performance of land tenure systems in Australia. When the freehold systems were developed—first of all, the common law‐general law titles of Australia and then followed by the Torrens system of title giving indefeatable titles—there were always qualifications about the rights of the Crown. It was always stated that the Crown would be paramount in certain respects.

After Federation, the Australian constitution provided that the taking of people's property by the Commonwealth had to be accompanied by adequate compensation and could not be taken unless there was adequate compensation. But the right to take property has been set out quite clearly in the constitution since Federation. All the states also have power to take property from property owners. In some cases, the states do not have to pay adequate compensation, although most of the state parliaments have passed legislation acknowledging that adequate compensation should be paid.

But take water, for example, which is one of the issues involved in the Yorta Yorta claim. The rights of Australian freeholders to water have been severely curtailed by the parliaments. It is important that water be managed properly in the public interest because it is a finite resource. In fact, in Victoria, my state, 50 per cent of our water resource is already consumed by the existing residents, and commercial and farming activities in that state. So it is a very precious commodity.

Years ago, Alfred Deakin in Victoria was the pioneer of water legislation which eventually led to the Victorian parliament actually confiscating—might I say without compensation at all—the water rights of freehold people in Australia. Ground water, underwater water reserves, and water in water courses, rivers, creeks and the like now belong to the Crown. Previously, some title owners would have had some claim to them.

Similarly with minerals: the history of land tenure systems in Australia has acknowledged that it is in the public interest that the elected parliaments, state and federal, have control over those mineral resources that are below the surface in this country. So it is that freehold owners of land in this country do not have the right to prevent exploration or to stop mining. They have certain inputs into the process which are set out in state acts of parliament dealing with access, compensation, disturbance of soil and perhaps royalties in some cases. But the minerals are owned by the Crown, not by the individual freeholders.

I make these comments simply to put in context the Labor Party attack on this legislation, which is designed to do things that are absolutely urgent and which does not take away the common law rights of indigenous people as set out in the High Court judgment. Nevertheless, the indigenous people should be judged in the light of the fact that all other property owners in Australia since white settlement have had to give up some of their rights—under their freehold rights or otherwise—because public policy has determined it appropriate that the management of resources be vested in the Crown in certain ways.

I feel it is important to point that out because it does diminish the worth of the contributions made by Labor Party members who are trying to argue that this legislation does awful things. It does not at all. It reduces uncertainty, which has to be done because we cannot go on the way we are due to the failure of the 1993 legislation of the Labor government. It improves the workability of the process of determining whether native title exists or not. And that has to be done to help bring people together, to stop confrontation. It finds a balance, using wisdom, insight and judgment—but a correct judgment—amongst the interests of all of the parties designed to bring them together.

Finally, and most importantly, it maintains respect for native title as determined by the High Court in the Mabo decision. It does not extinguish those rights. Furthermore, at the end of the period under the legislation when the statutory framework for dealing with these claims expires, it preserves the common law rights of people to make claims for native title under the judgment of the Mabo decision of the High Court. That has to be recognised as being a very responsible approach being taken by the government.

I would also like to mention—for those people who are attempting to show that indigenous people are being stripped of their rights—that the Aboriginal people in Australia have already been provided through a system of freehold, leasehold or crown land with some 15.3 per cent of the land surface of Australia. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people represent some two per cent of Australia's total population. They have already a 15.3 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have too much already, have they?

—No, I did not say that. It is interesting to hear the interjection from the member for Brisbane. Do you see the divisive nature of the interjection? I do not say that at all. I have just spent a number of minutes explaining that this legislation preserves the right of indigenous people to apply for further land under the Mabo judgment. I have just pointed out that this legislation preserves that. But I am also pointing out, in answer to some of the propaganda from the Labor Party, that indigenous people in Australia already have 15.3 per cent of the land. I welcome the opportunity for them to make further claims under the Mabo common law judgment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the contribution of the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) was short in a number of areas but most notably in any consideration of social justice. I am sorry he ran out of time because I would have liked him to elaborate on the point he was making about the percentage of population to the percentage of area of land. He might like to extrapolate that and tell us what inference he was drawing in that contribution. But, sadly, time ran out for him. Unfortunately, time for members of the opposition in this debate is going to be even more curtailed. Because there are so many members of the opposition who want to speak on this legislation, we have been asked to cut our contributions roughly in half. I will endeavour to cover the key issues of concern in the time available.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill, the High Court decision on Wik, the High Court decision on Mabo and the earlier native title legislation has not been conducted in some policy vacuum, social vacuum or social equity vacuum. It has not been con ducted in terms of the legalese of land ownership; it has been conducted against a background of social inequality and prejudice that is unparalleled in the history of the Australian people.

It would be foolish to address this issue without acknowledging some of those events. There has been a systematic discrimination against Aboriginal and Islander people for the last 200 years which cannot be compared to the problems beset by any other group in this community. Yes, there are many groups in the community, and individuals particularly, who have a disadvantage from one perspective or another, but there is no other group which has been systematically discriminated against by the state over many years. This is not a political point; it happens to have been a fact of life for all political persuasions over the course of democratic governments in this century and, prior to that, colonial government. There has been systematic discrimination.

The horrific thing is how recent that systematic discrimination has continued. In the state of Queensland, for example, it has only been in the last 20 to 24 years that Aboriginal and Islander people have been allowed to work for a wage and keep it. Until the mid-1970s, Aboriginal and Islander people who worked side by side with anyone else in a full award paying job were not allowed to get an award wage. The state government, through legislation, took the money from them and put it into an account—not their account; a state Treasury run account. To this day, the millions of dollars that were taken from those people have never been returned to them—some are still alive—or their families.

That systematic deprivation of economic liberty was not imposed upon any other individuals in our society at any time. But, in the state of Queensland, Aboriginal and Islander people were denied the opportunity to ever get any economic independence in our society. It is a matter of some shame that successive Queensland governments have been unable to properly address the question of the wages that were stolen by law, but nonetheless stolen, from those people.

BREAK.PARA: No other group has been systematically rounded up and located in reserves. In a former life when I was an official in the Queensland Teachers Union, I had the opportunity to visit the schools and to see the conditions of life of people living in the Gulf, around the Cape and on the islands. The conditions which those people were forced to live in were a disgrace.

What was even more of a disgrace was the way the state government at that time—in about 1981 and 1982—took some glee out of the hardship that those people suffered. I can remember standing on the jetty on Thursday Island watching the supply boat that was owned by the state government, the Melbidir, come into port on Thursday Island while they ferried the young girls—only the young girls—from the island out to the boat to be entertainment for the public servants on that ship. I stood there on that jetty and watched in absolute disbelief. This is not South Africa. This is not the United States 200 years ago. This is Queensland not even 20 years ago.

No group in our community has been so systematically stripped of their dignity or systematically murdered, as has been the case with Aboriginals and Islanders. I am advised that the last time someone was shot with no charges being laid against the person who fired the gun that killed the person who was doing no harm—if we exclude things such as deaths in custody—was in the early 1950s in the Northern Territory.

No other group in our community has had their children stolen from them. Every member of this House has read, or at least had the opportunity to read, the excellent report on the stolen generation. No group in our society has suffered the systematic attack on the very fabric of their life—their family, their loved ones and the people closest to them—other than the Aboriginal and Islander people.

The shame of it is that it was done by authority of the state. That is the background in which this debate has occurred. It is patent nonsense for people like the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) to stand here and tell us that we should treat everyone the same, to draw a line in the sand and pretend that yesterday we were all equal and therefore everyone should be treated equally tomorrow. It is peddled either by people who are ignorant or by people who are racist. It seems to me that they are the only two options you have in analysing that.

Let me now quickly turn to some of the provisions that are before us, having made some comments about the background. There has been a lot of debate in the community and some in this House about the rights of people with land ownership and how the wishes of Aboriginal and Islander people in respect of the Wik High Court decision will somehow affect people's ownership rights. I have spoken to a lot of people in my electorate and around Brisbane about this. There is a great deal of surprise when you tell people that the pastoralists we are talking about do not actually own the land. They have never bought it. They do not own it today. They have never owned it at any time in their life. Their parents did not own it. No-one has owned it. It has been leased; it has been rented.

There is a perception in the community, which some in this debate are happy to continue to foster, that these people are pastoralists—but they may be third, fourth or fifth generation pastoralists—and that that land is theirs because they have paid for it, they have bought it and they have a freehold in the same way that people in my electorate in Brisbane know and feel they own the house that they bought and are living in. That is not the case, but the view that the indigenous people have set out in relation to freehold land should be noted for the record. I am referring to a document put out in June this year by ATSIC on issues for indigenous peoples. In this document they said:
. . . it is accepted that private freehold grants and residential leases extinguish native title . . .

That is plain enough. The Aboriginal and Islander people are not contesting that. It is about time a bit of honesty entered this debate and people understood that we are not talking about freehold. In this particular area, we are talking about pastoral leases and leasehold land.
What have the indigenous groups said about that? The document that was prepared in relation to the Wik decision earlier this year says this about pastoral leases:

If there is a need to clarify the ability of pastoralists to carry out development activities under their leases, the NIWG policy position is that it is prepared to support appropriate legislative confirmation of the existing legal rights of pastoralists under their leases.
The NIWG is the National Indigenous Working Group.

What is wrong with that? They are saying that they are quite happy to legislate and put into the law an acknowledgment that the rights people have under their leases will be enshrined in the statutes. That seems to me to be quite reasonable. But the problem with it is that a lot of those people who have got leases have done things beyond the rights of their lease. Pastoralists have gone beyond their legal rights. They have rented the property—in very many cases for not much payment—and, having done that for many years and enjoyed the land as if it was theirs in freehold, they now want you to believe they should have the rights of freehold.

They have been caught out by the Wik decision. Their past practices of exceeding their rights as tenants—their past practice of doing more than their lease allows them to do—have now been brought into question. The High Court has said and the Aboriginal and Islander community have said that they are happy to support a view wherein those rights extinguish native title rights to the extent of any inconsistency, but that does not mean that Aboriginal and Islander people have no rights at all on that land, because leasehold rights are not the same as freehold. They do not afford unfettered opportunity to do what you like with the property. It is a lease.

There are people who are leaseholders who want to turn their lease rights into ownership rights and they want to do that at the expense of Aboriginal and Islander people. They want to do it at the expense of common law rights that those Aboriginal and Islander people have as determined by the High Court. That is fundamentally wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you said in 1993 that native title was extinguished by pastoral lease.

—Let me go to the comments of your Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer): `Bucket loads of extinguishment in the 10‐point plan.' They were the Deputy Prime Minister's words. That is what your own Deputy Prime Minister describes this as being. People who have freehold land are entitled to the rights of freehold land. People who have leasehold land are entitled to a different set of rights. The Wik decision made it plain that, where the two rights clash, the pastoralist lease rights prevail, and the Aboriginal and Islander community have accepted that.

BREAK.PARA: But that is not good enough for the conservatives in this parliament. That is not good enough for people like the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman). The member for Indi wants to strip these people of those rights. He wants to say to someone who is a leaseholder, `We will give you the same sorts of rights as if you owned it.' In fact, they are going one better because, if you happen to be lucky enough to have a lease which is next to vacant crown land, this legislation is actually going to say that you can extend into that vacant crown land. Aboriginal and Islander claims over vacant crown land that is adjacent to the lease are going to be wiped out. Under this arrangement, the leaseholders are being given more power than if they owned the land. They are actually now going to have a claim over adjacent vacant land by wiping out the rights of indigenous people over that vacant crown land. That is a disgrace.

I have used up the time that I was asked to restrict myself to, but there are a couple of points I want to make very quickly. The exposure in the last few days of the Law Reform Commission's views on this legislation should ring alarm bells in the minds of everyone in the government, even if they do not like what the High Court has said. Even if they want to extinguish the Aboriginal and Islander title, they should understand the folly of what they are embarking on.

There will be one winner out of this legislation going through the parliament and that will be the lawyers. This is their bonanza. Do not worry about the year 2000 fund; the year 2000 fund will pale into insignificance. Over the course of the next few years, this will be the lawyers' bonanza and the government will have created it because they will not heed the advice of people who have been involved in negotiations on this for some years, nor will they heed the advice of people such as the Law Reform Commission.

I quickly want to mention the tax act definition of primary production that has been thrown in here. Mr Deputy Speaker, do you know why the government has decided to define primary industries broadly under the tax act definition? It is precisely because of what I said before: the government knows that there are a lot of pastoralists out there who have breached their leases and have done things that they were not entitled to do. So to cover that, they are going to introduce a new definition. They are now going to legislate to enable those pastoralists to do whatever it is the tax act says is primary industry, even if they never had the right to do that in the past under their lease. And that is fair play—fair play against a group of indigenous people who have got a High Court decision that says otherwise!

There are two final things that I will quickly say. I listened to a comment earlier in the debate from one of the government members about how mining has been devastated as a result of the High Court decision and our earlier native title. Yesterday, the ABS figures for actual and expected private mineral exploration came out. Members on the other side were making an argument that suited their political purpose; these are the facts. I am quoting from the document released just yesterday. It says:
The upward trend in exploration expenditure since the June quarter 1993 continued to the June quarter 1997.

In other words, in precisely the four‐year period in which members of the government say that investors have been running away from us and that the mining industry is being destroyed, the ABS tells us that mining exploration has gone up again in the last quarter as it has right through from June 1993. So no more of the scare tactics about how we are frightening away investment. We are not. The legislation you are putting through, the uncertainty it will create, and the field day it will provide for solicitors are what will provide the uncertainty. If there is a downturn in that figure next year, it will not be as a result of our legislation or the High Court's decision; it will be as a result of your own uncertainty.

The very last thing I want to say is to quote a source I do not usually use, the editorial of the Brisbane Courier-Mail. Today the Brisbane Courier‐Mail, in a very timely intervention in this debate, had an editorial in which they referred to a number of things, including the comments made by the Law Reform Commission. The editorial said:
. . . an important and independent group of expert lawyers considers that the legislation to implement the Prime Minister's 10‐point plan is constitutionally suspect.

The parliamentary committee and Parliament may pretend that advice does not exist. Everyone else will know, however, that the Government's proposals, if adopted, will be challenged in the High Court. The one thing that we can be sure of is that it will take years to determine whether any new law is valid. The 10‐point plan will not produce the certainty everyone desires.
It went on:

The Prime Minister has lost sight of that aim, in his determination to wind back the impact of native title claims. He has gone too far in bending to the demands of the National Party for "virtual" extinguishment of native title. He has failed to recognise that pandering to those who want to overturn the High Court's decisions in Mabo and Wik will not work in the long run. Aborigines are not going to give up their struggle for land rights even if they lose this particular battle.
It concluded by saying:

Some changes to the Native Title Act are essential. But the Government is wrong to try to remove such native title rights as may be recognised under existing common law and the Native Title Act. Besides, if the ALRC is right, this legislation will probably fail.
And sadly, that is what will happen, at great cost to this nation, both in dollars and in social cohesion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Randall, Don, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting for some time to talk on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . This government has set out to do what the previous government could not do, which is to address the myriad problems that are contained within the flawed legislation of the Native Title Act 1993, commonly known as the Mabo act.

SPEECH.PARA: It is nearly four years now since we have seen an act which was supposed to benefit the indigenous people of Australia but which has benefited nobody but wealthy lawyers—on that point I agree with the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis)—bureaucrats and those from the industry.

It is a matter of history now that the existing legislation has seen only one determination of native title in this country. That is pretty extraordinary for an act which has been in force for over four years. As I have said in this place before, over 1,383 applications have been lodged with the Native Title Tribunal. Of those, 596 were claimant applications. In support of those claimant applications, ATSIC has spent $90 million in legal fees—$90 million to deliver zero.

In fact, while I am talking about that, it makes me wonder about the judicious handling of some of these funds from ATSIC—the sum of $16 billion over the last 12 years, over $1 billion a year, and yet we are told that 30 per cent of children in Alice Springs suffer from malnutrition. The decision to spend this sort of money, $90 million on the 600 claims, was made by ATSIC's own economic section, so I think they have got their priorities wrong.

The opposition have said they will cooperate with the government in terms of greater certainty for stakeholders, for greater workability and for timely resolution of disputes. In fact, I sat and listened to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in his response to this bill's introduction. He has acknowledged that the 1993 act needed remedial attention; that if they had remained in government—typically, in their old 14th year—they would have got around to it. But we know that they did not. It is unworkable and it has to be dealt with.

We see this bill being attacked for some apparent unconstitutionality. I have boiled it down to three main reasons that the Labor Party oppose this bill. They are opposing it for these reasons: the racial discrimination clause, the right to negotiate clause, and the sunset clause. There are other aspects, but they are the three main issues that the Labor Party seem to be taking up with this 1997 bill.

The ALP alleges that requiring the claimants to be more accountable in their claims and the fact that claims are of one particular racial group constitute racism and contravene the Racial Discrimination Act—hence its attack on its constitutionality. It is a pretty long bow, pretty spurious. In fact, the ALP says that, because it does not satisfy the Racial Discrimination Act, it would be subject to High Court attacks and therefore struck down. Quite honestly, I think that the opposition know that that is not true. In fact, they say its constitutionality is flawed because it is a dilution, as I said, of the group's rights, but do they not have the same accountability? Are they not required to be accountable?

We would say, using the pendulum analogy, that the rights have swung to one particular racial group. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said on many occasions that the rights have swung far too far. This legislation brings the situation back to a more cohesive and a fairer middle ground. This legislation is not racially discriminatory. In legal advice to the government from the Attorney‐General's Department, several opinions state that this legislation is not discriminatory. In fact, it just goes to the fact that the Australian Labor Party is trying to turn this into a race debate, as we saw the member for Banks (Mr Melham) do in the Northern Territory recent election.

Until it can be proven otherwise—there was the introduction of Mabo in 1993—there is no precedent that this matter is racially discriminatory.
