In fact, it is just posturing from the Australian Labor Party. There is no evidence—it is only conjecture and hearsay—that any of these matters would be proven to be racially discriminatory.

If the industry groups were interested in delivering real title, they would not jump on this as a racial issue. The previous speaker spent half his time talking about past injustices. We all agree that there have been many past injustices, not only to one particular racial group but to many groups, including women and orphans. What we are saying is that that is wrong and these things must not proceed. I believe this bill addresses real fairness in terms of Aboriginal rights.

Instead of continuing to turn this into a race debate—which those in the opposition seem to do every time they get up—and saying that this legislation is racist, they really should concentrate on legitimate racial concerns. If you cry wolf over this bill, people will not believe you in the future.

I address the Law Reform Commission's criticism of this bill in their draft which was waved around today. Alan Rose, who has attacked the constitutionality of this bill—as was said by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams)—was a former employee of that department. He is a former disgruntled lawyer of the Attorney-General's Department. In fact, he is obviously one of the Labor Lawyers; he belongs to the Labor Lawyers association. He is an acolyte acting on behalf of the Labor Party in terms of this matter. He is simply doing their bidding. He knows that he comes from one philosophical viewpoint. If you want to go out and get an opinion on any matter from a QC, those who interpret the law can interpret it their way. This is what Mr Rose is doing.

The Attorney-General's advice to the government is that the bill is not unconstitutional. In fact, his chief counsel has told him that this bill certainly does not contravene the Racial Discrimination Act and that it is constitutional. In fact, as has been said earlier today, the Law Reform Commission should look at matters which are put before it by the government, as it is in its terms of reference. This has been pointed out on many occasions.

The member for Banks agreed, when he was the chair of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the previous parliament, that the Law Reform Commission should address their terms of reference, not have a roving brief. But here they have gone off and decided to submit their views on native title, which they were not asked to do. They did not have these terms of reference. There are many negative submissions, and they have already been put to the joint committee on native title, which is currently having hearings.

If the Law Reform Commission is clearly going outside its brief, it would be interesting to know if it has misused its funds in doing so—by going outside of its brief and seeking extra work which is not part of its terms of reference. In fact, I hope that in the next Senate estimates committee hearings somebody asks just that question: is the commission awash with personnel and funds so that it can have this roving brief?

While I am talking about lawyers and the interest in this Native Title Bill, I feel compelled to refer to Mr Ian Viner QC, who is also a member of the Reconciliation Council and a lawyer who defends Aboriginal claims. As a member of the Reconciliation Council, he gets his sitting fee as a lawyer. He has a vested interest in defending these claims. As a former minister in this parliament, he continues to get his superannuation. He should declare this and let us know that he has a commercial interest in this. He should stop milking it for his own commercial want.

I agree with those who say that native title is about justice, social cohesion, welfare and cultural identity, but you cannot just talk about those matters and leave out the economic realities that native title has not delivered either social justice or economic justice. So to people like Ian Viner, I say: cut the rhetoric and support a government which is going to do something about the certainty for all.

For example, in my own state of Western Australia—the state most affected by native title—around 82 per cent is under some form of native title claim. Much has been said about the cost to the mining industry since this act came in. We know that the mining industry not only contributes huge amounts to Australia's export economy but creates jobs. Some say that there is growth despite the native title problem, and I am sure that is true in many areas, but it is also true that it is holding up the whole matter of certainty in the mining industry. That goes towards Australia's national interest and jobs for people who are desperately seeking work. We say that you should take all these matters into account rather than be diverted on some of the more spurious allegations. It is vital to our economic development.

I will give you an example: the Mirriuwang ‐Gajerrong case, which is currently in the Kimberleys. This case is holding up the second stage of development on the Ord River dam project. This project is worth untold millions, not only to the state of Western Australia but to Australia. There are people laying spurious claims over that area. They know that they do not have a legitimate title right to that area but they think that, if they can register an interest, there is a good chance, by being involved in the right to negotiate, of some sort of financial settlement, if it is settled before it can be decided in legislation. This is true of a number of projects north of the 26th parallel, especially in Western Australia. They have just been held up because of the overlapping claims and the unholy interest in being registered as having a claim and the right to negotiate and what that does.

What has been achieved so far? All we have seen is the granting of one title, and that was at Crescent Head in New South Wales. Unbelievably, that was outside of this legislation—an agreed title—and it was paid out at 150 per cent of its real value.

We have seen numerous compensation claims paid out. For example, the Anaconda mining project in Western Australia recently negotiated a claim with the local claimants. But, by agreeing to a claim outside any legal framework, the legitimacy of that claim is thrown into doubt in relation to its absolute land title. In other words, you can negotiate an agreement over a particular mining area, but at some time in the future you will again have a problem when either that particular agreement finishes or that mining tenement finishes. This is because native title has not been decided even though there might have been a commercial agreement. That does not give certainty to anybody, especially future generations of claimants.

The only certainty is negotiation within the framework of the legislation. We are addressing this by ensuring that all claims can be made through the act. This simplified act will be there to ensure legitimacy and certainty for all time. As I have said, we have seen overlapping claims which do not appear to resolve anything; all they do is create a huge bureaucratic backlog.

The opposition's biggest stumbling point in this is, as I have said, the right to negotiate provision, which contributes to the problem with overlapping claims. In relation to the right to negotiate, let me say that I could not believe it when the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) said the right to negotiate was in common law. It is not. The right to negotiate was never part of the 1993 act. It was referred to in the preamble—just as Keating referred to the fact that there was no native title over pastoral leases—but the opposition always sought to treat it as a core part of the legislation.

I can assure this House that there is no common law right over areas that have been part of a claim. That point really needs to sink in, because the Leader of the Opposition came into this House and said that there is a common law right over this land, which is just not true. In fact, when challenged later by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), conceded that that is the case, but that at some time in the future there may be a common law right. Saying that there may be a common law right is a lot different from saying there is a common law right.

The Labour Party really should get this right. They should understand that they are misleading the people of Australia by telling them that people who lay a claim have a common law right over that land. It is just not true.

Currently, the structure of the right to negotiate provision is inefficient because it allows multiple groups and overlapping claims. Our amendments to the right to negotiate provisions will streamline the process so that unnecessary delays are eliminated while maintaining the protection of the legitimate interests of the native title holders and claimants.

BREAK.PARA: But nothing can be done until the right to negotiate provision is addressed, because everybody loses out; the claimants themselves experience delays. In fact, as I have said, no claims have been settled other than the one in New South Wales, which was negotiated. The Aboriginals are missing out. I can assure you that they individually tell us that they are pretty angry that they cannot determine these matters on their behalf. We have seen the farce involving Century Zinc where a large number of people claimed the same area. The right to negotiate was sorted out, but the actual claim on the land was not.

I have to laugh when I hear people talking about this being a pastoral lease issue. It is not. There are 66 claims over crown reserves, drainage reserves and road reserves in one city in my electorate of Swan, and yet people think it is just an agricultural or pastoral lease situation. It is not. The City of Belmont has all these claims over its parks and reserves. For example, because of the right to negotiate provision, at Forster Park in Belmont, if the council wants to extend a toilet block, they have to enter into negotiation provisions with the local Aboriginal claimants, which is totally ridiculous.

We know that there are overlapping claims in Perth. Not only are there three overlapping claims on the Perth airport, but there is another overlapping claim which starts north of Perth in Gidgegannup and goes right down to the south‐west of Western Australia. Part of my backyard was part of a claim. When the council tried to put sewerage in my backyard, which is near the Swan River, they were not allowed to do it because it was subject to a native title claim. They had to go down to the front, to my road. When they say your backyard is not claimable, that is just not true.

There are many other examples of vexatious claims. We have to be suspicious about the motives, because there is more money in the right to negotiate than there is in awarding native title. This point has been made on many occasions. You will get far more out of the right to negotiate than you will get out of the awarding of title. The threshold test needs to apply immediately so as to strike out these vexatious claims.

The ALP's willingness to have Aboriginal claimants involved too early in the process will cause problems because it stalls a resolution for all parties. Strangely, the ALP agrees that, even though it may be discriminatory, the registration or the threshold test should be tightened up—this is because they realise the inefficiency of multiple claims—but they want the right to negotiate to continue to run parallel with the registration test.

The threshold test will determine whether, under the original Mabo legislation, there was a legitimate claim. We know that the legitimate claim test is that claimants have had a continuous association with the land over a long period of time. But this has to be a physical attachment to the land, not a spiritual attachment. As Judith Watson, a former Labor member in Western Australia, said in relation to the Yackabindie nickel project, the planes could not fly over the project because the spirits would be entering heaven and that would contravene some right. That is crazy. How high would a plane have to fly over the project before it did not contravene a right?

I want to move to the matter of the sunset clause. The ALP's third major disagreement with our legislation is the sunset clause which will come into effect six years after the implementation of this legislation. I should point out that claimants can go to the Federal Court if their claims are rejected by the tribunal. If, after the amount of publicity, a claim has not been made in the six‐year period, I will be most surprised if people do not continue to find and resurrect pieces of land that were not found in that six‐year period. The 10‐point plan legitimately delivers native title to the claimants, and certainly to the land‐ and leaseholders. It has brought the act and the spirit of native title back to the middle ground. Hopefully, we will begin to see more indigenous people gain from the changes to the act. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Tanner) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received advice from the Chief National Party Whip that he has nominated Mr McGauran to be a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in place of Mr Marek.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fahey, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr FAHEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Airports Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 will facilitate the sale of the remaining federal airports by amending the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996, the Airports Act 1996 and the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.
On 1 July, the government executed the airport leases for the sale of the three phase 1 airports—Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth—and the new owners took over running of those airports on 2 July 1997.

It is a matter of public record that these sales represented a further major step forward in the micro‐economic reform agenda for the aviation sector. The sale of long‐term leases over three of our major airports enables world's best practice to be brought to the management and operation of Australia's major airports and facilitates future capital investment on a commercial basis.

In this regard I had previously announced that the new lessees of Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports are contractually committed to long‐term development obligations—including substantial investment commitments in core airport infrastructure—totalling over half a billion dollars over the next 10 years. Moreover, this investment is being made under a post‐privatisation pricing regime which will see a real decline in aeronautical service charges over the next five years in line with expected productivity improvements at these airports.

Innovative management practices are already becoming evident with the announcement by the new Melbourne airport lessees that rebates of up to 50 per cent on aeronautical charges are available to airlines, on application, offering new services and up to 30 per cent for those increasing frequency of existing services to and from Melbourne airport. Available on a decreasing scale for three years, the aim of this measure, with direct benefits to the travelling public, is to lower operating costs for start‐up services and to facilitate the growth of services considered viable in the longer term.

The sale of the Sydney basin airports, which are Kingsford Smith, Hoxton Park, Bankstown, and Camden airports, will take place only after completion of an environmental assessment of options for the site for the second Sydney airport and when the government has effectively addressed noise issues relating to Sydney airport.

Under this phase of the sales program, 10 regular public transport (RPT) and five general aviation (GA) airports are to be disposed of. It is proposed, as for phase 1 sales, the eight RPT airports at Adelaide, Alice Springs, Canberra, Coolangatta, Darwin, Hobart, Launceston and Townsville will be sold by long‐term leasehold. Each lease would be for 50 years with an option for an additional 49 years. These sales can, of course, be undertaken under the existing provisions of the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996 and will be subject to the same Commonwealth regulatory controls that apply to the phase 1 airports as provided for under the Airports Act 1996 and associated regulations.

On this occasion, however, the government wishes to have the flexibility of offering the five GA airports at Archerfield, Essendon, Jandakot, Moorabbin, and Parafield and the two RPT airports at Mount Isa and Tennant Creek for freehold disposal. A freehold disposal of these airports, however, requires amendments to be made to the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996.

Before I turn to the specifics of the proposed amendments I would like to briefly elaborate on the reasons for the government's decision. While the airports included in phase 1 were all airports of national and international significance, the 15 airports in phase 2 are diverse. Some are major national airports while others are principally of regional and local significance, many with a large general aviation base.

Freehold sale of the general aviation airports and the smaller regional airports will provide greater opportunities for those airports to be integrated into the policy and planning frameworks of state and local authorities. The sites would cease to be Commonwealth places and in the future the states and territories would assume the responsibility for planning and environment controls on the airports.

This is logical and consistent with the practice adopted under the previous government's aerodrome local ownership program where some 230 local airports were transferred under freehold title to local owners, a number of which are far larger in terms of revenue and aircraft traffic volumes than some of those now being proposed to be disposed of by freehold sale.

Unlike the major airports, these airports are principally intrastate in their traffic and their non‐aviation activities are more locally orientated, with a local community focus and impact. A freehold sale of these airports provides an opportunity for a strengthened association with local community interests—those best placed to influence the development and operation of the airports in a manner conducive to fulfilling regional aspirations—without a Commonwealth overlay of controls in the areas of planning and environment.

Existing Commonwealth controls over safe operations, flight paths and aircraft noise would be unaffected, but the question of how an airport's operations interlink and interact with the community in which it is located would become a matter for the state or territory concerned. The Commonwealth will require, however, before an airport is sold freehold that the relevant state government undertakes to ensure that state or territory and local laws do not jeopardise continued airport operations and that the core airport site will be restricted to continued use as such. The Commonwealth wants to ensure that any airport sold freehold continues to be used as an airport, and is reserving the option of leasing any of these airports if the required assurances are not forthcoming from the relevant state or territory governments.

As mentioned earlier, in order to allow for freehold sale of some of the phase 2 airports it is necessary to amend the Airports (Transitional) Act 1996. Those amendments are contained in schedule 1 to the bill and their main provisions are to facilitate the transfer of: land from the Federal Airports Corporation to the purchaser; the assets, liabilities, contracts and employees directly to the purchaser following the transfer of land; and the relevant staff at each of the airports to the purchaser.

As for the phase 1 sales, it will be important that the jobs and entitlements of FAC staff at the airports to be sold will not be threatened by the disposal process. Therefore, whether the airports are to be leased or sold, staff and management will be transferred to the relevant airport entity immediately upon sale. Existing awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment will transmit to the new airport lessees or airport entity which will ensure that airport staff retain key terms and conditions of employment and entitlements to accrued benefits following their transfer. Following the transfer of staff, the terms and conditions of their employment, as contained in awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment, will be able to be varied only according to the terms of those agreements.

There are two minor amendments to the stamp duty provisions in the Airports (Transitional) Act. Firstly, item 14 of the bill provides that, post sale, an entity is not liable to stamp duty in respect of an instrument which was executed by the FAC before sale. This is an extension of the existing provisions under section 47 of the Airports (Transitional) Act in regard to a leasehold disposal. Its purpose is to ensure that an airport company does not become liable to pay stamp duty in respect of an instrument to which the FAC was party and which was formerly exempt from duty. Any alteration to the instrument after sale which would attract stamp duty is not exempted by this provision.

Secondly, item 15 of the bill is to extend the application of section 48 of the Airports (Transitional) Act to freehold entities. Section 48 ensures that stamp duty is payable in circumstances where the sale is affected by making of a declaration vesting the freehold in the airport entity. That section provides that, where stamp duty would have otherwise been payable, it is not exempt just because the transfer of the airport was affected by a ministerial declaration.

There is one minor amendment, item 16, to the special income tax rules in the legislation and that is to extend to a freehold entity the power of the minister to make a declaration that the Income Tax Assessment Act applies to the FAC as though it had received payment for the disposal. This provision was used in the phase 1 sales to declare the value for tax purposes on the assets disposed by the FAC.

As for the phase 1 sales, I am not proposing to utilise the determination provisions available in sections 49, 50 and 51 of the Airports (Transitional) Act. For the purposes of their bids, prospective purchasers will be advised that they should value the airports on the basis of depreciation arrangements that are consistent with those outlined in the Treasurer's press release of 4 August 1997.

This bill also contains amendments to the Airports Act 1996 which are proposed to streamline the regulatory regime for the leased federal airports. Schedule 2 of the bill covers four main areas, which I will deal with in turn.

Firstly, section 5 of the Airports Act specifically defines a joint‐user airport as Canberra, Darwin and Townsville. The Department of Defence is currently considering the nature of its operations at Canberra Airport and the status of the airport may change in the future. The bill will amend section 5 of the Airports Act to enable a regulation to be made declaring that Canberra would no longer be a joint‐user airport at such time as the Department of Defence chooses to cease operating at that airport.

Secondly, section 33 of the Airports Act provides that an airport lessee company cannot enter into an airport management agreement with another person unless that person is both approved in writing by the minister and a qualified company within the meaning given under the act. The Airports Act also provides that the minister cannot approve an airport management company if it breaches ownership restrictions under the act.

Since the ownership restrictions in part 3 of the act already apply to an airport management company, the provision is unnecessary and so the bill provides for the requirement to be repealed. In its place the Minister for Transport and Regional Development will retain a simple power to determine by disallowable instrument whether a specific agreement is, or is not, an airport management agreement, and to not approve any agreements if there are concerns with them. The government wishes to take advantage of the benefits that foreign management expertise can bring to Australia's airports, but it remains important that any structures designed to circumvent the public policy objectives of the legislation can be denied.

Thirdly, section 192 of the act provides that the minister may determine that each airport service provided at an airport will be a declared service for the purposes of the access regime set out in part 111A of the Trade Practices Act 1974, except to the extent to which a service is the subject of an access undertaking given within 12 months after the airport is leased to the private sector.

The bill proposes to give authority to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, to determine by disallowable instrument which activities at an airport fit within the relevant definition of an `airport service' as a result of a determination by the minister. This amendment will ensure that the ACCC has the capacity to clarify situations where doubt arises about the scope of an `airport service' that has been declared as a result of the minister's determination.

BREAK.PARA: Fourthly, subsection 242(1) of the Airports Act provides for applications to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of certain decisions made by the minister. Those decisions concern the approval of master plans, major development plans and environment strategies, including variations to master plans and major development plans and environment strategies.

Under the act, the airport lessee is required to undertake wide public consultation prior to submitting draft master plans, major development plans and environment strategies to the minister for approval. The minister then either approves or refuses to approve the draft plans having regard to the matters to be considered as set out in the act, including: whether an airport development would assist airport users; how the airport and surrounding areas are affected; comments made by interested and affected parties as part of the public consultation process; and the environmental impact. These procedures are comprehensive and permit soundly based decisions to be made by the minister. The amendments ensure that these decisions will be open to the scrutiny of the parliament. The minister is required to prepare and table in both houses of parliament a statement about these decisions, except to the extent that the commercial interests of a person would be substantially prejudiced. This will also bring these provisions into line with planning processes under state law.

In addition to these four changes, the bill will insert a number of notes to existing sections of the Airports Act to clarify the way in which state law applies to airport activities. Schedule 3 of the bill extends the corporation's functions to include assisting in the sale of a federal airport by way of freehold disposal. This removes any ambiguity as to whether the corporation is empowered to assist in the disposal of its assets by this means and provides the board with an assurance that they are clearly operating within their responsibilities.

The additional amendment to section 41 of the FAC Act clarifies that information obtained by the government under a ministerial direction given before the commencement of the amendment may be used after its com mencement. This ensures that there is no perceived legal impediment to using the information in connection with any freehold sales.

In conclusion, I would like to note that the government's airport sales process and the post‐sale regulatory regime, which has been put in place, is making Australia a world leader in airport ownership and management. It provides the opportunity for the utilisation of private sector investment and expertise at Australia's airports.

There is already a great deal of investor interest in the next tranche of airports, particularly in regional areas. The proposed measures outlined in this bill will maximise the opportunities for the development of regional airports and will provide a more streamlined and effective regulatory regime. Given the need to provide certainty to airport bidders and airport users, it is essential that this legislation be passed in the current sittings to meet the airport sales timetable. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr FAHEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendment No. 2 be disagreed to.

This amendment to clause 37, page 23, after subclause (2), seeks to include the words `The Attorney-General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor-General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament'.

The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment for two reasons. First, it is the proper role of the elected executive to bear responsibility for preventing damage to the public interest. It is the executive which will be held accountable to the parliament and ultimately to the electorate for its performance in that regard. Secondly, the framework of clause 37, as amended by the Senate, would provide scope for the Auditor‐General to be drawn in as an unwitting party to the often political issues that members and senators may wish to pursue.

I have some difficulties in understanding why the Labor Party came to the conclusion they did in the debate on this particular amendment in the Senate. I note that Senator Cook stated in his remarks on this amendment:

. . . it is possible to construct scenarios in which some matter may be being sought to be inquired of by a parliamentary committee which does border on the national interest or directly impinge on the national interest or some state secret.

He went on to say that it is generally the case that parliamentary committees are made up in the majority by members of the government and, therefore, the government would act to protect the national interest, to protect national interest issues. I think that clearly indicates what this particular section is all about as it stands in the bill before it was amended by the Senate and it perhaps indicates what the Senate had in mind in seeking to amend it.

BREAK.PARA: Clause 37 of the bill is specifically relevant to those areas which apply to national security. I would have thought that all members of this House would appreciate that it should not be left open for the Auditor-General to be interfered with in his decisions on matters of national security and national interest or, for that matter, for it to be left in the hands of a committee of the parliament to seek information that would go into the public arena in a way that could do great damage to Australia's standing on an international basis or otherwise.

I believe that in the drafting of the bill, as it was originally passed by this House, the government had this in mind, and I had many discussions on the need to ensure, firstly, that there was an unfettered power there for the Auditor-General as an officer of the parliament entrenched by these bills and, secondly, that the Auditor-General was not embroiled in political controversy brought about by some decision of a committee whereby the majority on that committee were not members of the executive government of the day.

Clause 37 replicates a framework which has been in operation in the Audit Act 1901 for almost 20 years. The scope for intervention by the Attorney-General to prevent disclosure of particular kinds of information on public interest grounds is not extensive. In view of discussions I had on that very point, it was considered appropriate that the Attorney-General, again in the national interest, should give a certificate to the Auditor-General as to why information should be withheld by the Auditor-General. Again, that is to ensure that the maximum amount of accountability was there and at the same time we did not interfere with the national interest and particularly, as I say, the national security.

There are provisions to prevent information being forthcoming that might prejudice matters before a court. Of course, this just entrenches the sub judice rule. One can appreciate the fact that that can do untold damage to many people in the community if a committee of the parliament could take advantage of information that had been brought to its attention to circumvent what should surely be in the interests of justice in this country of ours.

The reasons listed in clause 37(2) for the Attorney-General to issue the certificate relate only to matters of genuine importance and significance. (Extension of time granted) If one were to imagine a worst case scenario that could occur under the Senate amendment it is possible to see how damage could be caused to Australia's national or international security and how the integrity of the Commonwealth's position could be undermined in ways that caused genuine damage to Australia. Accordingly, the House of Representatives believes that it is not worth the risk to accept the Senate amendment.

The House of Representatives believes that the framework in clause 37, unamended, has been proven to operate in a realistic and sensible way, having been used only once for reasons of national security. Moreover, clause 37 as drafted provides an added measure of accountability on the executive in that it compels the Auditor-General to report any intervention by the executive and the reasons for it. The House of Representatives believes that the framework provided for in clause 37 is sound and therefore disagrees with the Senate amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The only point of difference between the opposition and the government on this whole package of legislation relates to clause 37. The legislative package itself dates back to 1989 and the work of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. It lapsed in previous years, principally because of an obstructive opposition at the time. As the Labor opposition, we support the legislative package. It is largely our creation. Whilst the former opposition delayed the package literally for years, in this parliament we have facilitated quick passage and intend to continue doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth needs modern financial systems in legislation and this package will deliver that. However, there is one matter of contention, and that relates to the power of the executive to gag the Auditor-General. Labor accepts that in some situations the national interest will be served by the non-disclosure of some information—for example, sensitive Defence or foreign relations information. We agree with that position and, accordingly, support the right of the Attorney-General to issue a certificate under clause 37 in appropriate circumstances.

I note that this power currently exists and apparently has been used only once over the last 20 years or so. I believe it was during the time of the Fraser government. However, the amendment which the Senate agreed to is designed to stop potential abuse of what is by any yardstick a very wide power given to the Attorney-General. The amendment of the Senate, whilst maintaining the general power of the Attorney, qualifies it in one important respect—namely, that the Attorney cannot issue a certificate to silence the Auditor-General about an issue on which the parliament, or a committee of the parliament, has requested information.

Just as the reserve power for the Attorney is important, so too is a legislative guarantee against the abuse of that power. Indeed, the unfortunate recent episode where we saw the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) seeking to gag the Law Reform Commission is a striking and contemporary illustration of the need for this kind of protection. We have had the Law Reform Commission seeking to make a submission concerning the native title legislation. We have had clear evidence that the Attorney-General has interfered with that process. His defences have been that this issue is outside the charter of the Law Reform Commission, yet the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Nick Minchin, has sought himself the views of the Law Reform Commission on the native title and Wik legislation.

The Law Reform Commission routinely comments on inquiries by parliamentary committees. Indeed, the Attorney-General had to own up this afternoon to having tabled an annual report which gave a number of examples of that process in action. The Attorney-General had not even bothered to read it, according to his response this afternoon. The real reason for that attempt by the Attorney-General at suppression was political—the embarrassment of the government at the Law Reform Commission's findings that the government's proposed native title legislation may be unconstitutional, may involve massive taxpayer compensation, may be in breach of this nation's international obligations.

It was never a problem before that the Law Reform Commission made submissions to parliamentary committees and other bodies. So for this government, when the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) attacks Aborigines, that is free speech and ought to be celebrated but, when the Law Reform Commission wants to tell the government some home truths and tries to support Aborigines, that material ought to be suppressed and never see the light of day.

In my view, this is not the kind of Attorney-General whom we would want to see having the kind of unlimited power which the government is seeking to provide for with its provision. It is clearly a political use of the Attorney-General's power to suppress what he has been engaging in. The matter was reported to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by the Chief of Staff to the Attorney‐General, Mr Hugh Funder. He spoke with the principal private secretary to the Prime Minister, Tony Nutt, to let him know what was going on. This was all about high politics, not some appropriate and genuine concern on the part of the Attorney-General about the Law Reform Commission exceeding its powers.
The Labor opposition will support the Senate amendment. We will be supporting it again in the Senate. We believe it represents an appropriate safeguard. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Senate's amendment No. 2, I have a couple of questions I would like to ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) on the matter. I am interested to know exactly in the terms of this particular amendment of the Senate whether it in fact would make the Auditor-General more answerable to the parliament, as was, in my view, the understanding of the role of the Auditor-General. I refer to House of Representatives Practice , which specifically says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Audit Act provides that reports of the Auditor‐General must be forwarded to the Speaker for presentation to the House, and this is illustrative of the position of the Auditor‐General as a person responsible to Parliament, rather than to Government.

I would have thought that the Democrats' amendment in the Senate is in fact enhancing the relationship between the Auditor-General and the parliament rather than perhaps reinforcing the relationship of the Auditor-General as a creature of or answerable to the executive. I would be interested in his response to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr FAHEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, in response to the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), I can indicate that, if the honourable member for Moore looks at section 37 and the subsections there in terms of the provisions that are applicable, the circumstances in which the Attorney-General can in fact issue a certificate is very clear. That certificate can only be issued by the Attorney-General and, of course, reported on by the Attorney-General to the parliament where it is in the public interest to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about a protection of areas. I would have thought that the honourable member for Moore would understand more than anyone else that information will be forthcoming from committees of this parliament on a regular basis where the government is not in the majority, particularly in another place, if there is an opportunity given for base political purposes. I seek to avoid the national interest being affected by such decisions that are taken for base political purposes. I certainly would want to avoid any risk being put to national security. That is the basis for the clause as drafted. That right, that protection, is taken away by the amendment moved by the Democrats in the Senate.

There are very limited opportunities for the Attorney-General to issue such a certificate. I have indicated that in the past 20 years it has occurred on one occasion. I would have thought that the honourable member for Moore could imagine many situations in any single week where information is in the national interest. Dare I say it, events in New Guinea and Bougainville earlier this year might have been fairly relevant, but it would not have been in this government's interest for that sort of information to be in the public arena. It is narrow. It is clearly in the public interest to have that there, and the amendment would destroy that protection which I believe is vitally important for this nation's future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me repeat: it is not the opposition's view that it is appropriate for a power of this kind to be given to the Attorney‐General without any qualification which has regard to the parliament. We believe this does raise separation of powers issues involving the primacy and supremacy of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We note that part of this bill is to make the Auditor-General an officer of the parliament and, against that background, we think it is appropriate that parliament should have some fetter on the powers of the Auditor-General. I emphasise that, for the Auditor-General to be truly independent, the Auditor-General is in a position to carry out his or her functions in the way that he or she sees fit. I do not think what is being proposed by the Senate gives rise to the prospect of parliamentary committees dictating to the Auditor-General in any shape or form.

I would make the point that, while the opposition does not propose to divide on the bill in the House again, and we are keen that it has an appropriate passage, we do intend to pursue this issue in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment for two reasons.

First, it is the proper role of the elected Executive to bear responsibility for preventing damage to the public interest and it is the Executive which will be held accountable by the Parliament and, ultimately, the electorate for its performance in that regard. Secondly, the framework of clause 37, as amended by the Senate, would provide scope for the Auditor‐General to be drawn in as an unwitting party to the, often, political issues that Members and Senators may wish to pursue.

Clause 37 replicates a framework that has been in operation in the Audit Act 1901 for almost 20 years. The scope for intervention by the Attorney‐General to prevent disclosure of particular kinds of information on public interest grounds is not extensive. The reasons listed in Clause 37(2) for the Attorney‐General to issue a certificate relate only to matters of genuine importance and significance. If one were to imagine a worst case scenario that could occur under the Senate amendment, it is possible to see how damage could be caused to Australia's national or international security and how the integrity of the Commonwealth's position could be undermined in ways that caused genuine damage to Australia. Accordingly, the House of Representatives believes that it in not worth the risk to accept the Senate amendment.

The House of Representatives believes that the framework in Clause 37, unamended, has been proven to operate in a realistic and sensible way, having been used only once, for reasons of national security. Moreover, Clause 37, as drafted, provides an added measure of accountability on the Executive in that it compels the Auditor‐General to report any intervention by the Executive and the reasons for it. The House of Representatives believes that the framework provided for in clause 37 is sound and therefore disagrees with the Senate amendment.
Motion (by Mr Fahey) agreed:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I received a letter from a man in Nambour, Queensland, in the electorate of Fairfax. Over the last couple of days, both in this place and in the Main Committee, we have been debating quite extensively the firearm reforms. I want to take the opportunity to congratulate everybody concerned with that. I do not want to take up too much of the time of the House doing that, but I cannot let the opportunity go by without congratulating the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the premiers, the chief ministers and indeed the Australian people. That effort involved a lot of reasonable people.

SPEECH.PARA: This letter that I have received reflects the view of a minority group of unreasonable people. I am very pleased that the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) is in the chamber. She should, I suggest, listen to this because these are some of the so-called supporters of what her One Nation party stands for.
I would like to read to the House what this letter said. I will only read part of it, but it is the salient part. It is headed `Treason Trials', and it says:

I have been instructed to advise you sir, that your name is in the eighth batch of one hundred (100) alleged political, judicial, administrative, media and financial criminals to be charged, tried, and where found guilty, HUNG for treason, crimes against the constitution, crimes against the Bill Of Rights 1688 . . . and crimes against humanity et. al.
It goes on:
As you would be, or should be well aware by now, this will be your last term in office. After that the Treason Trials.

I have provided a copy of this letter in accordance with standing orders to the clerk. It is signed by Mr Norm Segal of Nambour, Queensland. This gentleman, if that is the right terminology, and one or two others of the same ilk—the McNivens, the Dawnings, the Tony Pitts—who are involved in the member for Oxley's organisation and the publication of such outlandish magazines as Lock, Stock and Barrel are the sorts of people who are writing to us.

Like a lot of politicians, I have to have a thick skin. I do not want to make anybody a martyr in this matter, but I think it is about time we exposed some of these people for what they are. They are a very vociferous minority group in our community, and I think it is about time we exposed them for what they are.
Adjournment proposed and negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I was raising a matter of privilege and was referring to some of these people and the writer of this particular letter that I received. Others may have received such a letter; I do not know. I can only act as an individual. Some of these people are absolute loony tunes and fringe dwellers, and we should expose them just as that. We listen to what they have to say, but I think it is about time we drew the line and did something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of these people are involved with the member for Oxley's organisation and with the organisation of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). Both members want to hide behind some of these people. If I were the member for Oxley, I would be looking over my shoulder at these people. I do not know that you understand the way you are being manipulated by these minority groups, and that was reflected in your speech earlier in the day in this place on native title. You talk about one nation conspiracy theories and new world orders. That is quite ridiculous. You are being driven by some of these vociferous minority groups. It is about time you grew up and knew exactly what was happening.

Mr Speaker, I would like to raise this letter as a matter of privilege. Before you came in, I provided a copy of this letter to the clerk and I seek your guidance. As I said before, nobody wants to make anybody a martyr. But I think it is about time that this particular gentleman really understood what parliamentary privilege is all about. I seek your guidance and your ruling under standing orders 95 to 97A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Groom. You raise some very interesting questions. I will take the matter on notice and report back further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of weeks ago Channel 9 and News Limited, in conjunction with the CES, ran a Jobs for Australia campaign. They should be commended for that, as should the employers of Australia that offered the 20,000 jobs. However, the stark reality is that these 20,000 jobs, even if they all eventuated, would do nothing of a fundamental nature to change the chronic and endemic unemployment that stagnates the economies of Australia and the developed world.

SPEECH.PARA: Corporations and business will not deliver full employment. Why would they? They do not have the long-term responsibility for stability and families that governments can have. Governments need to lead. Governments need to set the policy environment in order to seek the cooperation of corporations, business and labour unions. Yet governments around the world, including the Howard government, are moving away from the commitments and social contracts they have had with ordinary workers post‐World War II.

In an article in Foreign Affairs volume 75 No. 3, Ethan Kapstein, Director of Studies at the Council on Foreign Relations in the United States, made a number of points about globalisation and its impact on employment:
The global economy is leaving millions of disaffected workers in its train . . .
Just when working people most need the nation‐state as a buffer from the world economy it is abandoning them . . .

For generations students were taught that increasing trade and investment, coupled with technological change, would drive national productivity and create wealth. Yet over the past decade despite a continuing booming international trade and finance, productivity has faltered and inequality in the United States and unemployment in Europe has worsened . . .
In globalisation's previous incarnation governments had done little to protect working people from its malign effects, and their mistakes exacted a price in revolutions and war.

Kapstein argues that governments are trying to break their postwar deal with workers while maintaining their commitment to an open economy. Governments cannot have it both ways and, instead, the policy focus should be on negotiating a package that helps workers adjust to ongoing changes. Kapstein says:

If the concern is incoming inequality, policies should be adopted to close the income gap. If the concern is unemployment more jobs should be created. In developing positive solutions however, it is important to recognise that declining rates of economic growth caused largely by a drop off in productivity are hurting all workers.

Governments from the mid‐1980s until now have adopted policies deemed sustainable or credible by financial markets. These policies have privileged stability over employment, according to Kapstein. Restrictive economic policies, reduced deficits, reduced spending, reduced taxes and—the most exalted deity—low inflation have favoured financial interests at the expense of workers. Politicians and public officials who adopt these restrictive measures are labelled `responsible' by editorialists, and the markets reward their behaviour sustaining the ideology.

Kapstein says that governments essentially have four choices to assist their unskilled and semi‐skilled work force. The first choice is protectionism, which is a remedy worse than the disease. The second is education and training, and that is perhaps the only policy intervention that meets with universal approval. Democratic societies should be financed. It makes for good politics and good economics. But, in the near term, it cannot provide the solution to the structural problems of employment and inequality.

The third approach is to increase the number of jobs through public works programs and employment subsidies to the private sector. Public job creation is relatively efficient and socially productive—since it provides younger workers with needed job experience—and it can be done fairly quickly. The fourth policy choice is tax reform, and perhaps eliminating income taxes altogether for a large number of the working poor while making them sharply more progressive up the income ladder.

One of the main arguments against an expansionary strategy is that it is inflationary. Certainly, inflation is unwelcome, but so is unemployment, which in this country is more like 13 to 15 per cent and much higher than the admitted rate of almost nine per cent. Kapstein acknowledges that restrictive policies may have been necessary when first conceived in the 1980s to bring stability to financial markets, but they have failed too many people for too long.

The challenge to all governments is clear: restore growth and opportunity. Unfortunately, in this country of Australia that we all represent, realisation of the message that Ethan Kapstein brings—who was also one of the proponents of globalisation in a former life—totally escapes the Howard government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Two Dunkley small businessmen have lost substantial sums of money investing in a phonecard vending machine business that had the backing of Telstra. Mr Gerhard Schulz and Mr Ted Hancock each lost $16,000 by investing in a business opportunity in 1993 promoted by General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd, an associated company to Del-Marina Pty Ltd, which shared a common director, Mr Rod Montague Laski of Prahran East, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Laski's companies claimed in advertisements published in the Age in early 1993 a `staggering 40 per cent minimum guaranteed return on your investment'. This same claim was reiterated in subsequent correspondence between Mr Laski and my constituents. The written guarantee promised that only sites that took revenue of at least $340 per week per machine would be selected. Naively but not unnaturally, as the associated company, Del-Marina Pty Ltd, had a distribution agreement with Telstra, they were among at least 19 small investors who believed these claims and purchased phonecard vending machines subsequently deployed at various retail outlets around Melbourne and Sydney.

Companies like Telstra and those associated with it have an obligation to behave ethically. On 14 October 1994 after the Casualties of Telecom saga with one compensation payment of $2.3 million, Telstra CEO, Mr Blount, said in large advertisements that Telstra embraced `an approach based on honesty and integrity . . . values fundamental to the way we do business'. My constituents assumed Telstra would have conducted a full study on Del-Marina Pty Ltd in view of their distribution agreement and relationship.

Telstra suggested to potential investors that Del‐Marina would be the sole source of new phonecard distribution outlets. The Telstra phonecard brand name was used in advertisements. My constituents assert that Telstra never enforced its agreement with Del‐Marina which insisted investors read the distribution agreement, only provided to Mr Schulz four months after he had made his investment. In July 1993 Telstra stated that General Vending Pty Ltd was the trading arm of Del-Marina and that General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd was now registered as a company.

By September 1993 my constituents knew that the claimed return on investment was mythical. Mr Schulz complained to the Trade Practices Commission which advised that, with their limited resources, the matter did not involve widespread consumer detriment and therefore would not be pursued. Despite receiving complaints in mid-1992, Telstra failed to terminate General Vending's contract until 28 October 1993. Telstra knew of Mr Laski from previous dealings and had previously terminated a contract with him. This surprising reaffirmation of faith in Mr Laski by Telstra allowed General Vending to win around $1 million in revenue. Telstra benefited from more phonecard sales and a reduction in vandalism at public phone boxes.

While Telstra offered to allow affected investors to supply phonecards to existing sites, this was impractical because a tiny number of people were supplying large areas by this time in view of the low returns from each machine. By October 1994 Telstra was indicating to Mr Schulz's solicitors that they might consider funding an action against Mr Laski, but nothing came of efforts to get Telstra to fund a class action against Mr Laski or the companies, justified by Telstra on the basis that General Vending was pending company deregistration. This was despite Telstra engaging solicitors to prepare a class action. Eventually, in April 1995, Telstra offered Mr Schulz $1,600 to use as he saw fit. Mr Rodney Laski did not cease as a director of General Vending (Australia) Pty Ltd until 24 April 1996 but had ceased his directorship with Del-Marina Pty Ltd on 2 February 1993. These vending machines were sold by General Vending for up to $1,800 each.

Australian Securities Commission records show Mr Laski to be currently the director of eight other companies including Miami Coin International Pty Ltd. Mr Laski's companies have previously been located in the Cadbury-Schweppes building at Level 10, 636 St Kilda Road, Melbourne. About six months ago, he did a `midnight flit' from this building. He now trades at Level 1, 391 St Kilda Road, Melbourne.

Mrs Robyn Peet of Dingley, Victoria, obtained judgment against General Vending Pty Ltd, Del-Marina Pty Ltd and Conmorre Pty Ltd for $71,800 in February 1996. Mrs Peet had been pregnant at the time she originally invested $63,000. Mr Donald Smith obtained a judgment in the county court for $70,000 in November 1995 against Del‐Marina and Mr Laski. In July this year Telstra wrote to Mr Schulz saying that they were unwilling to reopen their previous goodwill offer or renegotiate. Mr Laski is now offering so-called `club cards' for phone sex.

I call upon Telstra to put aside its indifference and to again consider doing what it can to assist these investors. The Australian Securities Commission should formally consider whether Mr Laski is a fit and proper person to hold Australian company directorship under section 230 of the Corporations Law. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening to I would like return to one of my favourite and recurring themes—namely, the hopelessness of the Western Australian parliamentary Liberal team. We know that my view of their hopelessness is shared by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) because there is not one Western Australian Liberal in the cabinet. We know that, in all of the speculation this week, about who is going to come and who is going to go, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) are much more likely to go out than they are to go up. We have seen headlines in recent times such as `PM takes Moylan to task', `Time may soon be up for minister' and `Moylan too ill to fend off her critics'. So we know that the Minister for Family Services is on a short fuse.

SPEECH.PARA: We also know, as the member for Moore (Mr Filing) alluded to today in question time Senator Campbell from Western Australia is gunning for her as well. He is after her spot. We also know that the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, has no confidence in either the Attorney-General or the Minister for Family Services. Yesterday he refused to be drawn on either of them, either their current performance or their future.

What do we know about the Attorney-General? We know that the Prime Minister has no confidence in him because as an Attorney-General he is not in cabinet. Now we discover that the Premier of Western Australia has no confidence in him either. An article in the West Australian of 1 October headed `WA cabinet call' says:

Premier Richard Court put in a bid yesterday for a WA Cabinet minister in the Howard Government's ministerial reshuffle . . . Mr Court said it was ludicrous that WA was not represented in Cabinet . . . He refused to comment on speculation that WA's Judi Moylan would be dumped . . . Mr Court singled out senators Chris Ellison and Ian Campbell as talented MPs who would make good Cabinet ministers.

That is picked up in the Australian , whose headline reads `Premier at odds with PM over make‐up of cabinet'. He again calls on Senators Ellison and Campbell to be made cabinet ministers. We know the Prime Minister has no confidence in the Attorney-General. Now we know the Premier has no confidence in him. Daryl would have gone by the end of the week, but now that he has been caught out over the Australian Law Reform Commission, the Prime Minister is handcuffed to him and he cannot take him out.

BREAK.PARA: Who is one West Australian Liberal who the Prime Minister would like to promote? His good friend, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). An article in the West Australian of 29 August headed `Rocher to bide time' says:
Prime Minister John Howard is missing one of his most loyal lieutenants. He wants his long‐time friend and political ally Allan Rocher to return to the Liberal Party.
It is understood he wants to meet privately with Mr Rocher—possibly as early as next week—to discuss future options, including a way of facilitating his comeback.
The scheduled meeting for Wednesday of this week was cancelled because of other matters.
But an article in the Sunday Times on 28 September headed `PM backs return by WA's Rocher' states:
Prime Minister John Howard has privately backed moves to bring a former Liberal and now independent MP, Allan Rocher, back into the Government.
But the move is believed to have run into opposition in WA, with one Liberal warning it would be "World War III" if it went ahead.
Liberal Party president Tony Staley is understood to have approached the WA Liberal Party in July offering a deal to bring Mr Rocher into the party.
The deal was that a WA minister would go into the Cabinet if the party agreed to re‐endorse Mr Rocher for the seat of Curtin.
"Staley would not have done that off his own bat," one Liberal source said.
"Tony was the emissary for Allan's good friend—the Prime Minister."
So we can have a WA cabinet minister from the Liberal Party if Allan is back in the show!
Why would Premier Court want to promote Senator Campbell? Because we know that there is real trouble for Liberal senators in preselections coming up in October and November.

The West Australian on 19 September states there is `serious jockeying for position by incumbents Sue Knowles and Ian Campbell' for the Senate spot. Why do we know that Senator Campbell is in trouble? Because he has let down the WA resources and prospecting industry over section 23(pa), as the parliamentary secretary at the table well knows.

So, why would Premier Court want to support someone who is letting down Western Australia so badly? Because they are both Noel Crichton‐Browne kids—they grew up in politics at the feet of Noel Crichton‐Browne. There is another Noel Crichton‐Browne kid—Senator Lightfoot—who is prepared to stand up for Western Australia. Today I received in my office a letter dated 26 September from Senator Lightfoot, senator for Western Australia. It is addressed to Senator Ian Campbell, senator for Western Australia, Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, and it says:

. . . it is still my unchangeable position, that the section 23(pa) should stay intacto within the present act. There are no possible suggested amendments that could replace that section, that will be either revenue positive, or recreate the incentive for prospectors to add to the Nation's mineral reserves wealth.

May I also add, that with the combination of Native Title, Diesel Fuel Rebate capping, the removal of 23(pa), the Western Australia Government's soon to be implemented Gold Royalty, a worrying number of miners are on their fiscal knees. As the Nation's biggest dollar earner, I am becoming increasingly uncomfortable with my Government's indifferent, even irresponsible attitude to the mining industry.

So let us hope, for the mineral and resources industries in WA, that Senator Campbell's disloyalty to the industry is not rewarded by a promotion into the cabinet over the Attorney‐General and over the Minister for Family Services. Senator Campbell does not deserve to be promoted on the basis that he has monstrously and massively let down the Western Australia mineral resources and prospecting industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about a school in the Richmond electorate—Kingscliff High School. This is a very progressive school which has over 1,150 students. The principal, Milton Simmons, has seen the school grow from 400 students from when he became the first principal of the school in 1986.

BREAK.PARA: One of the reasons for the success of the school is its initiative in reaching out to feeder schools. It has become a standard feature of the high school that students spend some time at feeder primary schools telling the pupils what the high school children are doing, especially in the environmental field. As Milton puts it, it is `kids teaching kids', and it has been very effective. They have been very proactive in environmental work and I fully support and encourage the principal, Milton Simmons, and a number of very professional and dedicated teachers.

At the school they have the Kingscliff Enviro Club and membership is about one‐third of the whole school from all age brackets. Their involvement with landcare projects includes dune regeneration work, reafforestation work at Kingscliff and river care. They won the NSW Landcare award in 1996, they were finalists for the Telstra Landcare Education Award in 1996, they won the Banksia Environmental Award in 1996, they were entrants in the NSW Landcare award this year and they are also now putting together a proposal for the United Nations Environment Programme Environmental Youth Forum for South Pacific and Asian nations.

There are three students in particular who attended the Australian Youth Forum at the Old Parliament House in Canberra whom I would like to mention: Lara Maciuk, Tammy McDonald and Kim Meighan. Several very positive decisions came out of the conference and particularly the proposal for a youth congress which would talk directly to government. These three and others from the Kingscliff High School are actively working to bring people in the Tweed Valley into environmental programs. They participate in the activities of the local Tweed Valley Family and Youth Support Service—run by David Neely who is doing a very good job as a youth officer—and set up a Tweed Coast Youth Council which meets every month at the Kingscliff High School. They are discussing not just environment issues but public transport, other activities and facilities for young people.

Lara Maciuk, a 16‐year‐old year 11 student was also nominated for the 1998 Young Australian of the Year Award for her environmental and youth work. This is the second year running she has been nominated for the award. She is a key member of the Kingscliff Enviro Club which, as I mentioned, were finalists in the NSW Landcare awards to be announced in November. She has represented Australia at the United Nations Youth Forum.

There are some other individuals, too, in the electorate that I should mention. Christopher Teitzel of Mount St Patrick's School in Murwillumbah has also been nominated for an award for a CD, Saving the Environment, which he produced and which was sponsored by the Total Catchment Management of the Tweed Valley. Melinda Schubert has been doing a CPA and has been nominated for a career achievement award.

The school's rugby union team won a country schools' competition—the Yeates Shield—in the electorate of Calare on 21 September. The good old Kingscliff school from the north coast stole the match away from Kinross Wolaroi, scoring twice in the last three minutes—almost as good as the rugby league game last week—31 to 29. I note that the son of the member for Calare (Mr Andren) was also playing in the local team but, unfortunately, the boys from the north coast beat them.

The school is also a leader in the performing arts. They have participated over the last six to seven years in the Coca Cola Schools Spectacular held at the Sydney Entertainment Centre which I am sure many of my Melbourne colleagues would know quite well. Also, many of the students are involved in the drama and entertainment fields.
In other areas of sporting achievements, this year Kingscliff High School won the secondary schools swimming titles. They won the girls' section—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good!

—I note the member for North Sydney was impressed by that. They also won a number of other competitions. So my congratulations go to the Kingscliff High School for doing an excellent job and I am delighted that this House sees fit to note that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is indeed lamentable that the Australian music industry is foreign owned and controlled, there are many Australian artists who record with these companies and the industry supports thousands of Australian jobs. As free trade and the so‐called level playing field are destroying our manufacturing and farming sectors, free trade in our music industry in the form of parallel importing will very likely do serious damage to the whole music industry and everyone it supports: production people, workers, and nearly 2000 music retailers—to name but a few.

SPEECH.PARA: The best case scenario for price reductions under the government's plan on new releases is only about $2 to $3 per CD. This minor saving would hardly seem worth the potential cost to the industry and Australian jobs. While reducing the cost of consumer goods is a worthy cause, many would say the human price is too high. A recent poll found that 85 per cent of Australians would pay a little more to save jobs and therefore have a better and more secure society.

There is also no guarantee that the price of CDs will fall. Considering that the deregulation of the banking sector has resulted in the highest bank charges—and the poorest service ever—just as with banking, the supposed savings may not even be passed on to the consumer.

We must also ask if this is just the first step in a broader breakdown of intellectual property rights in Australia—a situation that puts at risk all industries that depend on copyright, patent or trademark protection.

We should be wary of this government's intentions for the music industry. If it is the first step to a broader approach including patents and the like, we will all yet again feel the darkness of the shadow of our old enemy, the United Nations and its Lima declaration.

If the coalition is fair dinkum about reducing the price of CDs, as it promised at the last election, then it should do so by changing the inefficient sales tax regime which slugs business and consumers. Copyrights, like tariffs, protect Australian jobs and local industries, and jobs must be our No. 1 priority.

More jobs will lead to a more secure society with less crime, less substance abuse, less family breakdown and less suicide. Jobs in Australia will be created only by applying the principles of economic nationalism, while those of free trade will keep our country in a downward spiral. Governments have a lot to learn about ordinary Australians and what they are going through. I fear that these are lessons neither Liberal or Labor will ever learn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 July this year I conducted a youth forum on drugs at North Sydney Leagues Club. Students from nearly 21 local secondary schools as well as some prominent local guest speakers came along, including Alice Wood, who, at the age of 17, lost her 15-year-old sister, Anna, after she took an ecstasy tablet at a dance party, and Billy Moore, an Australian representative in rugby league who plays football for the local North Sydney Bears.

SPEECH.PARA: The discussion on this vital issue was forthright. I learnt from students that drugs such as marijuana and ecstasy are more common and accessible in our local schools than even I previously believed.

Gone are the stereotypical drug pushers who lurk in public toilets and laneways waiting for kids to finish school for the day. Now the dealers are students in the schools and, despite what older people may think, they no longer have to widely ply their trade. Students these days have more knowledge about where to get drugs than they do about what drugs actually contain and what they can actually do.

Some students at the forum spoke of peers who turn up to school stoned; others told of the frankness and openness with which marijuana use in particular is spoken about at school. Still others discussed the fairly sophisticated way in which credit for drug purchases is provided.

As our discussions continued, I was amazed at how undisturbed these students appeared to be about the presence of illegal drugs in their lives, both at school and at parties. The stereotypical North Shore student shows no real intrigue and is not unfamiliar with the different types of drugs available, nor the various methods of use.

But from almost all the approximately 40 students in the room I received an overwhelming message: fear campaigns such as the anti-smoking campaign are very effective. The ads show kids how uncool it is to smoke.

Currently, some influential figures in the lives of the average teenager send deadly messages. It could be a band like Oasis—who I happen to like—or singer Evan Dando, who put their song writing ability down to a permanent drug haze, or actor River Phoenix, whose death from a drug cocktail is attributed to merely `bad karma', that are inspiration for a student to give it a go.We need to fight back with a campaign illustrating how you can be successful, drug free and cool at the same time. We need some positive role models.

The second demand of students was for a real life education campaign that was not couched in the usual rhetoric of a `teacher knows best' classroom. On the real life effects of drugs, we all have much to learn. For example, I was surprised by Billy Moore's comment that as a professional footballer he cannot stay in a room where people may be smoking marijuana, because the smoke from a joint will penetrate the pores of his skin. Of course, with the random drug tests in professional sport this could mean the end of a sporting career.

In fact, it was a guest crown prosecutor who surprised students with a detailed treatise on exactly what goes into uppers like ecstasy, acid, and other laboratory manufactured drugs. He spoke of the contaminated backyard stills where drugs are mixed and cut with various substances in an environment that is a far cry from the sterile surroundings where legal pharmaceuticals are made. He concluded that if drug users could see and smell these garage factories they would not be so keen to ingest the finished products.

We must be honest with ourselves and our young Australians. There must be a certain degree of acceptance in this battle. Drugs are part of our community, like it or not. So let us teach our young people not merely that drugs are bad but that drugs can interfere with achieving long‐term goals and can bring about future health problems.

We should respond to the calls from students in my electorate with a two‐pronged attack. Firstly, we must prove to young Australians that drugs are uncool. Secondly, we must educate our youth and allow them to make informed decisions as mature, young adults. If we do not respond, then Anna Wood will be just one of many young people in our society who, after making a flippant and ill-informed decision, ended their lives in a manner which allowed them no opportunity to say, `This was a dumb idea after all.'
Question resolved in the affirmative.
