PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Firearms Program Implementation Bill had its genesis in the meetings of the Australasian police ministers in May and July of last year and, more particularly, the Port Arthur massacre of 28 April 1996. That massacre certainly encouraged the national campaign intended to bring in tighter gun laws in this country and to ensure a degree of uniformity.

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted at the outset that one of the main accomplishments of the campaign concerned the matter of uniformity. Until the action of the government, with the support of the opposition, we had had a mishmash of different regulations around this country which undermined the credibility and the effectiveness of gun laws.

If we go back to the period just after that massacre, we find there was a variation in regards to minimum ages. In Queensland it was 17 years and 13 years on farms. In the ACT it was 18 years for a full licence and no minimum age for club use. In the Northern Territory it was 16 to 18 years. There were different requirements in regards to registration. There were different waiting periods for licensing ranging from five days on renewal in New South Wales to 21 days in all cases in Tasmania, et cetera. As you can see, one of the problems this country faced was the question of a lack of consistency and therefore the ability of people to play off different state and territory regulations where they found restrictions or problems for themselves in obtaining arms.

When we talk about Port Arthur, whilst it was certainly a massive jolt to this country, it should not be seen in isolation from the broader problem of gun deaths in Australia. It is worth noting that in the period 1987 to 1996, or at least up until Port Arthur, 124 people in Australasia had been gunned down in these massacres. The massacres ranged from the November 1990 Aramoana, New Zealand, massacre of 14 people and a further 13 wounded, through to the more well‐known ones in this country, such as Hoddle Street and Strathfield.

There had been a clear problem in this country which, unfortunately, the political system failed to deal with. The reason it failed to deal with it was because a minority of people with very determined views were prepared to change their votes due to this one particular issue and so thwart the wishes of the majority of people.

All surveys in this country have shown the determination of the vast majority of people to support tougher gun laws. If we go back to 1978, nearly two decades ago, a Morgan poll showed that 88.8 per cent were for registration of shotguns and .22 rifles and only 8.1 per cent were against it. That shows there has been consistent support in this country for tougher gun laws. Unfortunately, there had been a degree of political opportunism in this country, but that did not arise in this case, I am pleased to say.

BREAK.PARA: There is a minority of people out there who possess guns. We all know that possession of guns leads to certain attitudes in regards to restrictions on registration, licensing, et cetera. There is a minority out there who are prepared to put their votes on the line because of this gun issue and try to control the political system by their willingness to ignore all other issues and, essentially, determine policy in this area.

The momentum after Port Arthur was assisted not only by the determination of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the preparedness of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) to stand by him, but, importantly, by the fact that the opposition did not choose to seek applause from that minority.

As early as 5 May, the opposition spokesman in this policy area, Senator Nick Bolkus, made a series of policy statements outlining where Labor stood in regard to tougher gun laws in this country. He called for the implementation of strict controls on the mail‐order sale of firearms; uniform standards of qualification and training for gun owners; uniform standards for the security and storage of firearms; and a requirement for authorised gun dealers to record all transactions, et cetera.

He also made very clear early on that the minister in this policy area in the previous government, the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), had already gone down a large part of this road that we have now reached. Essentially, what we have today are the kinds of measures that he had been pushing through at national ministerial meetings. There has been fundamental support from the major political parties in this system.

Those people who use the rhetoric of the silent majority, middle Australia, the majority of people et cetera, are the same people who will come into this parliament seeking to exploit that minority of people who feel victimised or feel that they suffer from having their rights taken away. The reality is that the majority of people very strongly support these rules.

It is extremely important that, at this stage, Australia has accomplished this. All surveys show internationally, particularly in the United States, that there is a clear correlation between attitudes in regard to gun laws and the question of ownership and possession of guns. Unless we bring in these kinds of laws to try to persuade the Australian electorate that you do not need a gun because you fear your next-door neighbour, you do not need a gun because you fear crime rates and you do not need a gun on the off-chance someone breaks into your home, we will have a situation, such as exists in the United States, where there are so many people with a vested interest in ownership that they are prepared to work actively within the political system to avoid restrictions and controls.

This action then takes place at a very important stage in this country. We know the situation in America, where the National Rifle Association, a hugely funded organisation, has been able to thwart most measures. There were the Baker changes in the last few years, but essentially the NRA has succeeded in inducing a tolerance of a gun culture in society. There are figures that indicate nearly half of American people fear guns. They feel that guns are a significant problem, not only in their community, but in their local schools. I think the figures show that around 30 per cent of people have actually heard a gunshot. That is the kind of situation that this legislation aims to tackle. That is the kind of legislation that we need at this stage.

The accomplishments are to have a compensation scheme through the Medicare levy increase for the surrendering of guns and for the operation of the various states' and territories' surrender and buyback schemes. Concurrently there is also finance towards a national education campaign in regard to guns. There is also the move towards uniform firearm laws, with the licensing of guns and the registration of owners. Related to this, there is an endeavour through the national exchange of police information et cetera to monitor the situation.

Amongst the matters that the opposition would raise in this particular piece of legislation today, which mainly deals with compensation paid for historically prohibited weapons, is the understanding that any surplus would be repaid. Certainly we appreciate that that is in the spirit, as the Attorney‐General pointed out, of what was intended. We endorse fully the attempt to pick up that point today.

The other matter is this question of the distribution of information. The Attorney‐General's Department, either alone or in conjunction with the Australian Council of Police Ministers, prepared in May of this year advice to the Attorney as to the degree of compliance of each state and territory with the resolutions agreed to by the Australian Council of Police Ministers. The opposition would appreciate if the Attorney‐General would table advice on the degree to which each of those administrations has accomplished what was sought and the degree to which the public has cooperated. If possible, it would be appreciated, from the point of view of ensuring continued bipartisanship in this policy area, that the Attorney‐General would provide that kind of material.
We do know that there has been a very significant level of compliance—in the area 550,000 to 600,000 weapons surrendered. I would—

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred and seventeen thousand, I am assured now.

—Thank you—as I said, in the area of 550,000 to 600,000 weapons. I put on the record the hope that those people who have not complied would still do so. It certainly is of concern that there are elements in the political system, actual elected representatives, who would still seek to run around the place trying to decry these laws—
—There are not many.

—Very few—as you note—who have basically described this as some kind of attack on rights and on liberties, and have conspiracy theories about supranational world governments and all those kinds of crackpot theories. There are people out there who, in other instances, are prepared to run around the place trying to make sure that young kids are gaoled for spitting at them or something, but, at the same time, are essentially saying that these laws are not important, that they are somehow different from other laws in this country and that people have more rights in this case to defy the elected legislature with regard to changing rules.

BREAK.PARA: It concerns me that there seems to be this tone out there that somehow, with regard to weapons possession, you have intrinsically greater rights than other people in terms of adhering to the law. I would like to put on the record a hope that, whilst there is obviously a degree of danger for our police force in enforcing these laws, like any other laws they have to be adhered to, they have to be respected and they have to operate. This was not done, as some people would suggest, as a knee‐jerk, politically opportunistic measure. It was undertaken because of a very obvious perceived need, because guns are a serious problem in any society.

It is important to reiterate that this is not just a matter of trying to deal with active criminality. The problem of guns is more pervasive in everyday society. The kinds of arguments that say that possession of a gun will be of advantage to the home owner with regard to burglaries are being absolutely demolished in US criminology work. The fact of life is that, in altercations where a gun is involved in burglary, a gun owned by the owner of the property more often than not is actually used on the owner by the person breaking in, because of the element of surprise.

That criminology work has been mainly by people like Zimring, who has done a lot of work in this area. He has also traced the lethal nature of guns and the fact that if one compares the degree of assaults involving the use of a knife and a gun, the gun is far more lethal. There is also a very clear correlation relating to availability. If you look at the United States, gun possession is far greater in the south than in the north, west and east, and there is a clear correlation there between gun suicides and gun homicides per capita.

In Australia we know the same point has been made. There has been concern by everyone in our political system about our levels of youth, and more particularly male, suicide. Again, if you look at the statistics on the nature of those deaths, the gun is certainly a very active participant and is essentially a far more useful vehicle for accomplishing that task.

Gun laws are critically related to the fact of life that most people are not killed by criminals or by their permanent or long‐term enemies. Most people suffer deaths through their neighbours, their friends, their family, their business partners, in spur of the moment altercations, often arising from trivial matters and with very little forethought. So the availability of a gun is critically related to the question of these deaths that might not have occurred if the gun was not available.

So, the opposition does endorse this measure. It understands fully that these kinds of laws were long overdue, that we had a very big hole in our system because there were different regulations, restrictions, licensing, and waiting times. All of these things fluctuated around the states of Australia and related either to the political facts of that state or, I guess, to some degree, to the culture of the state itself and the degree of power of the rural interests who obviously have a very understandable need in this area.

This legislation allows some continued access for primary producers and exemptions for occasional shooters who are licensed for feral animals. The opposition endorses the measure. It would like to see, as I said earlier, some material in regard to the monitoring of the various levels each state and territory has reached in regard to adherence to these requirements, and it hopes that the government will reiterate its earlier commitment to repaying any surplus from this measure. We know that at this stage there are still calculations to be made in regards to gun shop proprietors who have lost businesses through these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the main chamber the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) strikingly quoted from an editorial in the Australian. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the cumulative horror and disbelief felt by the public coalesced into a determination that Australia not allow a "gun culture" to take hold. It was this firm public resolution that John Howard articulated as a political leader.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has shown absolutely outstanding national leadership in relation to this issue of guns. When as a nation we were riveted by the tragedy at Port Arthur, the Prime Minister stepped forward without being concerned about political popularity, or winning a few votes, and made a very strong, immediate and public stand saying that enough was enough. Credit must also be given to the opposition for supporting the Prime Minister and the government in their determination to ensure that never again would we have a Port Arthur like tragedy.

BREAK.PARA: I am not known for standing in the parliament and rejoicing at the expenditure of huge amounts of public money, but I must say that I am particularly pleased that almost $300 million has been paid out by the government as a result of the firearms buyback program.

As I mentioned in an interjection when the honourable member for Reid was speaking, some 617,416 weapons have actually been handed in, and now Australia is a much safer place. It is, of course, with respect to this background that I am very pleased to join the debate on the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997 . This bill complements the earlier act, the National Firearms Program Implementation Act l996, which provided for the states and territories to be reimbursed for compensation paid by them in support of the national firearms program.

The response to the Port Arthur tragedy was indeed a national response. Most of the powers in relation to guns reside in the states and territories, but the Prime Minister and the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) were able to sit down with the police ministers from right around the country and decide that this gun culture was not going to continue and that we ought to have a national response which would ensure that there would be many fewer firearms out there in the Australian community.

The 1996 act proscribed a number of firearms which were prohibited as a result of the nationwide firearms agreement. It was interesting that when the guns buyback took place, there was a whole raft of other weapons out there in the community which were not in the minds of the police ministers when they had their conference in response to the Port Arthur tragedy. The states have actually handed out considerable amounts of money to collect other historically prohibited weapons, such as submachine guns, heavy machine guns and other similar weapons.

I understand in fact that in the Northern Territory, 22 aircraft cannons were surrendered in that jurisdiction. Technically, what has happened under the buyback is that the states and territories have actually paid out money that was not in accord with the 1996 act. They paid out to bring in weapons, not prohibited as a result of the police minister's agreement, that clearly were well within the spirit of that agreement.

That is why this very small, brief and concise bill has been introduced to the parliament by the government to complement the earlier legislation. The bill aims to ensure that the Commonwealth reimburses the states and territories for compensation that they have already paid for historically prohibited firearms or other weapons. In a sense, the states and territories have broken the law prior to the passage of this bill. At least, they have paid money given to them by the Commonwealth to bring these weapons in. Everyone in the Australian community believes that these weapons ought to be collected. If the states have gone out there and been proactive and collected weapons within the spirit of the 1996 agreement, clearly this government and this parliament should make sure that they are not out of pocket as a result of that very positive step.

There was some suggestion that the sole reason for the bill was that the Northern Territory needed to be reimbursed for the $460,000 it paid to the owner of the 22 aircraft cannons. That was certainly one instance. It has also been discovered that, in other states and territories of Australia, compensation has been paid for historically prohibited firearms. It is important that all states and territories be compensated for collecting these historically prohibited weapons.

Some people have also suggested that maybe this ought to have been an amendment to the 1996 act, but the government decided, on advice and after consideration, that it would be more concise and precise if a small specific act was brought in to meet this particular need. That is why we have got this clear, concise bill before the parliament, which certainly does the job.

Some people say, `The buyback ended yesterday. What's going to happen with respect to the reimbursement of the states and territories for moneys that they have outlaid not in accordance with the word of the previous law?' The simple facts are that provided these historically prohibited weapons have been surrendered by yesterday, the Commonwealth will be able to reimburse the states and territories with respect to those weapons surrendered. Even though this piece of legislation will not have proceeded through the parliament by 30 September, it will still be possible to compensate the states and territories.

There has been speculation, and it was mentioned by the previous speaker, that some members of the parliament are not happy with the national response to the firearms buyback. Overwhelmingly, regardless of political party—including some independents—we have spoken with one voice on this issue. The government, the opposition and most other members of the parliament were prepared to join together to ensure that there was an effective national response to the Port Arthur tragedy.

This was not done as a populist measure or with one eye on the next election; it was done as a matter of principle by the Prime Minister. The Australian people have overwhelmingly endorsed the government proposal. Interestingly, surveys indicate that over 78 per cent of adult Australians are in favour of gun laws and 56 per cent are strongly in favour of the new laws. Unlike many other pieces of legislation which seem to escape many members of the Australian community, overwhelmingly, Australians are aware that the federal parliament has acted, in conjunction with the states and territories, and 96 per cent of people are aware of these reforms. That may well be the reason that we have had some 617,416 weapons handed in and the reason that the Commonwealth has paid out $296,874,323 in compensation.

There were some people who said that Australians would bury their weapons, that they would do absolutely anything to avoid handing in these prohibited weapons. But I am very pleased that the Prime Minister and the Attorney‐General have both been proven correct and, overwhelmingly, the people with prohibited weapons have indeed complied with the law of Australia. This indicates that, as an Australian community, we are very responsible. I would like to commend those gun owners who have indeed acted in accordance with the law in handing in their weapons and receiving compensation.

I am particularly pleased to support this legislation, coming as it does just one day after the close of the buyback program. As was mentioned by the honourable member for Reid, the buyback was funded as a result of a temporary increase in the Medicare levy. Overwhelmingly, Australians supported this revenue raising measure as a means of fixing up what was a glaring national problem.
The Prime Minister must be congratulated, as must the Attorney‐General. And, in a spirit of bipartisanship, the opposition ought also to be congratulated for supporting the reforms of the government.

Returning to the bill, it is a very small bill and it complements the 1996 act. It does enable the states and territories to be compensated for the compensation that they have already paid with respect to historically prohibited weapons, including submachine guns, heavy machine guns and aircraft cannon, and other weapons which might not have been actually prohibited by the police ministers' agreement and which therefore were not approved for compensation under the 1996 bill. I am very pleased to commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have grave reservations about supporting the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill and can assure you it is quite controversial in my electorate. This bill will ensure that state governments will be able to dip into the Medicare funded cash pool to allow collectors to be compensated for older military style weapons surrendered under the national buyback scheme. We have reports of all sorts of old weapons being handed in under the scheme, ranging from anti‐aircraft guns to cannon and submachine guns.

SPEECH.PARA: I have strongly supported the gun buyback scheme; I do not back away from that. But I am reluctant to support this bill because I do not believe the majority of these old weapons pose a threat to society. I cannot see why taxpayers should have to give up their hard‐earned money for weapons that really do not pose a threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have already been surrendered.

—Just listen for a moment; I will explain what my particular problem is. What we are seeing is people, and in some cases government instrumentalities, cashing in on this scheme at taxpayers' expense. In my own electorate, there is great anger after the federal government owned Australian Defence Industries factory in Lithgow surrendered 160 unwanted firearms and was paid more than $400,000. ADI has defended this decision, claiming the company is a licensed firearms dealer and is legally entitled to compensation. I have argued that this is morally wrong and goes against the spirit of the buyback scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in rural areas like Lithgow there is already some opposition to the buyback scheme. This extremely unwise decision to sell off old military style weapons has only helped generate more anger and opposition to what is a very worthwhile scheme but one that has been extremely difficult to sell to rural people.

To make matters worse, it has since been confirmed to me by two former executives of the ADI Lithgow small arms factory that taxpayers have now forked out twice to have those particular weapons destroyed. Both former executives have said that the majority of weapons recently surrendered under the buyback scheme were from the Korean and Vietnam wars. ADI Lithgow was contracted by the army to destroy the weapons between 1969 and 1974 but it seems they were not destroyed.

Now we see the struggling factory, decimated under 13 years of Labor government administration, doing everything it can to stay in business—and, unfortunately, `everything' includes double‐dipping at taxpayers' expense. What we are seeing is a buyback scheme being used to purchase weapons that should have been destroyed years ago and that were safely kept under lock and key in a factory armory. Surely ADI has the means within its walls to shred these weapons and not dip into this public purse. As a great supporter of ADI Lithgow, it pains me to have to highlight this fact, but this decision has clearly angered the people of Lithgow as I am sure it should anger the people of Australia.

The rush to hand in weapons over the past few days under the buyback scheme has demonstrated that there are still vast numbers of firearms in homes across this country, and that many have been slow to take advantage of the amnesty. I would much rather see the amnesty extended and publicised for another month, to rid Australian homes of conventional low‐powered rifles and such, than see money spent buying antique military weapons that pose little or no threat at all. It is the presence of these low‐powered rifles that poses the greatest danger.

BREAK.PARA: One of the great legacies of the Port Arthur tragedy is that this shocking incident empowered the government of Australia to take action to restrict firearms and to ensure there are enforceable uniform laws in all states. Many misguided firearm owners still believe it is their constitutional right to bear arms. Of course, there is no such right, and with multipartisan support this government has shown that only people with a genuine need for firearms have any right to have one. The gun culture that many with vested interests try to promote has taken an enforced step backwards.

Most firearm owners I have been in contact with say they find the new laws fair and workable, and they have no problem complying. That particularly applies to farmers. In most cases it is only the absolute fanatics who are disenchanted with this law reform: people who cannot be satisfied with owning any gun, but feel they really must have one or several high‐powered deadly weapons.

Of course, there are also those collectors who have, I believe, a legitimate concern about the loss of their hard‐won and long‐cherished weapons, handed down from grandfathers and so on. I can appreciate their appreciation of the aesthetic form of these weapons, but say to them that, at the end of the day, a gun was designed to kill something. Unless we can get the most dangerous weapons out of the system, then we will not have achieved anything in the wake of Port Arthur.

There are still many high‐powered deadly weapons out there that have not been handed in. According to bush folklore there are hundreds, perhaps thousands, buried underground in PVC piping. For that reason, the critics of the buyback scheme have branded it a failure, and say the deadly weapons are still out there and there is nothing to stop another Martin Bryant going on the attack.

Mr Deputy Speaker, they are wrong. In New South Wales around 150,000 automatic and semiautomatic firearms have been handed in. That is a magnificent figure, and will ensure the lives of many ordinary Australians are saved. Thankfully, the Martin Bryants of this world are extremely rare. Most people who are killed by firearms are not victims of mass shootings like Port Arthur. They are everyday mums and kids, killed in the heat of a domestic dispute, perhaps; or people caught up in the child support system at the moment—a system that I hope is finally getting some sort of reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nowhere near enough, though.

—Nowhere near enough, no. These people are struggling farmers or troubled youths on the farm, who in a moment of depression desire to take their lives, where unfortunately a firearm is easy to access and ends their life before they even have time to have a second thought. As a former rural journalist I am very familiar with the enormous curse of suicide in country Australia—as are many, many members in here, and not only rural members. I see in our midst the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who has a true and deep appreciation of this tragedy.

BREAK.PARA: In my former job, how many times did I do the police rounds over the years, hearing of a fatality only to be told there were no suspicious circumstances. `No suspicious circumstances' is police terminology for suicide; and traditionally, unless there is a well‐known person involved, these suicides go unreported in the media in this country. So they should, although the statistics should be highlighted and semaphored as much as we possibly can; but exploitation of the tragedy of suicide for news purposes is something that I certainly never engaged in.

As a rural journalist for the best part of the last 20 years, and with rural Australia in crisis for much of that period, I am very familiar with how many of these deaths there are. They are deaths that, unlike Port Arthur, do not make the nightly news.

A study published in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1991 shows exactly how prevalent these non‐headline grabbing killings really are. An examination of coronial reports in the Brisbane region during the 1980s revealed 587 firearm deaths, including 76 per cent suicides, 18 per cent murders, with the remainder accidental. Of the murders where the perpetrator was identified, 71 per cent of victims were killed by someone known to them. It was often a spouse, jilted ex‐boyfriend, family member, friend or neighbour. It is an established fact that the most common perpetrators of gun violence are not criminals or crazy people. They are people otherwise known as `normal responsible gun owners' who kill either themselves and/or people close to them.

For the gun lobby to warn of invading hordes from Indonesia, or the need to protect yourself from home invasions and the like, is nothing more than a nonsense really, born of the insecurity in our community and largely of the fact that there are so many guns out there in the first place. The buyback scheme will save lives.

Another ridiculous argument of the gun lobby is that most people who have handed in firearms have then gone out and bought new ones. This claim has come at the same time as gun shop owners say they are going broke. Only last week the owner of Carrington Firearms in Dubbo, one of the best known dealers in western New South Wales, was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as having sold only two guns in the last few months. This exposes the gun lobby's lies. The fanatics cannot have it both ways. The shop owners say they are not selling firearms. This talk of people replacing old guns with new ones, I believe, is incorrect.

As I said earlier, I strongly support the gun buyback program, but this bill takes it all one step too far in the eyes of many people in my electorate. In some respects, it is catching up with the horse after it has bolted because I know that, as in the case of Lithgow ADI, the compensation has already been wrongly paid and wrongly directed.

I think this amendment really directs funds that could be better used to extract other lawful weapons from the community rather than being used for this government instrumentality to top up its income—from one hand of government to the other. I realise it will be passed on the voices but, in my case, it will be with great reservation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened very carefully to the sincere speech by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren). It is yet another one of his many sincere contributions since he entered this place and I always find it a pleasure to listen to him.

SPEECH.PARA: I imagine a lot of us, as members, have had many letters from people who you could say have been part of the gun culture which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), by his leadership on this issue, has sought to dispel in the community. Unfortunately, one or two very extreme individuals in that group have written to me.

One individual, whom I shall name, is a Mr Stuart Willis from Samford who wrote a diatribe of letters to me over a number of months. Most of the time they were five or six pages and full of absolute balderdash and rhetoric and almost unintelligible. But in recent times, because I stood up to some of the rubbish that he was writing to me and took him on, he decided by way of payback to write an anonymous letter to the local paper in grossly defamatory terms about me. Unfortunately for him, I recognised the writing style, which was all too obvious, and Mr Willis will be feeling the force of some responses by way of legal proceedings in due course for his efforts.

I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as much as anyone else, have had a good deal of correspondence about this issue. We all know how hard it has been for the government and for some genuine members of the community. I am a gun owner myself. I live on a property and I need weapons because I have dingoes, foxes, and sick stock which need to be put down. It is necessary for me to have weapons. Therefore, I have applied for a licence. I put in my application last Friday and I hope it will be accepted. I did have a licence previously, of course. The application is for the basic weapons, not the fancy weapons; it is for a .22, a shotgun and a .303.

One aspect of the overall legislation, if I might say by way of comment, involves a leap too far. I have had a number of complaints from constituents, one of which I really have to mention to the House. This particular constituent had been bequeathed two air rifles by his grandfather. He had never so much as polished the oil off the barrels in about 30-odd years, yet he has had to hand in these rifles. It seems to me that that was one situation where the buyback scheme went too far.

I remember the comment that was made earlier by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) about the aircraft cannons which had to be handed in. They were World War II cannons and $440,000 was paid for 22 of them. One would really wonder whether that was catching too many fish in the net, as it were.

There have been some anecdotal stories of weapons that have sat on display for many years—old cannons and old bits and pieces of machine guns and so forth—having to be pulled out of their stocks, having to be unbolted and handed in. You do tend to wonder a little bit about that.

What I wanted to turn my attention to specifically was a particular constituent who has been hurt very badly by the events that occurred and by the subsequent legislation. His name is Mr John Peterson. He has a business in my electorate called Queensland Combined Arms Technologies and it is located at 30 Duntroon Street, Brendale.

Mr Peterson and his wife have been building up the company over a number of years. In more recent times they have achieved some success in their business by the development of certain moulds used in the manufacture of stocks for weapons. The revenue from the sale of these stocks provided a regular income to the company. It is a little business. Like so many small businesses in this country, it depends for its existence on the incredible effort and time that is put in by a husband and wife team. Also, the assets that they own are used to support and maintain the business.

The income generated was used over a period of time in the development of a semiautomatic weapon with a view to selling it to the Australian army as a training weapon. There was also interest from the Thai government in relation to the development of this particular weapon. The company was involved in the tender process.

However, after the Port Arthur massacre and the subsequent events, demand for weapons Australia‐wide dropped dramatically and the income previously generated by the sale of the synthetic stocks was reduced to a near non‐existent level. As a result, the company was forced to withdraw from the tender process, thereby denying itself the possibility of a significant profit from the sale of the weapons. The company, in effect, has been put in grave jeopardy by these measures.

BREAK.PARA: The question really is whether or not he can get compensation and that is a real question in this particular case. A compensation claim was subsequently made on behalf of the company to the firearms compensation division of the Queensland Police Service. Compensation was sought in respect of the moulds and related to their value, which was established by professional valuers.

The Queensland Police Service wrote to my constituent through his solicitor on 25 September this year to the effect that the items of equipment contained did not fall within the parameters of stock items being compensated for under the Queensland firearms compensation scheme for licensed dealers. Items being compensated for under the scheme are broadly confined to restricted firearms and parts and accessories specific to those firearms, not equipment used in the manufacture of those items. The letter goes on to say that items used in the manufacture of firearms or firearm components are clearly included under the auspices of the loss of business program in Queensland. The operational components of this program are being managed by Price Waterhouse. The company was invited to present a case for consideration by Price Waterhouse under the loss of business compensation program.

In effect, under the claim that was made, this amounted to a letter of rejection and it was suggested that the alternative process—by loss of business compensation—should be pursued. The problem, as the company sees it, is the very restricted models for valuation of the business that have been prepared. In other words, a very narrow and restricted model for valuation has been prepared by Price Waterhouse. As I have indicated, this company is a registered dealer and, as such, it is entitled to make a claim for loss of business under the program. However, the models produced for assessment of value of business are drafted in such a way as to relate to dealers and not specifically to manufacturers.

I ask the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) to look into this. The company fears that the limited compensation models will prevent a fair and reasonable payment to the company in respect of its loss of business. This fear is a well grounded one, it would seem.

The National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997 provides that the Attorney‐General may authorise the payment to a state of amounts by way of reimbursement for qualifying compensation paid by the state. It therefore seems to me, having regard to the bill, that there is an opportunity or there is a discretion perhaps that is open for the Attorney‐General to authorise the compensation payment by the state to an applicant in respect of items which were not specifically covered in the buyback program. Thus, arguably there is a possibility that this could be extended to include compensation to be paid in respect of the moulds. The company believes that the government has already made payments to others in respect of surrendered moulds. I do not have information in relation to that; that is a belief that the company instructs me about.

It is no overstatement to say that this company is teetering on the brink. With it goes the livelihood of the people who own the business, Mr and Mrs Peterson, as well as the assets they have used to support the business in its trading position. Its trading position has suffered considerably and its somewhat buoyant and prospectively exciting role of being able to be a supplier of specific and very discrete weapons, both to the Australian Army and to Thailand, has been very much eroded and, indeed, probably eliminated by the effect of the measures that the government has introduced.

I ask the government, and the Attorney in particular, to look into this matter. I intend to take it up with him personally. I ask whether or not this situation can be compensated so that the Petersons' business may survive or, at the very least, that they will receive some compensation which will help them to save their home and their assets, because it is so serious that their business could well and truly go under as a result of what has occurred.

I have met Mr Peterson on a number of occasions. He is a genuine and balanced individual. He has made proper and consistent representations, both to me and to a particular staff member in my office who has been dealing with this matter in a very competent way. As well, he has been acting through a solicitor whom I know personally and who is very competent. So I ask that this particular matter be given some attention to see whether or not the bill and the Attorney can provide for the exercise of a discretion to cover a person who is in this situation.

Having regard to all of the matters to which I have referred, I do support these measures. But I say to the House that there have been some unexpected and unintended consequences for some people who have been hurt as a result of their business activities prior to the tragedy and prior to the subsequent events. I ask the Attorney to bear these matters in mind in exercising his discretion ultimately in respect of this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians have always had reasonable access to firearms, and law‐abiding citizens have always had an understandable expectation that individual ownership would continue, as indeed would the facility for them to pursue their sporting pastime. This reasonable expectation has lost ground daily. Australian firearm owners quite rightly believe the day is coming when the civilian population will be disarmed and only those who break the law will possess firearms.

SPEECH.PARA: The uniform gun laws were ill‐conceived and rushed through without thought or consultation. Any proposed need has no basis in fact and is an affront to anyone who is even slightly informed of the facts and figures. Dr Adam Graycar, from the Australian Institute of Criminology, has stated that banning semiautomatic firearms will do nothing to prevent the majority of Australian gun deaths.

While I would certainly not advocate illegitimate ownership of such firearms, we cannot escape the fact that even just in the case of centre‐fire semiautomatic rifles, the majority of which are military style, there are in excess of a million such firearms in Australia, yet this style accounts for less than two per cent of Australian firearm deaths.

Despite the free access to millions of firearms in Australia, the available data shows the number of murders committed with firearms since 1979 has been in a steady downward trend, despite the rise in murders generally over the same period. It should also be acknowledged that this period of general decline covered the peak years of importation for the so‐called military style semiautomatic firearms. In fact, this period shows that an average of 92 murders, or 20 to 30 per cent of the total murders committed each year, were carried out with firearms. Many more people are murdered by other means.

Since 1990, there has been a rapid increase in murders committed with sharp instruments. These alone far outnumber murders with firearms for the same period—again, despite the vast availability of firearms. Even when looking at suicides, where there is an alarming increase in incidence, you will find a steady downward trend in the use of firearms. Available information shows that since 1979 suicides have increased nearly 45 per cent but use of a firearm to commit suicide has gone down by over 25 per cent. Since 1970, suicide with a firearm has dropped from nearly 30 per cent of all suicides to about 17 per cent.

Removing completely inoperable guns from our war museums and paying compensation in excessive amounts is probably one of the more foolish examples of this government's agenda. The act of removing rusty, non‐working machine guns from museums is contributing to erasing our history and will not save a single life. A person in Darwin was paid nearly $½ a million for 20‐millimetre cannons from fighter planes. Considering that the current removal of firearms from private ownership was largely targeted at centre‐fire semiautomatics, and less than two per cent, or 10 firearm‐related deaths a year are attributable to this style of firearm, is the $500 million buyback coupled with the unaccountable costs justifiable in the context of the variety of weapons used to commit murder, and the many causes of accidental deaths?

Perhaps as many as 50,000 Australians die each year through the effects of diseases caused by alcohol and tobacco. What impact would the $500 million have had in reducing these horrendous figures. Each year, countless thousands die in road accidents and in all manner of other activities, yet are we to believe that these and the deaths from alcohol and tobacco are somehow more acceptable because so many people drink and smoke and drive? There are millions of firearms and firearms owners, but despite the vast numbers and the amount of use, in context, the number of deaths is relatively low, and the government's approach cannot be justified.

Bear in mind that removing firearms from law‐abiding citizens will most likely impact only upon accidents, and in this case, there are only about 15 fatalities each year. One thousand people die each year from accidental falls, and 250 drown. There was no gun debate, as such. There was no consultation or concern for the facts, merely misinformation shoved down the throats of an understandably emotional public.

This has been a political exercise, pure and simple, with no reduction in the amount of firearms in society. In fact, quite the contrary has occurred, as the figures show. For every firearm turned in, approximately 1.7 modern firearms have been purchased with the compensation. There is also the issue of the number of firearms that have literally gone underground.

The returns do not begin to count for the estimated number of firearms. In particular, hundreds of thousands of military style semiautomatics would seem to be missing. It is time we acknowledge that crime is caused by economic desperation and helplessness, unemployment, loss of hope, family breakdown, substance abuse, and cultural conflicts—not by firearms ownership.

The Swiss experience is, perhaps, the best example. In Switzerland, there are more firearms and fewer deaths than in Australia. The majority of firearms in that country are military weapons—millions of them. It is only when we, as one nation, address these issues together that crime will reduce. Violence and crime are not proportional to the availability of firearms; they are directly linked to the security and decency of our society. Governments that pretend otherwise are looking to hide the true causes of the situation and escape the responsibility for addressing the real issues and, therefore, they perpetrate a lie on their people.

Saving lives, or reducing crime, was obviously not behind the government's attacks on the private ownership of firearms. Indeed, they are guilty of the crime of using an emotional period for political purposes. Have no doubt, the buyback has failed. There are now more firearms out there than before, and many are modern and potentially more deadly than the firearms they replaced. It seems that most Australians have not handed in their firearms, and be assured, absolutely no criminals have complied.

What does the government intend to do with the millions of Australians who have not complied? Will Australia become a police state with homes systematically raided and property confiscated? Will the government harass, fine and gaol otherwise innocent law‐abiding Australians. History has shown that only the worst kind of government disarms its people. I stand by my belief that Australians have the right to defend themselves and their families in their own homes. Shooting is a legitimate sport and pastime, and participants should be treated accordingly. Disarming law‐abiding Australians is not in the national interest and will do nothing to reduce crime. An honest government would take heed, so we can be sure this one is not listening.

Simply put, it should be remembered that, during the last election campaign, the current government used the slogan: `enough is enough'. Be assured that the firearm owners of Australia are tired of unwarranted and unjustified interference. They are tired of being used as political scapegoats and of being the victims of United Nations treaties. You can be assured that Australia's firearm owners have adopted the Liberal‐National coalition slogan because that is exactly how they feel, that enough is enough. Always remember, outlaw firearms and only outlaws will have them.
