SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reassure the clerks that it will not be necessary to reset the clocks, because I will not be requiring my full time. My children frequently make fun of dad cracking the camera, but this is taking that jibe just a little far!

SPEECH.PARA: I do welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate, and I want to do so by picking up some of the remarks made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), who preceded me in the debate. In reflections on the question of gun ownership in Australia that did not surprise any one of us, the member for Oxley implied not only that the scheme has been a failure, but that it was the intention of the government to disarm Australia with the legislation that followed the Port Arthur massacre, and that that intention has failed because Australians have successfully rearmed; so the scheme has been a failure, and there are more weapons in Australia than there were prior to the legislation being introduced. That was the first of her themes.

The second of her themes was that effectively, since alcohol, tobacco, cars and sharp instruments killed more people than guns, the government in some way had been inconsistent in applying this gun legislation and not legislating effectively, in her view, against the carnage caused by alcohol, tobacco and road accidents.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let me tell you, this chamber and the member for Oxley that it was not the intention of the government to disarm Australia. The legislation that was introduced following the horrific Port Arthur massacre was introduced because the federal government recognised the responsibility that it and every Australian government had to ensure that the innocent would be adequately protected.

BREAK.PARA: If the intent of the federal government had been to disarm Australia, Australia would have been disarmed. But as a member for a rural electorate, with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) sitting here on my left, let me hasten to reassure everybody that neither I nor anyone that I am aware of within the coalition—and, I would suspect, no‐one in the opposition either—sought at any stage to disarm Australia.

When the rumours about disarming Australia were running so rife I was one who said to the Attorney‐General, `I hope you are not intending by some sort of underhand method to disarm Australia, because I am not going through all of this agony again if this is only step 1.' Of course, that was not his intent. It was not the intent of the government, nor was it the intent of the opposition.

What effectively has happened, counter to the general theme of the speech of the member for Oxley, is that in Australia today we probably have very nearly as many weapons as we had prior to the Port Arthur massacre. That does not cause me any alarm. As far as I know, it does not cause the Attorney‐General any alarm. He will have an opportunity to respond in just a moment.

What we have succeeded in doing is removing a large proportion of what were the most antisocial weapons out of the community and replacing them with those that are legal. I am not bothered that people who surrendered firearms and were compensated have used that compensation money in many instances to acquire another firearm. That does not bother me at all. I expected that to happen. The firearm they have acquired, however, is not as antisocial as was the firearm they surrendered and it is a firearm that, by the very nature of the acquisition under this legislation, will now be both licensed and recorded so that the law enforcement agencies know where that weapon is and in whose hands it is held. That is a dramatic step forward.

It is just absurd to draw any sort of analogy between the firearm legislation and the other difficulties that we have in common with every other society as a result of drugs or alcohol or cigarettes or even knives. No‐one is proposing that the government, for example, should legislate against knives so that we cannot consume meals except with forks. Even a fork in the wrong hand could be seen to be lethal in one form or another.

Furthermore, the government has not ignored, as the member for Oxley would suggest, the antisocial implications of alcohol, drugs and tobacco. Quite on the contrary! Both sides of the parliament have been quite adventurous in the way that they have dealt with ensuring that the laws across Australia for drugs somehow are enforceable from state to state and ensuring that road tragedy laws become increasingly reinforced from a common perspective. What has been done with the legislation that was introduced following the Port Arthur massacre is simply that we now have a situation where uniform laws apply across Australia.

I participate in this debate as a South Australian, as someone from a state whose gun laws were seen to be relatively effective. But even in South Australia, the management is dramatically enhanced of weapons that no‐one—not even the member for Oxley—would want in Australia and weapons that ought to have been illegal across the entire nation because of their military characteristics. Whereas, prior to the Attorney‐General's action, any South Australian could have a neighbouring land‐holder across the border store those weapons for them, in October 1997 we are in a situation where wherever you place that weapon it is illegal unless licensed. The full force of the law will be brought against you if you are found to be in possession of it.

That is a dramatic step forward—a step that not just the government but the parliament and the Attorney‐General ought to be commended for as well. It is simply nonsense to paint a picture of legislation seeking to disarm Australia. It is simply nonsense to run some sort of conspiracy theory that suggests that somehow we are going to leave the citizens of Australia more vulnerable to attack as a result of this legislation. It is nonsense because the citizens of Australia remain in a position where they have access to legal firearms as they need them and nonsense because there is no sense in which one can expect to be defending the nation sitting in your front lounge poking an automatic weapon through the window at someone who is or would be an intruder. If Australia is genuinely under attack, its defence will come clearly from the full force of the military. Any other form of defence is nothing more than offensive in terms of keeping a cohesive and effective society.

The legislation before the House deals, of course, with much more than the events that have followed the Port Arthur massacre. It has been a necessary amendment brought in by the Attorney‐General because of action in the Northern Territory where the acquisition of 22 aircraft cannon warranted some additional compensation beyond the act and hence this legislation. This has been brought in with the support of both the government and the opposition, recognising that this amendment allows us to complete what was part of the firearm buyback in Australia, that it covers an anomaly that had arisen in the Northern Territory, and that it is part of a scheme that has allowed us to take over 600,000 firearms out of the community at the cost of not quite $300 million.

By any measure, Australia is a safer country because of the action taken by the government and the opposition and by the vigorous actions of Attorney‐General following the Port Arthur massacre. No-one pretends that risk has suddenly been eliminated from Australia, but one of the risks, the mowing down of innocent people as occurred at Port Arthur, has been dramatically reduced through this legislation. Not to have done what we have done would have been an act of gross negligence on the part of the parliament. Parliamentarians should be proud of the action that they have taken in the face of some community hostility. It was action that was taken courageously, recognising that it is in the community interest.

As the representative of a rural electorate, there is one other issue that I must address before I sit down, and it is this. It is absurd to suggest that farmers have in some way been disadvantaged by the legislation that was introduced following the Port Arthur massacre. In fact, access to bolt action weapons is still readily available to any farmer at any time, and exemptions are in place so that where an appropriate automatic weapon is needed then farmers can acquire it.

There is no cause for concern on the part of the rural community. There is no cause for concern on the part of those who have a sporting interest in firearms because as a result of being a recognised member of an appropriate firearm club, they too can have access to the weapons they need to participate in various sporting events. Anyone with a legitimate need for a weapon that is seen to be not of the antisocial group that the original legislation was designed to prohibit still has access to those weapons.

I am pleased to be a part of a government that has acted courageously not to trim the rights of Australians, and to ensure that innocent Australians are protected from the sort of horror that we witnessed at Port Arthur. I recognise that this legislation is a step towards ensuring that an anomaly that occurred in the Northern Territory can also be addressed as part of the guns buyback scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak today on the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997 . The greatest reason for the nationwide guns buyback scheme was the tragedy at Port Arthur in Tasmania on 28 April 1996. There is a lot of debate saying that this government or this parliament has disarmed the country. However, debate on this guns issue has been in the community for many years. As far as the whole issue is concerned, I congratulate both sides of the House because of the fact that people were prepared to work in a bipartisan way to ensure that this country's future is well protected.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirty‐five people were killed and many people were wounded when Martin Bryant used his high‐powered semiautomatic weapon. As a result of this tragedy, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) immediately announced that the Commonwealth government would buy back all military style self‐loading rifles, pump action shotguns and other semiautomatic weapons. People have not only handed in all those different types of weapons, but we have also seen submachine guns and, of course, World War II aircraft cannons as well.

The guns buyback scheme has been a great success, with more than 600,000 firearms being handed in for destruction and compensation. To say that the parliament wanted to disarm the country is crazy. Australians can still own firearms. I have heard people in the debate today say that it was not a great success. People have to understand that the government was only chasing a particular style or set of weapons. It is as simple as that.

If you want to own a gun, you can still own a gun. It is as simple as that. Whether it is for sporting or for feral animal eradication on your property—whatever it is—if you want to own a firearm and it is within the legal category, you can still have it. If, on the other side of the fence, you want something that is in the illegal category and you have a legitimate reason and you can support that, once again, you can have that weapon.

As far as I am concerned, this will make Australia a safer place to live. Of course, there are still many guns out there in the community; there may be some illegal ones as well. There are a lot less of them than there were before and I consider that to be a good thing. I have spoken to a lot of people in the community—and I will keep using this word `emotion'—and now that the emotion has been removed from the debate somewhat, people are starting to say, `Well, gee, this isn't such a bad thing after all.'

I still get faxes and letters from some people, including constituents in my electorate who believe the gun buyback scheme has not worked and there are still thousands of illegal guns in the community. I hope this is not right. I have attended many gun rallies since the inception of the gun debate. I have attended both sides of the argument. I understand the pain and the passion of many people over this issue. Most gun owners are decent, responsible people and the majority of Australians will agree that change had to happen, especially in relation to a prohibited persons register. At the end of the day, if somebody is not of sound mind and they should not have a firearm, then that should be exactly the case. They should not have a firearm.

The whole issue has caused a lot of angst in the community. Fair enough, this is a democratic society. We should all have the right to express ourselves. There are some out there in the community who have tried to use the debate for their self-gain and self‐promotion. I consider it is terrible that people are prepared to use this debate for their own devices. I ask people to look very closely at those who try to use it for their own self-gain. Make sure you look and go all the way into the debate, because, once again, the emotion of the issue is what has caused a lot of the heartache.
I handed my own gun in the other day and I received a considerable amount of compensation. I do not mind saying that I only paid $300 for my semiautomatic shotgun and I received $730 compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You made a profit.
—That is right, exactly. I must say the compensation that was received from the government actually took some of the pain away. I thought it was not such a bad thing after all.
—He's honest.
—That is it. Ultimately at the end of the day, I did rather well out of the gun buyback scheme and I walked away not unhappy at all. I thought, `Okay, maybe it was not such a bad thing after all.'

SPEECH.PARA: If there were to be change at the eleventh hour, maybe I would have liked to have seen people who have applied for licences in relation to illegal weapons before 30 September and have been knocked back and had to hand their gun in still get compensation. We never know where that may end up somewhere in the future. Maybe there are opportunities.

On the whole I was not excited about handing my gun in. But once you take the emotion out of the debate and sit down and accept that this is now the law and it must be adhered to, it is simple as that. Basically as far as guns are concerned, I still have my 243 bolt action rifle. It is licensed. I am allowed to have it. It is as simple as that. I say to one and all—the people out in the community—this was not all about disarming Australia, takeover bids from other countries and this world order and so forth. If you want to own a gun and you can verify that you fall into the correct category, you can still have a gun. We had to remove those weapons that can cause mass destruction and were not acceptable in today's society.

On the other side of it, we see our gun clubs. Gun clubs have prospered from this. I think it is a great initiative. We can have community policing in society. Some people may not be able to have a weapon or a rifle, owing to the fact they do not have large amounts of land to shoot on. Now they have to be a member of a club. People will now see them mixing in society, with their rifles, when they go to sporting shoots. Now you can actually police people to see whether they are worthy to have that rifle. This form of community policing is very acceptable; it has gone a long way.

As far as I am concerned, at the end of the day, the legislation has gone through. There was a lot of hype and emotion at the start of the debate, but now that it is drawing to a close I certainly believe that people are starting to accept the legislation. As I said, if you want to own a gun, you can still have one.

TALK.START.PARA: —This National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997 complements the National Firearms Program Implementation Act 1996. The thrust of this bill is to ensure that the Commonwealth can reimburse the states and territories for compensation paid for historically prohibited firearms or other weapons. It will provide the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) with the authority to certify that the surrender of certain firearms or other weapons is consistent with the spirit of the national program and it will allow the Attorney‐General to authorise that the states and territories be reimbursed for the compensation paid for such firearms.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that the Attorney‐General has put a lot of effort into implementing the whole firearms buyback scheme in a very fair and balanced way. It is important that what we see is that the government, led very ably by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and strongly supported by the Attorney‐General and the states—and, I must also acknowledge, by the opposition—has put in place what, in general terms, has been something very beneficial for Australia. I also have to support the comments of my colleague and good friend the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) when he pointed out the nonsense of some of the things that were being said by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), particularly any suggestion that this move by the government is in some way to try to disarm the civilian population of Australia.

I come to speak to this bill as someone who has had a keen interest in firearms ownership for many years. I have, in fact, held a licence for 30 years. I have been a member of the Field and Game Association for more than 25 years. I was honoured to be asked by the Prime Minister to chair the Firearms Consultative Committee, which looked at certain details of the implementation of the firearms buyback scheme.

It is important that we should always recognise the dual expectations of the community. There is no doubt that the Australian community was absolutely rocked by the tragedy of Port Arthur. I think the Australian community was extremely impressed by the decisive leadership that the Prime Minister showed following that tragedy, and he was strongly supported, right across the political landscape. What the Prime Minister set out to do was to remove undesirable firearms from the community and, as well as that, to ensure that Australia did adopt uniform laws. The other aspect was to give much greater recognition to the need for a responsible approach to firearm ownership. On that point, those who have demonstrated a responsible approach should be able to continue to have that ownership and to pursue the use of the firearms in a responsible and legitimate way.

When we saw the drama of Port Arthur, it raised a very real community fear. It certainly was a terrible tragedy. But what it did do with the vast majority of firearms owners, who are responsible people, was to cast a question mark over them as to why they should continue to own firearms. Yet when you look at the safety record of the vast majority, when you look in particular at the safety record of gun clubs, I think they can demonstrate that they have in fact carried on their sport in a very responsible manner. At the same time, we should continue to recognise that legitimate shooting is a sport that is pursued not only within Australia but internationally. Australia was very well served by three medallists at the recent Olympic Games. There were two gold medals—one to Russell Mark and one to Michael Diamond—and a bronze to Desiree Huddleston. All of them achieved the pinnacle of their sport and did it in a way that made Australia proud.

There is also a very strong and legitimate reason for farmers to continue to have firearms, particularly in dealing with vermin such as foxes, pigs, rabbits, but also, at times, to deal with an odd animal that gets deranged, shall we say. I have had an occasion myself to go and borrow a neighbour's .303 to get rid of a bull that had flipped its lid and was totally uncontrollable. It was the only way we could deal with it. It did not matter what other method we tried, the only humane way to get rid of it was to shoot it with a .303. That is always going to be a problem. I think that all of us are aware of occasions when cattle have lost control and caused the death of individual farmers, and farmers are going to continue to need that last resort—which is all it is; but access to that last resort, nonetheless.

I would like to talk a bit about the tightening of the laws. While I certainly endorse what has been done, and I certainly agree with the move for uniformity, I think that it highlights also the importance of safe storage of firearms. We have heard a number of speakers already talk about the need to see firearms probably stored in a locked cabinet, or whatever, depending on the type of firearm. We have also seen, as has been mentioned, the growth in clubs which encourage the safe and responsible use of firearms. But the concern I have is that, notwithstanding the move to uniformity, there has not been a uniformity in the administering of some of the legislation.
In Victoria we have had a situation where the state government has not administered these laws in quite the same way as other states. I will just give you a quote from a constituent of mine who said:
I am a policeman with twenty years experience. I am a trained firearms instructor with the Victorian Policeforce . . . I have 36 years involvement with firearms—
He goes on to say:
We now have a system which creates confusion, frustration and inexcusable delays—

And he goes on to outline some of the frustrations that he feels as someone who has been a responsible gun owner and enforcer of the law. He is certainly—and I have spoken to him—far from happy with the way that the laws are being administered. There are many examples which I will not go into in the time available, but we could elaborate at another time.

The second thing that does concern me in the follow‐up to what has happened is that, while it is true that we have now seen over 600,000 firearms surrendered, the surrender rate seems to vary quite a lot between states. When we look at the official numbers that have been very kindly released by the Attorney‐General today, and we compare the ratio of the number of firearms surrendered with the number of registered voters, we find that the rate does vary quite considerably. For example, in Tasmania, the rate is 9½ per cent of the number of firearms compared with the number of registered voters. In the Northern Territory it is similar—9.3 per cent. Then it drops in Victoria to 6.9 per cent, and down further in Queensland to 5.9 per cent. Then we go to Western Australia, 4.3 per cent; South Australia, 5.2 per cent; New South Wales, 3.6 per cent, and the ACT, 2.4 per cent.

What I wanted to highlight from that is that there is quite a big difference between the highest rate of handing in and the lowest rate of handing in, particularly when we look at states like New South Wales. The concern I raise is that I find it difficult to believe that the ownership of guns varies so significantly between the states. It raises very serious questions as to whether states, such as Victoria and South Australia, and the others that have had high rates of hand in, where there has been firearm registration for some years, have had a higher rate of handing in than has occurred in those states that have not had firearms registration up until now. I believe that this is a matter that the Attorney‐General would probably like to take up again with the police ministers, and I will come back to that in a minute.

The other point that has come through very loudly and clearly is that gun ownership is very much a regional issue. By that I mean that people living in country areas have a much higher rate of gun ownership than those living in the city, and probably for very understandable reasons. I do get rather sick of the anti‐gun lobby, most of whom seem to sit smugly in city citadels such as universities. They go on with their unctuous branding of all firearm owners as inferior citizens. They go even further sometimes and suggest that they must have some sort of personalty deficiencies. Given the background of many of these critics, their unprofessional and distorted outbursts seem to be far more directed at personal publicity than seeking a balanced public debate or trying to get a responsible approach to this whole serious and complicated issue. I could give you some quotes, but I have not got them here with me.

Many people in the country not only have a legitimate reason to own firearms but also, in many cases, they work in an area where they need them as a tool of trade, as is the case with farmers. As I have said, in the country areas in particular and in some urban areas, there are gun clubs. These clubs have an impeccable safety record. This should not be overlooked. We should respect those who want to get involved without maligning them.

It is worth noting that there are schools in country Australia—I know of them in country Victoria—that are willing to train students in firearm safety because they recognise the need for this training and safety. They recognise that legitimate firearm ownership is quite frequent in country areas and that they have a role in teaching that safety. In my own electorate, the finals of the schools clay-trap shooting attracts around 200 student shooters each year. I add that there are not only boys but also females presenting at those finals.

In looking towards the future, it is important to continue to emphasise that ownership should be limited to those who are responsible. That is something that the Attorney‐General has emphasised. At the same time, we should recognise that ownership of legitimate firearms is a pursuit that should be allowed to continue. We should also recognise that firearms are a tool of trade for some people whether they are farmers or people involved in controlling vermin.

We also need to develop a confidence in the community so that, if we do have a proper licensing system and a responsible approach, community safety can be enhanced. I think that is equally important. At the same time, those who do have a legitimate reason to own a firearm should know that, if they are prepared to comply with the law and to behave in a responsible manner, they are not going to feel as though they are being treated like second‐class citizens. We should recognise the fact that we have Olympians who are as good as anyone in the world and who have demonstrated that. I see no reason why we should not encourage people to be involved in that sport, just like all the other athletes that we proudly send to the Olympic Games.

I do see the need for another aspect in this whole issue. With our achievements to date, and with the end of the buyback scheme yesterday, a lot of public confidence has been built up in safety. Nonetheless, this is an ongoing issue. I urge the Attorney‐General to set up consultative committees not only in each state but also with some national focus. I believe that those committees should have some real teeth for the ongoing work needed to encourage the safe and responsible ownership of firearms. The need does extend to ensure that the community is properly informed about what these committees could do and that community expectations are properly met so that legitimate and responsible firearm owners can be confident that they will not be the scapegoats for any future occurrence or tragedy. The tragedy at Port Arthur was clearly not done by the majority and the majority felt just as sick about what had happened there as all other Australians.

I commend again the Attorney‐General. What has been done will help to add to safety, not just because of the reduction in firearms but, equally importantly, because the campaign is helping to shape community attitudes. There is now an expectation—I believe a very strong expectation—that anyone who wants to continue to have the right to own a firearm will be granted that right only on the basis that they demonstrate that they are going to be responsible and that they have a genuine need.

On that basis, what has been achieved is something of truly national significance. I hope that through the use of consultative committees we can ensure that governments, both at the state and federal levels, are able to continue to meet the varied demands of the communities, particularly the different demands that often occur between regional areas and city areas, so that we have a more informed community and, most importantly, a safer community where we can all live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into this place not expecting to speak, until I received a letter this morning and I could not let the opportunity pass—I will come back to that in a moment. At the outset, in relation to the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill, I want to commend first of all, at the highest level, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). The Prime Minister's leadership on this issue has been fundamental to what has happened right across the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to commend the premiers and chief ministers, who had the responsibility in this area for implementing what was an absolutely essential move to reduce the risk factor across the country. The federal Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) is here with us this morning, and I want to take the opportunity to commend him for what he has done, under some trying circumstances, to put this piece of legislation through and to implement it. Daryl Williams, as the Attorney, has been accused by some of being some sort of left‐wing internationalist who wants to brutally disarm this country. He is not, and this legislation—and indeed the measures taken right around the country by state and territory governments—is, of course, a reflection of a community mood, and that community mood is overwhelmingly in favour of what has happened.

I have heard people talk about brutal disarming, about Indonesians coming over the hill, about all this rubbishy stuff which I totally reject. What the Attorney has been able to inject into the whole debate is the fact that there are hundreds of thousands of reasonable firearm owners around this country, and we should commend them for that.

But this legislation, and state legislation, injects into the equation a genuine need and genuine reason and the fundamental issue of registration and licensing that no reasonable Australian should argue against. But there are a number, I have to say, of unreasonable Australians who want to push their strong minority views on this and on other issues.
I come back to the letter which I received this morning in my electorate office and which has just been faxed down to me. It is headed `Treason Trials' and, in part, it says:

I have been instructed to advise you sir, that your name is in the eight batch of one hundred (100) alleged political, judicial, administrative, media and financial criminals to be charged, tried, and where found guilty, HUNG for treason, crimes against the constitution, crimes against the Bill of Rights 1688., etc., and crimes against humanity et. al.
As you would be, or should be well aware by now, this will be your last term in office. After that the Treason Trials.

Mr Deputy Speaker, can I just say to you that this is reflective of some of the looney tunes and minority groups that have taken over the whole debate in terms of firearm reforms. I speak of the Dorings, the McNivens, the Pitts and, indeed—I will get it into the record—Norm Segal of Nambour in Queensland. He is not even in my electorate, but I have had some correspondence from him, as a number of my colleagues have.

BREAK.PARA: It is about time we exposed these people for exactly what they are. They are not interested in responsible gun ownership; all they want is to generate some American militia concept, fundamental to which is the right to own and bear firearms.

To go back to the Bill of Rights 1688, I went along in May of last year, before the legislation had even been developed in Queensland, to a meeting of 800 or 900 people in the City Golf Club in Toowoomba. I found 899½ of them were against me. Why were they against me? Because they were being given all the wrong ideological rubbish. They thought that I would take a very rednecked line in this, but I did not, because what has been done is right.

I want to make the point this morning that we should expose some of these people. The Attorney‐General is well aware of the publication that goes around called Lock, Stock and Barrel. It is ridiculous stuff. It incites people, and what concerns me is that the One Nation is associated, and the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) appears in that particular publication as some paragon of virtue: a paragon of virtue who wants to bring back AR15s—automatic weapons. I think people have to understand that Australia First, Australia Reform and One Nation have behind the scenes people like Mr Segal, who want to inject their extremist rubbish into our community. I hope that this morning the Attorney will have something to say on this. I repeat, we should expose them for what they are.

At the same time, I am sure I am going to get criticised by some of them for what I am saying this morning. I really do not care; I think I represent the vast majority of Australians. If some of these people want to go to the ballot box and vote against me, that is their democratic right, but I stand up here this morning and I am sure that I stand up on behalf of the vast majority of Australians who say that responsibility in firearm ownership is absolutely essential in our community.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sorry I took a little longer than I meant to, but I wanted to inject the point onto the record this morning and to make it very clear that there are some people out there who want to take over the agenda. We should inject a balance back into the debate and reject them for what they are: a bunch of looney tunes and fringe dwellers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIAMS
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This bill is in the nature of a tidying‐up bill. It is a bill that has not attracted a great deal of attention in the debate, which seems to be a common feature of debates in the Main Committee, but it is significant nevertheless. It will enable compensation to be paid for firearms that do not fit within the description of the firearms to be surrendered under the 1996 legislation because they were of a more dangerous type—even more dangerous than the automatic military rifles that were one of the real causes of the buyback scheme. They include submachine guns and heavy machine guns, and they had been identified and handed in in a variety of jurisdictions.

SPEECH.PARA: The buyback scheme, which resulted from the police ministers meeting of 10 May 1996 and subsequent meetings, for the surrender of firearms for compensation, concluded yesterday. It is very pleasing to be able to report that, as of 10 o'clock this morning—that is, soon after the closing of the scheme at midnight—623,632 firearms had been surrendered and compensation to an amount of $296,874,323 had been paid.

Those figures will, no doubt, change somewhat. There will be a number of firearms surrendered in respect of which applications for licences have also been made but not yet dealt with. Those firearms may then be returned when a licence is granted. In respect of others, compensation may be payable if the licence is not granted.

BREAK.PARA: In drawing attention to the success of the buyback, I mention that there was a debate in the House of Representatives last night on a matter of public importance. I made then most of the points that I would wish to make in respect of the conclusion of the buyback. The other speakers included the member for Murray (Mrs Stone) and the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson). The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) also spoke, but took a rather different point of view which I would not commend to the House. The bill we have before us has generated little controversy. I will not comment, except in respect of a comment made by the member for Calare (Mr Andren), which I will come to in due course.

I would like to thank members for their contributions. I thank the member for Reid, the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), the member for Calare, the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek), the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) and the member for Groom (Mr Taylor). You will have noted I did not mention the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), whose comments I will have something to say about in a minute. I think her contribution was regrettable.

The member for Reid raised the question of provision of information on monitoring adherence to the requirements. A number of issues arise in respect of the termination of the buyback scheme, and these will be dealt with in police ministers meetings, the next one of which will be held in November. I will certainly be writing to my state and territory counterparts as police ministers, asking them to report on their monitoring of the uniform registration and licensing system. In due course there will be a full analysis and an audit of the scheme. I have requested them also to write reporting on the implementation of the buyback, with a view to identifying any injustices that may have occurred in the administration of the scheme that could be remedied relatively quickly.

The member for Reid also raised a question of the government adhering to the promise about repaying surplus funds in the Medicare special levy. The question of whether there are going to be moneys left over is an open one at this point. We know how much money has been paid out in compensation; we know that $63 million has been paid out to states and territories and on other administrative arrangements in relation to the buyback scheme.

What we do not have yet is a final figure on the firearms compensation and we are very far from a final figure on the compensation to be paid to firearms dealers. The exercise there is rather more elaborate than in assessing compensation for the particular firearms because what needs to be identified is the loss in value of the business or, if the business closes, the value of the business that has terminated. It will take some months to ascertain the appropriate figures and make the appropriate payments.

The commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stands that any surplus funds will be returned to taxpayers through the Medicare levy system. I apprehend that, if the amount of money that remains is relatively small, the community might have an expectation that it would be devoted to an appropriate measure rather than chewed up in administration on the return of the modest amount.

The member for Calare raised an issue that pertains to his electorate. He indicated there was some anger about Australian Defence Industries Ltd surrendering stock under the buyback scheme and acquiring payment. This is not an issue that arises under the bill under consideration. What was done was lawful under the 1996 act. He can be assured that because ADI is wholly Commonwealth owned, it does amount, in effect, to a transfer of Commonwealth moneys to a Commonwealth entity and therefore gives rise to little concern.

The member for Calare also—and he was the only one—expressed some reservations about the particular bill while supporting the general buyback scheme. His suggestion was that the money could be better spent by a commitment to recovering other prohibited firearms. I do not think what he is suggesting is necessary at this juncture. We have yet to assess the level of success of the buyback scheme. No doubt if there are steps that need to be taken as a result of the assessment, these will be taken by agreement among police ministers.

This bill complements the 1996 act, as noted by the member for Fisher. The old‐style military weapons—and I use the word `weapons' advisedly; they are weapons, not firearms—were not in the minds of the police ministers following the tragedy at Port Arthur. We did not have in mind that there would be in the community bazookas, aircraft cannon, Bofors cannon and the like, which subsequently, it turned out, there were. The surrender of historically prohibited weapons for fair and proper compensation is certainly within the spirit of the national program and this bill would allow for it to be achieved.

The member for Dickson raised concerns about the adequacy of the compensation arrangements. That is not an issue that arises in relation to this bill, but the buyback scheme was administered by the different states and territories. They had different arrangements pertaining—some started earlier than others. It is evident that in each jurisdiction there were some difficulties, at least at the outset, in establishing what was the most efficient scheme. Most of those difficulties were resolved as time went by, although there was, no doubt, considerable pressure, especially in Queensland, in meeting the target within the time frame.
The member for Wakefield followed the member for Oxley and addressed some of her remarks, as I will do also. He pointed out that the government did not seek to disarm Australia, as she had asserted.

The member for Oxley indicated that the day is coming when the civilian population will be disarmed. That statement is totally wrong. The government has no intention of going down that path, nor to my knowledge does any other government or any opposition in the country. It is not only wrong, it is inflammatory, dangerous and irresponsible. I commend the members who spoke subsequently and indicated their rejection of that particular view.

The member for Oxley seems to think that the only people who will be left with firearms will be criminals. I cannot imagine where on earth that conclusion could be derived from. The uniform laws contemplate that there will be valid uses of firearms and valid purposes for holding them. That is the nub of the scheme.

There is recognition that there are genuine reasons for holding firearms of whatever category. It recognises that there are, in some cases, genuine needs for having the more dangerous category C and D firearms. That is part of the scheme and it is not intended to change it. The member for Wannon, among others, mentioned the particular uses as tools of trade to which some firearms are put and mention was also made of recreational use under very strict conditions.

The member for Oxley suggested that violence and crime are not proportional to the availability of firearms. The point I would make in response to that is that she seems to have no research to back that up. I question the assumption. But what is evident from the research is that the availability of firearms is related to the number of deaths and injuries resulting from firearms. In Australia we have between 400 and 500 deaths from firearms, the bulk of which—80 per cent approximately—are suicides. The relationship between the availability of firearms and the suicide rate in a particular community is direct. By removing more than 600,000 firearms we may, and I hope we have, set in train a reduction in the death rate and the injury rate from firearms.

The member for Oxley asserted that the vast majority of Australians have not handed in their firearms and again mentioned that criminals, one should be assured, have not. The member for Oxley is talking through her hat. The research conducted by the government, about which I spoke in the MPI in the house yesterday at some length, indicates that there is very strong support for the uniform laws. What was indicated with that was that, nationwide, there is very strong compliance and intention to comply. The vast majority of Australians about whom the member for Oxley speaks in fact support the laws and the vast majority have complied with the laws. Again, what she says is inflammatory, dangerous and irresponsible.

The member for Wakefield spoke as a user of a firearm and I think the attitude that he evinced towards the use of firearms is a healthy and an appropriate one. The member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) raised particularly the question of those who had surrendered firearms by 30 September, but whose licence applications had not been dealt with. That is a particular situation which has been addressed already, but we will closely monitor that situation and the reports from the various jurisdictions in order to ensure that there has been no injustice in the closing off of the scheme.

The member for Wannon, whom I commend as the chairman of the consultative committee, who assisted the government in the formulation of the proposals, is a very experienced firearms owner, as his speech indicated. He highlighted a number of the features of the current scheme, I think appropriately. The safety record of firearms owners, and in particular those who participate in clubs, is well‐known and the responsible attitude evinced by those people is a matter of record.

He questioned the administration, giving an example of delays referred to by a constituent in Victoria. I am not able to respond directly to that, but I did indicate earlier that the administrations in the different jurisdictions did take time to settle down. That is certainly forgivable because the governments were doing something that had never been done before and, in some cases, they were setting up registration and licensing systems that did not exist in any form prior to the commencement of the scheme.

The member for Wannon has calculated the ratio of firearms handed in to population, and gave some interesting statistics. He queried whether the ownership of firearms does vary that much. It seems in fact that it does. I have been advised that New South Wales, for example, has a third of Australia's population but only one-fifth of the firearms, and that may account for the relatively low percentage figure that the member for Wannon referred to.

In Tasmania and Queensland there were relatively few, if any, rules relating to the ownership of firearms. That may account for the very high percentage in Tasmania, where there was no registration system at all. In the Northern Territory, I would suggest, it is much more likely that people would own firearms than they would in the southern states.

Victoria seems to have a different culture from other places. There has been a high ownership of shotguns in that state, particularly in the rural and regional areas, although, notably, there was a higher number of firearms handed in in metropolitan centres than there were in Victorian rural and regional centres. Western Australia and South Australia have had strict licensing schemes for some time and strict ownership rules, which may account for why their percentages are relatively low. However, analysis would provide better information, and I hope that will be done.

The member for Wannon mentioned the question of training in schools. One of the features of the uniform scheme was the development of training packages for new firearms owners. What is occurring in schools, which I had not heard about before, sounds very good. He also made particular mention about consultative committees. He suggested that there will be a need for ongoing work in relation to the safe and responsible ownership of firearms and a need to ensure that community expectations and safety expectations are met. This is an idea that I think should be taken up and examined and I propose to do that.

The member for Groom referred to some extremist views that had been expressed to him in a letter. That letter is one that I think should be referred to appropriate authorities. Those sorts of letters should not be received by anybody, particularly a public figure, from somebody who is simply making threats. He referred to some of the extremist views that had been expressed by a number of people. I reject them in the same way that he does. I think all right thinking people in Australia would reject the notion that firearms should be owned in order that there can be militia groups established who will conduct their own treason trials, as he pointed out.
That concludes the comments I wish to make on those who spoke. I commend the bill to the House and thank the opposition for its support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

TITLE.XREF: NATIONAL ROAD TRANSPORT COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 September, on motion by Mr Ronaldson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very straightforward piece of legislation which does one thing only, namely, extend the life of the National Road Transport Commission by a year, on the basis that it is necessary to allow time for further discussions between the federal government and the states with respect to the future role that the NRTC will play and what future framework may be involved with developing that role. The opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting in the brief comments that I will make that this is probably the sole substantial area of bipartisanship between myself and the former Minister for Transport, Mr Sharp, and I would commend both him and the government for continuing the work that was initiated by the former government with respect to regulation of road transport activities and the National Road Transport Commission, and providing the support and assistance necessary to pursue that work. As I have said, it is probably the only area of substantive agreement in the major policy areas so it must have something going for it.

The work of the NRTC has involved gradually developing, in consultation with the states—and, of course, relevant stakeholders, such as the industry and the Transport Workers Union, users and various parties—a structure of uniform national rules with respect to road transport. Of course, that covers a very wide variety of issues—not just things like uniform charging and registration issues but, also, driver hours, safety and mass limits. There are a long list of issues that have to be addressed.

I commend John Hurlstone, David O'Sullivan and the commission on the work that they have done to date. It is a remarkable tribute to them that they have managed to achieve so much and that that has been done in spite of the constraints of our antiquated federal system which means that it is impossible to do anything in these areas without getting agreement from a very wide range of players, many of whom have a variety of different agendas.

It is also very pleasing to see the NRTC pursuing a range of innovative agendas on a number of issues. I was particularly pleased to see that the question of penalties for drivers breaching regulations with respect to safety, driving hours, and the like, has been addressed by the commission, and that the question of company owners, or prime contractors, being held liable for breaches perpetrated by their drivers has actually been raised by the commission.

One of the critical issues in Australian transport policy and, indeed, public life generally at the moment is the way that drivers in the road transport industry are forced by employers, contractors, users and circumstances associated with the needs of the users to work ridiculously long hours in grossly unsafe circumstances which threaten the lives and the wellbeing, not only of the drivers, but also of other users of public roads. We are all very conscious of some of the tragedies that have occurred over the past five years or so that have related to excessive driver hours. It is an issue that I regard as one of the upmost importance and I am pleased to see that the NRTC has also given it a very high priority.

In that context I just wanted to give an example that was drawn to my attention only yesterday to illustrate just how serious this issue is and how difficult it is for ordinary truck drivers to escape the pressures that put them in a position where they are forced to work ridiculously long hours and to ultimately become a danger because of fatigue, not only to themselves, but also to other road users. In some instances they end up being forced to use drugs and this ultimately increases the level of danger that is already existing.

The example I would like to cite concerns a South Australian company, quite a substantial company. A driver has regularly been doing three round trips Adelaide to Sydney per week, which is, of course, a pretty lengthy trip. On top of that he has to do a range of things associated with routine maintenance, loading, unloading, refuelling, and all of those sorts of things. He is working regularly in excess of 90 hours a week, the vast bulk of which is on the road driving a potentially lethal piece of equipment.

This particular driver was on the way back into Adelaide only very recently when he stopped at a weighbridge, showed his logbook and indicated that he had clearly been breaching driving hours regulations. As a result of that his company was telephoned and he was instructed on the spot that he was dismissed. He was told that he should have taken a back route to avoid the weighbridge, that he was to take his rig and leave it at a nearby BP service station, and that it was his own problem as to how he then got home. There was instant dismissal because he had advised the regulators, or effectively the enforcers of regulations, that he had breached the regulations. This was not by some fly‐by‐night tiny company either; this was a substantial and quite well‐known road transport operator in Adelaide.

It is that sort of problem that is quite widespread. It is those sorts of pressures that force good honest working Australians to break the law in order to be able to work. As a driver, he is being offered two alternatives: he breaks the law or he does not have a job. That is the reality for a lot of drivers and that is why it is of fundamental importance for regulators, politicians and organisations like the NRTC to ensure that everything possible is done to minimise this sort of conduct.

It is probably impossible to stamp it out completely, because it is difficult to regulate, but we have to place maximum priority and emphasis on eradicating this sort of behaviour by companies and contractors. In that context, not only do I applaud the NRTC but also I am very pleased to see that industry organisations—like the Road Transport Forum, Victorian Road Transport Association and other industry associations—are treating these issues very seriously. One of the other problems in this area is that, if there is a proliferation of bad operators who break the law, it places the good operators—the decent companies of which there are many—at an immense competitive disadvantage.

We have already seen the majors like Mayne Nickless, Brambles and TNT gradually exiting from general road transport freight. One of the elements in that change—by no means the only one—is the problem of unfair competition faced by those companies by people breaking the law. It is important for the decent parts of the industry that the law is strictly and properly enforced, so that they can actually compete on a level playing field, where competition should exist on efficiency and reliability, not on breaking the law and endangering the lives of their drivers and other citizens on the public highway.

I commend the industry leaders for the seriousness with which they are approaching this problem and their willingness to address it. It is a very large industry. There are thousands of operators with a very wide range of people involved. It is very difficult to pursue this issue in a way that guarantees that the regulations are fully and comprehensively enforced.

Essentially, that is all I have to say on the legislation. As I said, the opposition supports the extension of one year for the life of the NRTC to provide a breathing space in which the various governments can negotiate about the future of the NRTC. My suggestion would be that there is a substantial future for the NRTC, once the bulk of its work developing uniform regulations is completed.

There is a substantial future for the NRTC in the enforcement field—not as a direct enforcer, because that ultimately will remain the territory of the states, but as a facilitator, in the same role that it has had in the regulatory sphere. I see the NRTC having a potentially valuable role as a national facilitator in the enforcement field, working with the various enforcement bodies to ensure that the regulations are properly enforced, to ensure that there is a degree of commonality and consistency across the various jurisdictions, and to ensure that there is a Commonwealth involvement, albeit by consent with the states, in that enforcement process, so that there is enough muscle and public commitment to ensure that the sort of story that I have just recounted with respect to this Adelaide driver becomes a rarity rather than the relatively common experience that it currently is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1997 . As the previous speaker said, through an amendment to the act the bill will extend the life of the NRTC by one year. There is already a strong feeling that we have moved a great deal of distance in terms of reforms to road transport in Australia, but it is felt that another year is needed to bed down the reforms that are already well in the pipeline and to work out what the best future is for the NRTC.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me list some of the most positive reforms that have been forthcoming since the NRTC was formed in 1991. There has been the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Act, which provides the basis for uniform national road rules; the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act, which allows for uniform and consistent registration requirements across the country; and the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act, providing for a safer operating regime for the transport by road of dangerous goods. And driving hours for long‐distance coaches have been regulated to ensure greater safety for all road users.

These reforms have been initiated since 1991. They have involved numerous negotiations and consultations between the states and territories and the Commonwealth. Originally it was probably never imagined that such a detailed negotiation was required. But there is further time needed to make sure that the reforms already under way are bedded down and institutional arrangements made are the best for the nation as a whole in the future.

The government last year reviewed the achievements, the accomplishments and the functions of the commission. The main findings of the review were accepted in February this year by the Ministerial Council for Road Transport. Commonwealth, state and territory officials are now working to turn the review principles into amendments to the National Road Transport Commission Act, but they also need additional time to achieve all of these objectives.

Clearly, Australia is an enormous continent. Most of the inland communities are effectively only linked by road and are dependent on an efficient network to move their primary production to the ports and manufacturers. And, of course, our cities depend to a very substantial degree on the transport industry to keep their commerce moving.

A 1996 report of the Department of Transport and Regional Development, entitled A national approach to road transport regulation, found that the transport industry dominates freight in Australia, accounting for 75 per cent of the value of the Australian freight market. As part of the report, a survey of road transport companies was carried out. According to the respondents, differing road transport regulations between states and territories in the past had imposed the most substantial and unnecessary costs on the industry and on transport users.

The report noted that, while substantial administrative changes have resulted from increased national uniformity in Australia's road transport regulatory regime, costs to users of road freight have not significantly dropped. Savings have been invested in better equipment and the need to meet increased costs, for example in fuel. Reforms leading to uniform mass and loading regulations, uniform vehicle standards and better access for B‐doubles will allow firms greater freedom to select the best driver‐vehicle combinations for a given task in the future.

National standards have enabled firms to make more efficient use of their existing fleets by giving them greater freedom to select the most appropriate vehicles. Small firms in particular will be able to have more flexibility in terms of the use of drivers always under a safer regime and, as time goes by, they would expect to see the costs of using road freight reflected in these substantial reforms.

In the past, state and territory borders have to some extent become artificial market boundaries and barriers and they have provided some shelter for intrastate operators compared with those operating interstate. Under a national approach, the artificial disadvantage to interstate operators can be removed.

Prior to Federation the colonies in Australia were each responsible for their transport infrastructure and regulation. The constitution recognised the integrity of the borders between states, but made sure that interstate commerce would always flow freely without taxes or tariffs. It has been the transport regulations that have assisted colonies to maintain some advantages—one against the other—over time, and it is up to this nation to make sure that we have in fact genuine free trade flowing between states.

BREAK.PARA: Responsibility for the development of road transport regulations has rested primarily with state and territory governments, and each has applied a regulatory regime considered best to suit its particular circumstances. One of the great achievements of the National Road Transport Commission has been the bringing together of all of those interests, where they recognise the nation as a whole must be, at the end of the day, the winner.

In effect, we still have a long way to go. The additional year that is being identified as the major thrust of this amendment will be the year needed to make sure the states, the territories and the Commonwealth together produce the best regime possible.

In an effort to try to overcome some of the consequences of the interstate parochialism, the federal government, in 1987, introduced the federal interstate registration scheme, or FIRS. FIRS has been restricted in its ability to compete with state registration schemes, however, as FIRS registered vehicles cannot be used to provide intrastate services, while state registered vehicles can be used to provide both inter‐ and intrastate services. That is just one of the anomalies we need to work with.

National Road Transport Commission recommendations are submitted to the Ministerial Council for Road Transport for its approval. Once the council agrees, the onus is on each government to amend its regulations to achieve national consistency. The Commonwealth is responsible for relevant legislation on behalf of the ACT, and for legislation to cover vehicles registered under FIRS. Other governments are then required to adopt substantially the intent and content of the legislation applicable in the ACT as their own.

In the case of emission and noise standards, these are presently developed by the NRTC in conjunction with state and federal environment ministers. However, while noise and emission standards for new vehicles are controlled through the Australian design rule system administered by the Federal Office of Road Safety, second‐hand or in‐service vehicles' noise and emission standards are subject to a template process. In other words, they remain ultimately in the domain of the states and territories—another example where we still need time to work through anomalies that are not in the best interests of the nation.

It is important to remember that much road transport takes place in built‐up areas with substantial road congestion and population densities. Most road freight trips do not cross a state or territory border, and a high proportion of them are in urban areas. About 80 per cent of all road freight trips are less than 100 kilometres in length; thus this issue of noise abatement and emissions is an example of one of the most important areas where work in reconciling processes still has to be done.

At the end of the day we need to be sure that the needs of environment protection and of those working in the industry are brought together in a very tight fit. It is not just the environment that stands to gain as we continue the road transport industry reforms.

A 1994 report by the Centre for International Economics estimated that Australia's road transport industry accounts for two per cent of Australia's GDP, and about 2.1 per cent of total employment. This would put the value of road transport at $8.5 billion, employing at least 160,000 people. In l994 the National Transport Planning Task Force found that road transport makes up 73 per cent of the value of Australia's freight market. It showed that the total quantity of freight carried by road increased from 18 per cent in 1975‐76 to 33 per cent in l990‐91, and since l975‐76 the average length of road freight trips has nearly doubled. Clearly, we are dealing with an industry here that is growing in proportion to the enterprise of Australia's businesses, and we have to make sure it is world best and efficient.

A l995 Industry Commission report calculated that road transport industry reforms would increase Australia's GDP by about $800 million a year, based on the size of the l995 economy. In a l996 survey by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, road freight operators were found to be superior in terms of reliability and service quality compared to other freight operators. They have been doing a good job. It was suggested that on some prime line haul routes such as Melbourne to Sydney, rail needed to become some 20 per cent cheaper to compete.

The performance of the road freight industry in Australia has also been found to compare well with international best practice. Prices were similar to those charged in the USA, Canada and New Zealand. Vehicle operating costs in Australia were found to be in the middle of the international range for both short and long distance services.

Road transport service holds a special place in the economic wellbeing of Australia. The statistics show that the road industry itself is doing its best to be efficient and safe, but it requires Australian state and Commonwealth regulations to ensure that they are working in an environment where the interests of their employees and of the consumers are protected.

We have already heard from the previous speaker that there are often great difficulties in the pressures drivers face in trying to cover the distances in the times required. There are a great many anomalies still at work in the industry. Let me give you an example.

Imagine the frustrations and the safety implications of an interstate trucking business faced with a 13‐hour trip between Sydney and Brisbane. Under New South Wales regulations still in force, a 14‐hour shift is legal. That is a shift with one driver driving continuously. Under Queensland law, however, the maximum time he may drive without a break is 12 hours. So the lone driver heading up the road from Sydney to Brisbane drives without a break and exchanges with someone else for the last hour or so of the trip or, indeed, the transport operator employs two people for the duration of the journey.

Clearly, such anomalies are nonsense. They are not in the interest of an efficient business. Clearly, someone driving a 14‐hour shift is driving to the limits of their ability to remain at all times at the peak of their efficiency. That sort of shift, obviously, can lead from time to time to endangering others on the road.

Likewise we have different road speed limits in New South Wales and Victoria. On the Hume Highway in Victoria, a huge truck can travel up to 100 kilometres per hour. In New South Wales, trucks without 100 kilometres per hour limiters are required to go some 90 kilometres per hour on that same highway where there are single lanes. A truck driving at 90 kilometres an hour on the Hume Highway is a frustration to both a truck driver and a line of cars piled behind.

We need to look very carefully still at the reforms that have taken place, but also at the implementation of those reforms. We need to listen very carefully to the industry, many of whom are still saying to us that there are pressures in this industry which make it unsafe on the roads and mean that we are still not getting the best efficiency out of our industry.

The government understands these needs. Today we are putting an amendment before the House which gives another year of service to the National Road Transport Commission. We are trying to ensure that, with our huge opportunities for developing our exports, we are putting in place one of the world's best transport sectors in the sense that they are not impeded in any way with regulations that are inconsistent from one state jurisdiction to the next and are not inconsistent with national rules that apply overall. I therefore, very strongly, commend this amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always good to take the opportunity to talk on road‐related matters with the success that this government has struck in the development of some new road programs across Australia and, more particularly, in our part of the country with the development of the Pacific Highway within the RONI program.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill that we are debating today is the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1997. The bill extends the operation of the NRTC for another 12 months. I think it is important that the parliament notes, first of all, the manner in which this organisation has been structured financially in that all jurisdictions helped fund the NRTC, with the Commonwealth putting in 35 per cent of the total annual funding of $3.6 million.

More importantly, it bridges the divide across the Commonwealth. The greatest impediments to development and efficiency in this country have always been state borders. At last, as a nation, I can see this country ever so slowly starting to mature in being able to work together in areas such as those that the NRTC have been working with on reforms in the road transport industry.

It is interesting to note that the Industry Commission estimated that gains from reforms to the national road transport industry would provide up to $0.8 billion to GDP. That is a significant amount of money. It is a significant improvement in efficiency in what we do in Australia. It is important that we should look at not only building better roads to improve efficiency and safety and all those other things that we are trying to achieve, but also focus on how an industry is operated and try to do away with a lot of those inefficiencies, which predominantly flow from different regulations in different states.

It is very good to see the work that the NRTC has achieved. I noted in the second reading speech of the former minister, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), that since the NRTC was created in 1991 heavy vehicle charges have been reformed. The speech also notes that the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Act has been passed; that the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act allows for uniform and consistent registration requirements across the country; that the Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act provides for a safer operating regime for the transport by road of dangerous goods; and that driving hours for long distance coaches and for trucks have reached an advanced stage of development.

I also note the comments from the previous speaker, the member for Murray (Mrs Stone), regarding the differences between the states. There have been some great achievements made in this area. In no small way that is due to an increasing commitment between the Commonwealth and the states to improve the processes involved in transport in Australia. I think everybody would be aware of the communique that came out of the national rail summit that the former minister had convened recently in Melbourne, which was another breakthrough as far as a national decision is concerned. It is in line with what I was saying: that this nation is slowly maturing in this area of being able to work together and not having petty jealousies across state borders.

Just out of interest, and this is something that my committee's inquiry into national road funding has noticed, there are still some parochial views held across Australia with regard to road funding. I came in for a bit of attention around Australia when we were conducting the inquiry because the Pacific Highway just happens to run through my electorate as it goes up the mid north coast. But it should not go unsaid that that particular piece of Australia's transport infrastructure has been screaming out, as have the members that represent the electorates along it, for attention for a lot of years. The Labor Party will jump up and say, `We were going to do it if we had got another term.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The 14‐year defence!

—It was another 14‐year defence: `In our 14th year, we would have done it, you can be assured about that,' but there was no way that they were going to pay attention to it in the 13 years that they were in government. That is notwithstanding the fact that they held two seats along some of the critical parts of the Pacific Highway.

SPEECH.PARA: The development of the strategy that the coalition government has with regard to road funding and the attention that is being placed on the national highway system—and not only on the development of the roads of national importance but also the reintroduction of the black spots program—have been very important elements of addressing the serious issues of transport in Australia, particularly road transport. It seems that the opposition is going to support this bill, and it was interesting to listen to the comments of the shadow minister, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), in this regard. His comments are certainly welcome and the support of the opposition is welcome.

We look forward to more positive gains during the next 12 months from the NRTC in advancing a national strategy for road transport in this area. Hopefully, in the future, we will see a national strategy—that is, one agreed to by all states—with further development of the very important network and infrastructure of roads, no matter what category they fall into across Australia. Until we reach that stage of maturity in attitude between the Commonwealth and the states, particularly coming back from the states, we will not progress it fast enough. We will not achieve the efficiencies that we must achieve to be much more competitive in the world scene.

But the most important thing that can be achieved from a national agreement on a strategy in this regard, as far as the National Road Transport Commission is concerned, and also with a national road strategy, is the efficiency in the expenditure of taxpayers' dollars. It goes without saying that we have seen what can be done with the Pacific Highway program when there is agreement between the Commonwealth and the state of New South Wales to fund that road. New mechanisms are being put into place. One section that is being built at the moment just south of my electorate is being done on a design, construct and maintain basis. The contract that was let came in, I think, somewhere in the vicinity of $60 million cheaper than the RTA's estimates.

That is a new form of contract where there is a massive contract for 27‐odd kilometres of brand new dual carriageway highway. The RTA estimated $196,000,000 to do the job and the successful contractor is going to do it for $130,000,000. Those sorts of innovations are what we are really responsible for in this place, making sure that we get the maximum efficiency out of taxpayers' dollars and that in turn will create a much more efficient road transport industry.

It is important that we support this bill and it is important we see the continuation of the very good work that the National Road Transport Commission has achieved so far. I support this bill in extending that for the next 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—May I, first of all, thank the shadow minister, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) for his support and constructive input into this debate, as may I also thank my colleagues, the members for Murray (Mrs Stone) and Lyne (Mr Vaile) for their contribution to an extremely important bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be acutely aware, a uniform and consistent national operating environment for road transport is the aim of both this government and the states and indeed follows on from the work done by the former government as alluded to by the member for Melbourne. We view it as a pivotal process.
In my own electorate of Ballarat, roads and road safety and a proper operating environment are the key both from an economic sense and also from a safety point of view, being on the national highway.

As you would also be acutely aware, a review of the reform process and the NRTC legislation was completed in early 1997. There were a range of improvements recommended including a continuation of the NRTC Act. They are significant matters. They need to be dealt with appropriately and, as honourable members will be aware, they require the unanimous agreement of heads of government.

I thank the opposition for enabling us to get this legislation through quickly and we need to do it before the expiry of the sunset clause. We will then move to implementing this quite significant and substantial range of improvements in this area once we have that agreement by the heads of government. It is extremely important.
I again thank the opposition for their assistance in moving this through quickly. I hope the Senate also is of a similar mind to do so and on that note I will not make any further comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
