SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1997 was introduced into the House on 26 June 1997. The purpose is the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board and the transfer of the AWB's wheat marketing and financing functions to an AWB wholly owned holding company and its subsidiaries.

SPEECH.PARA: The AWB is to retain control over export and marketing of wheat overseas. The AWB is to obtain control over the wheat industry fund, also known as WIF, until the WIF component of the levy on wheat sales is terminated on 30 June 1997. The AWB is to be treated as an agent of nominated companies in respect of new season wheat transactions in the season beginning on or after 1 July 1997.

The wheat industry of Australia is one of the great historic industries, with $3 billion worth of exports. Therefore, as we would all know and understand, it is inextricably linked to the history of the country. It has a long history of government intervention, beginning in 1915, with the Wheat Board established as a wartime measure and the breaking of the collusive wheat merchants' control. In the 1930s, the Great Depression led to the government direction of wheat production levels. The Senate and states remained barriers to legislative direction. Finally, in November 1931, the wheat bounty was passed by the parliament and there was recognition of both Commonwealth and state interest. I would add that there is still evidence right back to those times, right across Australia I would imagine, of the impact on land use and land tenure of the management of the wheat industry.

In 1948, the Labor government introduced guaranteed prices, a home consumption price, the Australian Wheat Board—as we have come to know it—and stabilisation arrangements. Between 1948 and 1984, there were a series of wheat plans based on these basic concepts. From 1979 to 1983, there were calls for reform from the High Court, the Senate, the Auditor‐General and the Industries Assistance Commission.

In all of that, the balance was for the growers, who by and large were small business operators, against the power—as was noted in 1915—of the merchants and the world traders. So the Wheat Board has shown a great resilience and ability to adapt, and, as much as any other contribution by any other organisation, has given a stability and strength to regional Australia, for which, as a former wheat grower, and going back as far as my grandparents, I have been extremely grateful.

The 1984 Wheat Marketing Act introduced a system of permits for wheat used for stock feed, where producers and consumers could trade directly but under guidelines and regulations; alterations to the guaranteed minimum price arrangements which sent increased market signals to producers; and five separate categories for wheat for which prices were underwritten, as against one category previously, to reduce the cross‐subsidisation and allow a stronger market focus.

In 1986‐87, a period I remember very well, the McColl royal commission into grain storage, handling and transport recommended a number of improvements including: marketing authorities to deal with a deregulated distribution system; removal of the requirement that market authorities grant sole receival rights to the state agencies for storage and handling; and removal of all restrictions and impediments for the transport of grain by road. There was a well‐known phrase, the least cost path, because before that we had a range of impediments related to the history and development of the road‐rail industry. The commission also recommended a disaggregation of port service and sea transport costs, with charges to growers and other users to reflect actual port costs—that is, reforms to allow charges for port and shipping services to more closely reflect actual costs incurred.

In 1988, we had the IAC wheat industry report, which recommended: limiting the AWB's power to control exports to prescribed markets; extending the grower‐to‐buyer and permit arrangements to export sales; extending permit arrangements to cover all domestic sales, with no restraints on reselling in the domestic market—and there was great debate on that issue at the time; the AWB's obligation to supply the domestic market; discontinuation of the administrative domestic pricing mechanism; discontinuation of underwriting provisions; and advance payments to be a declared proportion of the season's expected market returns, with the option of negotiable certificates in lieu. Finally, the IAC wheat industry report recommended that, as far as practicable, individual payments to growers were to reflect actual market returns and associated costs.

In 1989, we had further government reform and deregulation, no doubt contributed to by the previous IAC report. There was deregulation of the domestic wheat market through the removal of the AWB's compulsory acquisition powers and termination of administered domestic pricing arrangements. There was the introduction of a fixed government guarantee on AWB borrowings in relation to pool wheat for advance payments, payments in lieu of final payments and operational expenses associated with sales where the AWB's borrowing liability exceeded money available for repayment of the borrowing.

Further in that particular development we have the removal of the requirements that there be a majority of growers among board members. I remember the angst in the industry at that time and there was a feeling, perhaps, of loss of control by members. But the philosophy, I think, has been proven to be sound and right in that the industry and the government of the day brought in the expertise—in marketing, quality control: a whole range of different expertise—other than just that of the growers, as important as that is.

Then there was the establishment of the wheat industry fund. We have funded that principally from a minimum two per cent grower levy to generate a capital base for financing the AWB's marketing activities. And finally, there is the AWB objective of maximising net returns to producers by minimising storage handling and transport costs, with costs to be passed back to individual growers where possible.

This legislation delivers control back to the growers as requested by the grains industry, and from 1 July 1999 wheat marketing will be undertaken by a grower controlled and run company. The new company will comprise a holding company with two subsidiaries, pooling and domestic trading. There will be A‐class and B‐class shares and the organisation of that was set down in the speech of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). Transitional provisions will apply until 30 June 1999. There will be the cessation of the WIF levy and, of course, there is the issue of the composition of the board of the AWB.

In conclusion may I just put on record my appreciation of the industry's effort in coming to terms with the emerging competition policy and striking the balance between the stability that is so important out there for the wheat industry in regional Australia, and that which has to be market focused. In respect of those original pioneers who saw the importance of the AWB, I am sure they would be appreciative of the strength of the new arrangements adapting to the 21st century. Thank you.
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the sale of Jandakot airport in Western Australia be conditional on approval of the proposed fourth runway.
(2) Will the planning and environmental impact process for the fourth runway be concluded by the time the sale is completed.
(3) What precisely will be offered for sale.
(4) Will any prospective owner be contractually bound to address noise problems associated with the airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Neither the Government nor the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is planning the construction of a fourth runway at Jandakot Airport at this time.

(2) A draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) was prepared in 1992 in connection with the FAC's Proposed Additional Developments at Jandakot Airport. The FAC considered a range of future aviation and non‐aviation development initiatives for the Airport, including construction of a fourth runway from about the year 2010 should future demand warrant such investment. Following release of the draft EIS, the then Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (now Environment Australia) requested that further studies be carried out in relation to aircraft noise around Jandakot Airport. The FAC proposes to prepare a supplement to the draft EIS following completion of the Jandakot Airport Noise Study which is currently underway. However, as indicated in response to (1) above, there are no plans for the construction of a fourth runway at this time.
(3) The airport site comprising 618 hectares, together with existing infrastructure and commercial business, will be offered for sale.

(4) The Government does not anticipate binding the new owner through a specific contractual clause to address noise problems. The new owner will be required to observe all laws that apply to the Airport (be they Commonwealth, State or municipal laws). In this context, the Commonwealth will require the new owner to obtain and maintain the necessary licences and approvals to operate the aerodrome and ensure that all air traffic and navigation service obligations are met in accordance with applicable legislation and regulations (including Air Services Regulations).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What social security entitlements does an unemployed person have who sets up as a sole trader and is then seeking work on his or her own account.
(2) If such a sole trader is able to provide work for another person, is he or she entitled to a job seeker's allowance.
(3) Is it an anomaly that job seeker allowance is not available to help the creation of a trading entity or small business that provides work for other unemployed persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) To be eligible for Newstart Allowance a customer must firstly be unemployed. A person who is substantially involved in running a business would not normally be regarded as unemployed. An exception to this is where the business is on a small scale and designed to be a supplement rather than an alternative to wages and is compatible with taking a full‐time job.

Where it is determined that a person is unemployed for the purpose of meeting the eligibility requirements for Newstart Allowance, they must also satisfy a set of requirements known as the activity test. A major requirement of the activity test is that a person must be actively searching for and willing to undertake any suitable paid work. A self‐employed person generally must meet this job search requirement, including not refusing an offer of employment because it interferes with their business. Sub‐contractors or other self‐employed people, who hire themselves and/or their plant or equipment out for particular jobs, may be regarded as unemployed when out of work but they too must meet the above tests.

In certain circumstances, the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) may approve the development of self employment opportunities as an activity which satisfies activity test requirements and Newstart Allowance can be paid.

(2) The provision of work for another person would not in itself disqualify a person from receiving Newstart Allowance. However, it is unlikely that a sole trader in these circumstances would be considered to be unemployed or be able to satisfy the activity test requirements. If, for example, a sub‐contractor obtains some casual work, he or she would not be disqualified from payment on the basis that they employed another person. Where the work was of a casual nature, they would be treated in a similar manner to other casual workers and would generally remain qualified for payment, subject to the income test. Self‐employed people earning income may receive reduced payments or no payments at all.

(3) Newstart Allowance provides income support to unemployed people who are looking for work or who are engaged in other labour market related activities. There is no anomaly in denying an unemployment payment to someone who is not unemployed. People who have been on Newstart Allowance for at least 6 months can undertake self employment development (SED) as part of their activity agreement. SED can be approved as part of a person's activity agreement where the CES is satisfied that the business will be commercially viable within 12 months of commencement and it is likely to provide the person with full‐time employment at a level of income at least equivalent to the rate of Newstart Allowance. The approval is intended to be for the developmental stage only and it is expected that once the business commences, income support will cease and healthy, fair competition will prevail. In addition, the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS), administered by the CES, provides income support for up to 12 months to people setting up and running businesses, as well as training in business management.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to articles on pages A1, A4 and A15 in The Age of 11 June 1997 concerning experiments conducted by the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories upon children in orphanages.

(2) Were experiments conducted upon children who were child migrants under the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act; if so, (a) in which institutions were experiments conducted, (b) was the permission of the guardian of the child migrant sought; if so, (i) when was permission granted, (ii) for which children and (iii) for what institutions and (c) was there danger to the health and safety of child migrants living in orphanages and institutions of contracting infectious or contagious diseases without inoculation or injection.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No information on whether the children involved in the research were child migrants is contained in the relevant research articles and I am unable to assist the honourable member with this inquiry.

(a) Some research was conducted in the Saint Joseph's Foundling Hospital (formerly known as the Broadmeadows Home). In another research paper, nursing staff of the Berry Street Foundling Hospital, the Presbyterian Babies' Home and Saint Gabriel's Babies' Home are acknowledged, therefore it can be assumed research was conducted in these institutions. In a number of articles, the childrens' or babies' home or orphanage was not specified. Not all participants in the studies were recruited from such institutions.
(b) The research articles do not mention issues relating to consent.
(b) (i) There is inadequate information to answer this question.

(b) (ii) It is assumed that children in each study would have been treated equally with regard to consent issues, regardless of their migrant status, however, there is inadequate information to answer this question.
(b) (iii) There is inadequate information to answer this question.
(c) Yes, due to the fact that all children involved were living in close quarters.
